analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya  āhuneyya vagga
translated: Numerical Discourses With Verses 6.1 🔽1. The One Worthy of Offerings

original: Paṭhamaāhuneyyasutta
analyzed: paṭhama āhuneyya sutta
translated: Numbered Discourses The Greater Section The Worthy of Offerings (First Version)🔽The Worthy of Offerings

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Park.

original: Tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
analyzed: tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi
translated: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

original: “bhikkhavo”ti.
analyzed: bhikkhavaḥ ti
translated: “Mendicants!”

original: “Bhadante”ti te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
analyzed: bhadanta iti te bhikkhū bhagavataḥ
translated: “Venerable sir,” they replied.

original: Bhagavā etadavoca:
analyzed: bhagavān etat avoca
translated: The Buddha said this:

original: “Chahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṁ puññakkhettaṁ lokassa.
analyzed: chahi bhikkhave dhammehi samannāgataḥ bhikkhu āhuneyyaḥ hoti pāhuneyyaḥ dakkhiṇeyyaḥ añjali karaṇīyaḥ anuttaram puññakkhettam lokassa
translated: “Mendicants, a mendicant with six qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

original: Katamehi chahi?
analyzed: katamehi chahi
translated: What six?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpam disvā na iva sumanaḥ hoti na dummanaḥ upekkhakaḥ viharati sataḥ sampajāno
translated: It’s when a mendicant, seeing a form with the eye, doesn’t feel joyful or sad, but stays equanimous, mindful and aware.

original: Sotena saddaṁ sutvā …🔽ghānena gandhaṁ ghāyitvā …
analyzed: sotena saddam sutvā  ghānena gandham ghāyitvā
translated: Hearing a sound with the ear …🔽Smelling an odor with the nose …

original: jivhāya rasaṁ sāyitvā …
analyzed: jivhāya rasam sāyitvā
translated: Tasting a flavor with the tongue …

original: kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṁ phusitvā …
analyzed: kāyena phoṭṭhabbam phusitvā
translated: Feeling a touch with the body …

original: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
analyzed: manasā dhammam viññāya na iva su manaḥ hoti na dummanaḥ upekkhakaḥ viharati sataḥ sampajāno
translated: When he has consciousness of mind-objects with the mind, he is neither glad nor sad; he abides equanimous, alert, and mindful.

original: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, chahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṁ puññakkhettaṁ lokassā”ti.
analyzed: imehi kho bhikkhave chahi dhammehi samannāgataḥ bhikkhu āhuneyyaḥ hoti pāhuneyyaḥ dakkhiṇeyyaḥ añjali karaṇīyaḥ anuttaram puññakkhettam lokassa ati
translated: A monk endowed with these six qualities is worthy of gifts, worthy of hospitality, worthy of offerings, worthy of reverential salutations, an unsurpassed field of merit for the world.”

original: Idamavoca bhagavā.
analyzed: idam avoca bhagavān
translated: That is what the Blessed One said.

original: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.🔽Paṭhamaṁ.🔽Aṅguttara Nikāya 6.2
analyzed: attamanāḥ te bhikkhū bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinandunti  paṭhama  aṅguttara nikāya
translated: The bhikkhus were satisfied and delighted in the Blessed One’s words.🔽The first section for recitation on the one of discerning virtue is finished.

original: 1. Āhuneyyavagga
analyzed: āhuneyya vagga
translated: The Book of the Sixes

original: Dutiyaāhuneyyasutta
analyzed: dutiya āhuneyya sutta
translated: The Worthy One, Part One

original: “Chahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṁ puññakkhettaṁ lokassa.
analyzed: chahi bhikkhave dhammehi samannāgataḥ bhikkhu āhuneyyaḥ hoti pe anuttaram puññakkhettam lokassa
translated: “Bhikkhus, a bhikkhu endowed with six qualities is worthy of gifts, worthy of hospitality, worthy of offerings, worthy of reverential salutations, an unsurpassed field of merit for the world.

original: Katamehi chahi?🔽Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anekavihitaṁ iddhividhaṁ paccanubhoti—ekopi hutvā bahudhā
analyzed: katamehi chahi  idha bhikkhave bhikkhu aneka vihitam iddhi vidham paccanubhoti ekaḥ api hutvā bahudhā
translated: What six?

original: hoti, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hoti; āvibhāvaṁ tirobhāvaṁ; tirokuṭṭaṁ tiropākāraṁ tiropabbataṁ
analyzed: hoti bahudhā api hutvā ekaḥ hoti āvi bhāvam tirobhāva tirokuṭṭam tiro pākāram tiro pabbata
translated: Here, a bhikkhu wields the various kinds of spiritual power: having been one, he becomes many; having been many, he becomes one; he appears and vanishes; he goes unhindered through a wall, through a rampart, through a mountain as though through space; he dives in and out of the earth as though through water; he goes on unbroken water as though on earth; seated cross-legged he travels through space like a bird; with his hand he touches and strokes even the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful; he exercises mastery with the body as far as the brahma world.

original: asajjamāno gacchati, seyyathāpi ākāse; pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjaṁ karoti, seyyathāpi🔽udake; udakepi abhijjamāne gacchati, seyyathāpi pathaviyaṁ; ākāsepi pallaṅkena kamati,🔽seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo; imepi candimasūriye evaṁmahiddhike evaṁmahānubhāve pāṇinā
analyzed: a sajjamānaḥ gacchati sā iyathā api ākāse pathaviyā api ummujja nimujjam karoti sā iyathā api  udake udake pi abhijjamāne gacchati seyyathā api pathaviye ākāse pi pallaṅkena kamati  seyyathā api pakkhī sakuṇaḥ ime api candima sūriye eva mahiddhike eva mahā anubhāve pāṇinā
translated: without touching the ground, just as a bird does through the air; he dives in and out of the earth as if it were water; he walks on water without sinking as if it were dry land; he travels cross-legged through the air like a bird on the wing; he even touches and strokes with his hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful;

original: parimasati parimajjati; yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṁ vatteti.
analyzed: parimasati parimajjati yāva brahma lokā api kāyena vasam vatta iti
translated: He travels unhindered through walls, through enclosures, through mountains, as if through space. He dives in and out of the earth as if in water. He travels on water without breaking through as if on land. Seated cross-legged he travels through space like a bird. With his hand he touches and strokes even the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful. He wields bodily mastery even as far as the Brahmā world.

original: Dibbāya, sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāti—dibbe ca mānuse ca, ye dūre santike ca.
analyzed: dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkanta mānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāti dibbe ca mānuse ca ye dūre santike ca
translated: With the divine ear element, which is purified and surpasses the human, he hears both kinds of sounds, the divine and the human, those that are far as well as near.

original: Parasattānaṁ parapuggalānaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāti.
analyzed: para sattānam para puggalānam cetasā cetaḥ paricca pajānāti
translated: He understands the minds of other beings, of other persons, having encompassed them with his own mind.

original: Sarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ sarāgaṁ cittanti pajānāti,🔽vītarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ …🔽sadosaṁ vā cittaṁ …🔽vītadosaṁ vā cittaṁ …
analyzed: sa rāgam vā cittam sa rāgam cittam iti pajānāti  vīta rāgam vā cittam  sa dosam vā cittam  vīta dosam vā cittam
translated: He understands a mind with passion as a mind with passion,🔽and a mind without passion as a mind without passion;🔽a mind with hatred as a mind with hatred,🔽and a mind without hatred as a mind without hatred;

original: samohaṁ vā cittaṁ …🔽vītamohaṁ vā cittaṁ …🔽saṅkhittaṁ vā cittaṁ …
analyzed: sa moham vā cittam  vīta moham vā cittam  saṅkhittam vā cittam
translated: a mind with delusion as a mind with delusion,🔽and a mind without delusion as a mind without delusion;🔽a contracted mind as contracted,

original: vikkhittaṁ vā cittaṁ …
analyzed: vikkhittam vā cittam
translated: and a distracted mind as distracted;

original: mahaggataṁ vā cittaṁ …🔽amahaggataṁ vā cittaṁ …🔽sauttaraṁ vā cittaṁ …
analyzed: mahaggatam vā cittam  a mahaggatam vā cittam  sauttaram vā cittam
translated: a heightened mind as heightened,🔽an unheightened mind as unheightened,

original: anuttaraṁ vā cittaṁ …🔽samāhitaṁ vā cittaṁ …🔽asamāhitaṁ vā cittaṁ …
analyzed: anuttaram vā cittam  samāhitam vā cittam  asamāhitam vā cittam
translated: a surpassed mind as surpassed,🔽an unsurpassed mind as unsurpassed,🔽a concentrated mind as concentrated,🔽an unconcentrated mind as unconcentrated,

original: vimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ …
analyzed: vimuttam vā cittam
translated: a liberated mind as liberated,

original: avimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ avimuttaṁ cittanti pajānāti.
analyzed: a vimuttam vā cittam a vimuttam cittam iti pajānāti
translated: and an unliberated mind as unliberated.

original: Anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo …pe…. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.🔽Dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne
analyzed: aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati seyyathidam ekam pi jātim dve pi jātiyaḥ pe iti sa ākāram sa uddesam aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati  dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne
translated: He recollects his manifold past lives, i.e. one birth, two five, ten fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand, many eons of cosmic contraction, many eons of cosmic expansion, many eons of cosmic contraction and expansion, ‘There I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance. Such was my food, such my sensitivity to pleasure and pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose there. There too I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance. Such was my food, such my sensitivity to pleasure and pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose here.’ Thus he recollects his manifold past lives in their modes and details.

original: hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti: ‘ime🔽vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena
analyzed: hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti ime  vata bhonto sattā kāya duccaritena samannāgatāḥ vacī duccaritena samannāgatāḥ manaḥ duccaritena
translated: With the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, he sees beings passing away and re-appearing, inferior and superior, fair and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate, and he understands how beings pass on according to their actions: ‘These worthy beings who were ill-conducted in body, speech, and mind, revilers of noble ones, wrong in their views, giving effect to wrong view, on the dissolution of the body, after death, have reappeared in a state of deprivation, in a bad destination, in perdition, even in hell.

original: samannāgatā ariyānaṁ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa
analyzed: samannāgatāḥ ariyānam upavādakāḥ micchādiṭṭhikāḥ micchādiṭṭhi kamma samādānā te kāyassa
translated: But these worthy beings who were well-conducted in body, speech, and mind, not revilers of noble ones, right in their views, giving effect to right view, on the dissolution of the body, after death, have reappeared in a good destination, even in the heavenly world.’ Thus with the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, he sees beings passing away and re-appearing, inferior and superior, fair and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate, and he understands how beings pass on according to their actions.

original: bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapannā. Ime vā pana bhonto
analyzed: bhedāḥ param maraṇāḥ apāyam duggatim vinipātam nirayam upapannāḥ ime vā pana bhontaḥ
translated: Or these beings, endowed with good bodily conduct,

original: sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā🔽ariyānaṁ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ
analyzed: sattā kāya su caritena samannāgatā vacī su caritena samannāgatā manaḥ su caritena samannāgatā  ariyānaṃ an upavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhi kamma samādānā te kāyassa bhedā para
translated: endowed with good verbal conduct, endowed with good mental conduct,🔽who did not revile noble ones, who held right views and undertook actions under the influence of right views,🔽after breaking up the body, have reappeared in a good destination, a heavenly world.’

original: maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena🔽satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate🔽yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
analyzed: maraṇā sugatim saggam lokam upapannā ati iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena  satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate  yathā kammūpage satte pajānāti
translated: In this way, with his mind well established in the rapture of seclusion, he directs and inclines his mind to the knowledge of the destruction of the taints.🔽He understands as it really is: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering.’ …🔽He understands as it really is: ‘These are the taints’ … ‘This is the origin of the taints’ … ‘This is the cessation of the taints’ … ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of the taints.’

original: Āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: āsavānam khayā anāsavam cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim diṭṭhe iva dhamme sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati
translated: By completely surmounting the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, he enters and dwells in the cessation of perception and feeling.

original: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, chahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṁ puññakkhettaṁ lokassā”ti.
analyzed: imehi kho bhikkhave chahi dhammehi samannāgataḥ bhikkhu āhuneyyaḥ hoti pe anuttaram puññakkhettam lokassa ati
translated: When a bhikkhu possesses these six qualities, he is worthy of gifts, worthy of hospitality, worthy of offerings, worthy of reverential salutation, an unsurpassed field of merit for the world.”

original: Dutiyaṁ.
analyzed: dutiya
translated: The second section on the one worthy of gifts is finished.🔽The section on the one worthy of gifts is finished.

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 6.3🔽1. Āhuneyyavagga🔽Indriyasutta
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya  āhuneyya vagga  indriyasutta
translated: The Numerical Discourses of the Buddha 6.3 🔽1. The Chapter on Those Worthy of Offerings 🔽The Faculties

original: “Chahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṁ puññakkhettaṁ lokassa.
analyzed: chahi bhikkhave dhammehi samannāgataḥ bhikkhu āhuneyyaḥ hoti pe anuttaram puññakkhettam lokassa
translated: Numbered Discourses The Higher Fetters The Sense Faculties “Mendicants, a mendicant with six qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

original: Katamehi chahi?
analyzed: katamehi chahi
translated: What six?

original: Saddhindriyena, vīriyindriyena, satindriyena, samādhindriyena, paññindriyena, āsavānaṁ🔽khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā
analyzed: saddhindriyena vīriyindriyena satindriyena samādhindriyena paññindriyena  khayā anāsavam cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim diṭṭhe iva dhamme sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā
translated: The faculty of faith, the faculty of energy, the faculty of mindfulness, the faculty of concentration, the faculty of wisdom, and the faculty of freedom.

original: upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: upasampajja viharati
translated: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

original: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, chahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṁ puññakkhettaṁ lokassā”ti.🔽Tatiyaṁ.🔽Aṅguttara Nikāya 6.4🔽1. Āhuneyyavagga🔽Balasutta
analyzed: imehi kho bhikkhave chahi dhammehi samannāgataḥ bhikkhu āhuneyyaḥ hoti pāhuneyyaḥ dakkhiṇeyyaḥ añjali karaṇīyaḥ anuttaram puññakkhettam lokassa ati  tatiya  aṅguttara nikāya  āhuneyya vagga  balasutta
translated: A mendicant with these six qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.”🔽The third section for recitation on the higher fetters is finished.

original: “Chahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṁ puññakkhettaṁ lokassa.
analyzed: chahi bhikkhave dhammehi samannāgataḥ bhikkhu āhuneyyaḥ hoti pe anuttaram puññakkhettam lokassa
translated: Numbered Discourses The Higher Fetters The Sense Faculties “Mendicants, a mendicant with six qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

original: Katamehi chahi?
analyzed: katamehi chahi
translated: What six?

original: Saddhābalena, vīriyabalena, satibalena, samādhibalena, paññābalena, āsavānaṁ khayā
analyzed: saddhā balena vīriya balena sati balena samādhi balena paññā balena āsavānam khayā
translated: with the strength of faith, the strength of energy, the strength of mindfulness, the strength of concentration, the strength of wisdom, and with the destruction of the taints,

original: anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.🔽Imehi kho, bhikkhave, chahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṁ puññakkhettaṁ lokassā”ti.🔽Catutthaṁ.
analyzed: anāsavam cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim diṭṭhe iva dhamme sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati  imehi kho bhikkhave chahi dhammehi samannāgataḥ bhikkhu āhuneyyaḥ hoti pe anuttaram puññakkhettam lokassa ati  catuttha
translated: he dwells having known and made them manifest for himself right in the here and now through direct knowledge.

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 6.5🔽1. Āhuneyyavagga
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya  āhuneyya vagga
translated: “A bhikkhu possessing these six qualities is an object of gifts, an object of hospitality, an object of offerings, an object of reverential salutation, an unsurpassed field of merit for the world.”🔽The fourth section on the one possessed of calm is finished.🔽The Book of the Sixes

original: Paṭhamaājānīyasutta
analyzed: paṭhama ājānīya sutta
translated: The Worthy One

original: “Chahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato rañño bhadro assājānīyo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅgantveva saṅkhaṁ gacchati.
analyzed: chahi bhikkhave aṅgehi samannāgataḥ raññaḥ bhadraḥ assa ajānīyaḥ rājā arahaḥ hoti rāja bhoggaḥ raññaḥ aṅga ntvā iva saṅkham gacchati
translated: “Bhikkhus, a prince worthy of a sovereign position, possessing six factors, is a noble steed endowed with speed, a noble steed supreme in speed.

original: Katamehi chahi?
analyzed: katamehi chahi
translated: What six?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño bhadro assājānīyo khamo hoti rūpānaṁ, khamo saddānaṁ, khamo gandhānaṁ, khamo rasānaṁ, khamo phoṭṭhabbānaṁ, vaṇṇasampanno ca hoti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave raññaḥ bhadraḥ assājānīyaḥ khamaḥ hoti rūpāna khamaḥ saddāna khamaḥ gandhāna khamaḥ rasāna khamaḥ phoṭṭhabbāna vaṇṇa sampanno ca hoti
translated: Here, a prince worthy of a sovereign position is one who endures forms, endures sounds, endures odors, endures tastes, endures tactile objects, and is endowed with good color.

original: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, chahi aṅgehi samannāgato rañño bhadro assājānīyo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅgantveva saṅkhaṁ gacchati.
analyzed: imehi kho bhikkhave chahi aṅgehi samannāgataḥ raññaḥ bhadraḥ assa ajānīyaḥ rājā arahaḥ hoti rāja bhoggaḥ raññaḥ aṅgam tvā iva saṅkham gacchati
translated: A fine royal thoroughbred horse with these six factors is worthy of a king, an aristocrat, and is considered a factor of a king.

analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmin nigrodha ārāme

original: Atha kho mahānāmo sakko yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno, kho mahānāmo sakko bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:

translated: Then Mahanama the Sakyan went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,

original: “Yo so, mahānāma, ariyasāvako āgataphalo viññātasāsano, so iminā vihārena bahulaṁ viharati.
analyzed: yaḥ saḥ mahānāma ariyasāvakaḥ āgata phalaḥ viññāta sāsano saḥ iminā vihārena bahulam viharati
translated: “Mahanama, a noble disciple who has attained the fruit and understood the Teaching usually dwells with a mind well established in these four establishments of mindfulness.

original: Idha, mahānāma, ariyasāvako tathāgataṁ anussarati:
analyzed: idha mahānāma ariya sāvako tathāgatam anussarati
translated: “Here, Mahanama, a noble disciple recollects the Tathagata thus:

original: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā’ti.
analyzed: iti pi saḥ bhagavā araham sammāsambuddhaḥ vijjā caraṇa sampanno sugataḥ loka vidū anuttaraḥ purisa damma sārathi satthā deva manussānam buddhaḥ bhagavā ati
translated: ‘The Blessed One is an arahant, perfectly enlightened, accomplished in true knowledge and conduct, fortunate, knower of the world, unsurpassed trainer of persons to be tamed, teacher of gods and humans, the Enlightened One, the Blessed One.’

original: Yasmiṁ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako tathāgataṁ anussarati nevassa tasmiṁ samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṁ cittaṁ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṁ cittaṁ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṁ cittaṁ hoti;
analyzed: yasmi mahānāma samaye ariya sāvakaḥ tathāgatam anussarati na iva assa tasmin samaye rāga pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti na dosa pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti na moha pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti
translated: When a noble disciple recollects the Tathagata, on that occasion his mind is not obsessed by lust, hatred, or delusion;

original: ujugatamevassa tasmiṁ samaye cittaṁ hoti tathāgataṁ ārabbha.🔽Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṁ, labhati dhammavedaṁ, labhati dhammūpasaṁhitaṁ pāmojjaṁ.
analyzed: uju gatam eva assa tasmin samaye cittam hoti tathāgatam ārabbha  ujugatacittaḥ kho pana mahā nāma ariya sāvakaḥ labhati attha veda labhati dhamma veda labhati dhamma upasahitam pāmojja
translated: on that occasion his mind is simply straight.🔽When the mind is straight, the noble disciple gains a sense of urgency about unarisen unwholesome states …

original: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vediyati, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.🔽Ayaṁ vuccati, mahānāma:
analyzed: pamuditassa pīti jāyati pīti manassa kāyo passambhati passaddha kāyo sukham vediyati sukhinaḥ cittam samādhiyati  ayam vuccati mahānāma
translated: He becomes sensitive to the possibility of attaining the unattained, and he achieves the unachieved.

original: ‘ariyasāvako visamagatāya pajāya samappatto viharati, sabyāpajjāya pajāya abyāpajjo viharati, dhammasotaṁ samāpanno buddhānussatiṁ bhāveti’.
analyzed: ariya sāvakaḥ visama gatāya pajāya samappattaḥ viharati sa byāpajjāya pajāya a byāpajjaḥ viharati dhamma sotam samāpannaḥ buddha anussatim bhāveti
translated: This is called a noble disciple who has entered the stream, who has crossed the flood, who has cut off uncertainty, who has no more return to this world.”

original: Puna caparaṁ, mahānāma, ariyasāvako dhammaṁ anussarati:
analyzed: puna capara mahānāma ariya sāvakaḥ dhammaṃ anussarati
translated: “Again, Mahanama, a noble disciple recollects the Dhamma:

original: ‘svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṁ veditabbo viññūhī’ti.
analyzed: su ākkhātaḥ bhagavatā dhammaḥ sandiṭṭhikaḥ akālikaḥ ehipassikaḥ opaneyyikaḥ paccattam veditabbaḥ viññūhi iti
translated: ‘The Dhamma is well-expounded by the Lord, to be seen here and now, timeless, inviting inspection, onward-leading, and to be experienced by the wise for themselves.’

original: Yasmiṁ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako dhammaṁ anussarati nevassa tasmiṁ samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṁ cittaṁ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṁ cittaṁ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṁ cittaṁ hoti;
analyzed: yasmi mahānāma samaye ariya sāvakaḥ dhammaṃ anussarati na iva assa tasmin samaye rāga pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti na dosa pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti na moha pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti
translated: “Mahanama, when a noble disciple recollects the Dhamma, on that occasion his mind is not obsessed by lust, hatred, or delusion;

original: ujugatamevassa tasmiṁ samaye cittaṁ hoti dhammaṁ ārabbha.🔽Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṁ, labhati dhammavedaṁ, labhati dhammūpasaṁhitaṁ pāmojjaṁ.
analyzed: uju gatam eva assa tasmin samaye cittam hoti dhammam ārabbha  ujugatacittaḥ kho pana mahā nāma ariya sāvakaḥ labhati attha veda labhati dhamma veda labhati dhamma upasahitam pāmojja
translated: on that occasion his mind is simply straight.🔽When the mind is straight, the noble disciple gains a sense of urgency about unarisen unwholesome states not arising …

original: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vediyati, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.
analyzed: pamuditassa pīti jāyati pīti manassa kāyo passambhati passaddha kāyo sukham vediyati sukhinaḥ cittam samādhiyati
translated: and he gains rapture and joy.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, mahānāma:
analyzed: ayam vuccati mahānāma
translated: This, Mahanama, is called right mindfulness.

original: ‘ariyasāvako visamagatāya pajāya samappatto viharati, sabyāpajjāya pajāya abyāpajjo viharati, dhammasotaṁ samāpanno dhammānussatiṁ bhāveti’.🔽Puna caparaṁ, mahānāma, ariyasāvako saṅghaṁ anussarati:🔽‘suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, ujuppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, ñāyappaṭipanno
analyzed: ariya sāvakaḥ visama gatāya pajāya samappattaḥ viharati sa byāpajjāya pajāya a byāpajjaḥ viharati dhamma sotam samāpannaḥ dhamma anussatim bhāveti  puna capara mahā nāma ariya sāvakaḥ saṅgham anussarati  suppaṭipannaḥ bhagavataḥ sāvaka saṅghaḥ uju ppaṭipannaḥ bhagavataḥ sāvaka saṅghaḥ ñāya ppaṭipannaḥ
translated: has drawn near to the Deathless,🔽and that is: the Community of Noble Disciples.

original: bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, sāmīcippaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, yadidaṁ cattāri
analyzed: bhagavato sāvaka saṅgho sāmīcippaṭipannaḥ bhagavato sāvaka saṅghaḥ yat idam cattāri
translated: The Community of Noble Disciples consists of four pairs of persons,

original: purisayugāni aṭṭha purisapuggalā esa bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo
analyzed: purisa yugāni aṭṭha purisa puggalā esa bhagavato sāvaka saṅghaḥ āhuneyyaḥ pāhuneyyaḥ dakkhiṇeyyaḥ
translated: eight individuals. This Community of Noble Disciples is worthy of offerings, of hospitality, of gifts, and of reverential salutation.

original: añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṁ puññakkhettaṁ lokassā’ti.
analyzed: añjali karaṇīyaḥ anuttaram puñña kkhettam lokassa ati
translated: It is a field of merit for the world.

original: Yasmiṁ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako saṅghaṁ anussarati nevassa tasmiṁ samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṁ cittaṁ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṁ cittaṁ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṁ cittaṁ hoti;
analyzed: yasmi mahānāma samaye ariya sāvakaḥ saṅgham anussarati na iva assa tasmin samaye rāga pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti na dosa pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti na moha pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti
translated: At such a time, Mahanama, the disciple’s mind is not obsessed by lust, hatred or delusion.

original: ujugatamevassa tasmiṁ samaye cittaṁ hoti saṅghaṁ ārabbha.
analyzed: uju gatam eva assa tasmin samaye cittam hoti saṅgham ārabbha
translated: On that occasion his mind is straight in regard to the Sangha.🔽A noble disciple whose mind is straight in regard to the Sangha has conviction in regard to the Dhamma.🔽When he is convinced, he places faith in the Dhamma.

original: Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṁ, labhati dhammavedaṁ, labhati dhammūpasaṁhitaṁ pāmojjaṁ.
analyzed: ujugatacittaḥ kho pana mahā nāma ariya sāvakaḥ labhati attha veda labhati dhamma veda labhati dhamma upasahitam pāmojja
translated: This is called a noble disciple who has arrived at the view that is in accordance with the Dhamma, who has won the confidence that is in accordance with the Dhamma.

original: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vediyati, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.🔽Ayaṁ vuccati, mahānāma:🔽‘ariyasāvako visamagatāya pajāya samappatto viharati, sabyāpajjāya pajāya abyāpajjo viharati, dhammasotaṁ samāpanno saṅghānussatiṁ bhāveti’.
analyzed: pamuditassa pīti jāyati pīti manassa kāyo passambhati passaddha kāyo sukham vediyati sukhinaḥ cittam samādhiyati  ayam vuccati mahānāma  ariya sāvakaḥ visama gatāya pajāya samappattaḥ viharati sa byāpajjāya pajāya a byāpajjaḥ viharati dhamma sotam samāpanno saṅgha anussatim bhāveti
translated: He is incapable of doing any deed by reason of which he might be tortured with remorse, nor is he capable of passing away without having realized the fruit of stream-entry.

original: Puna caparaṁ, mahānāma, ariyasāvako attano sīlāni anussarati akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni akammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhisaṁvattanikāni.
analyzed: puna capara mahānāma ariya sāvakaḥ attanaḥ sīlāni anussarati akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni a sabalāni a kammāsāni bhujissāni viññu pasatthāni a parāmaṭṭhāni samādhi savattanikāni
translated: “Again, a noble disciple recollects his own virtues: ‘I am endowed with the virtue of refraining from killing living beings, I have abandoned the killing of living beings; I am endowed with the virtue of refraining from taking what is not given, I have abandoned taking what is not given; I am endowed with the virtue of refraining from sexual misconduct, I have abandoned sexual misconduct; I am endowed with the virtue of refraining from false speech, I have abandoned false speech; I am endowed with the virtue of refraining from liquor, wine, and intoxicants, the basis for heedlessness, I have abandoned liquor, wine, and intoxicants.

original: Yasmiṁ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako sīlaṁ anussarati nevassa tasmiṁ samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṁ cittaṁ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṁ cittaṁ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṁ cittaṁ hoti;
analyzed: yasmi mahānāma samaye ariya sāvakaḥ sīlam anussarati na iva assa tasmin samaye rāga pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti na dosa pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti na moha pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti
translated: When a noble disciple recollects his virtue, on that occasion his mind is not obsessed by lust, hatred, or delusion;

original: ujugatamevassa tasmiṁ samaye cittaṁ hoti sīlaṁ ārabbha.
analyzed: uju gatam eva assa tasmin samaye cittam hoti sīlam ārabbha
translated: on that occasion his mind is simply straight, based on virtue.

original: Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṁ, labhati dhammavedaṁ, labhati dhammūpasaṁhitaṁ pāmojjaṁ.
analyzed: ujugatacittaḥ kho pana mahā nāma ariya sāvakaḥ labhati attha veda labhati dhamma veda labhati dhamma upasahitam pāmojja
translated: When the mind is straight, Mahānāma, a noble disciple obtains conviction in the Dhamma; he obtains consolation in the Dhamma.

original: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vediyati, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.🔽Ayaṁ vuccati, mahānāma:
analyzed: pamuditassa pīti jāyati pīti manassa kāyo passambhati passaddha kāyo sukham vediyati sukhinaḥ cittam samādhiyati  ayam vuccati mahānāma
translated: When he is thus convinced and consoled, rapture arises in him. When the mind is uplifted by rapture, the body becomes tranquil. One tranquil in body experiences happiness. The mind of one who is happy becomes concentrated.

original: ‘ariyasāvako visamagatāya pajāya samappatto viharati, sabyāpajjāya pajāya abyāpajjo viharati, dhammasotaṁ samāpanno sīlānussatiṁ bhāveti’.
analyzed: ariya sāvakaḥ visama gatāya pajāya samappattaḥ viharati sa byāpajjāya pajāya a byāpajjaḥ viharati dhamma sotam samāpanno sīla anussatim bhāveti
translated: This, Mahānāma, is called a noble disciple who dwells in balance amid an unbalanced population, who dwells unafflicted amid an afflicted population.

original: Puna caparaṁ, mahānāma, ariyasāvako attano cāgaṁ anussarati:
analyzed: puna capara mahānāma ariya sāvakaḥ attano cāgam anussarati
translated: Again, Mahānāma, a noble disciple recollects his own generosity thus:

original: ‘lābhā vata me, suladdhaṁ vata me.
analyzed: lābhāḥ vata me su laddham vata me
translated: ‘How fortunate I am! How very fortunate I am!

original: Yohaṁ maccheramalapariyuṭṭhitāya pajāya vigatamalamaccherena cetasā agāraṁ ajjhāvasāmi muttacāgo payatapāṇi vosaggarato yācayogo dānasaṁvibhāgarato’ti.
analyzed: yaḥ aham macchera mala pariyuṭṭhitāya pajāya vigata mala maccherena cetasā agāram ajjhāvasāmi mutta cāgaḥ payata pāṇi vosagga rataḥ yāca yogaḥ dāna savibhāga rataḥ iti
translated: In a generation obsessed by the stain of selfishness, I live unstained by selfishness, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give & share.’

original: Yasmiṁ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako cāgaṁ anussarati nevassa tasmiṁ samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṁ cittaṁ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṁ cittaṁ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṁ cittaṁ hoti;
analyzed: yasmi mahānāma samaye ariya sāvakaḥ cāgam anussarati na iva assa tasmin samaye rāga pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti na dosa pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti na moha pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti
translated: “Whenever a noble disciple recollects his own generosity, on that occasion his mind is not obsessed by lust, hatred, or delusion;

original: ujugatamevassa tasmiṁ samaye cittaṁ hoti cāgaṁ ārabbha.🔽Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṁ, labhati dhammavedaṁ, labhati dhammūpasaṁhitaṁ pāmojjaṁ.
analyzed: uju gatam eva assa tasmin samaye cittam hoti cāgam ārabbha  ujugatacittaḥ kho pana mahā nāma ariya sāvakaḥ labhati attha veda labhati dhamma veda labhati dhamma upasahitam pāmojja
translated: on that occasion his mind is simply straight. When one’s mind is straight, the Dhamma appears.

original: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vediyati, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.
analyzed: pamuditassa pīti jāyati pīti manassa kāyo passambhati passaddha kāyo sukham vediyati sukhinaḥ cittam samādhiyati
translated: When the Dhamma appears, joy arises. When one is joyful, rapture arises. When the mind is uplifted, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, one feels pleasure. And when one is pleased, the mind becomes concentrated.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, mahānāma:
analyzed: ayam vuccati mahānāma
translated: “This, Prince, is called the development of concentration that, when developed & pursued, is of great fruit, great benefit.”

original: ‘ariyasāvako visamagatāya pajāya samappatto viharati, sabyāpajjāya pajāya abyāpajjo viharati, dhammasotaṁ samāpanno cāgānussatiṁ bhāveti’.
analyzed: ariya sāvakaḥ visama gatāya pajāya samappattaḥ viharati sa byāpajjāya pajāya a byāpajjaḥ viharati dhamma sotam samāpanno cāga anussatim bhāveti
translated: and he lives in such a way that he will not be subject to decline.’

original: Puna caparaṁ, mahānāma, ariyasāvako devatānussatiṁ bhāveti:
analyzed: puna capara mahānāma ariya sāvakaḥ devatā anussatim bhāveti
translated: ‘Again, a noble disciple recollects the gods:

original: ‘santi devā cātumahārājikā, santi devā tāvatiṁsā, santi devā yāmā, santi devā tusitā,🔽santi devā nimmānaratino, santi devā paranimmitavasavattino, santi devā brahmakāyikā,
analyzed: santi devā cātumahārājikā santi devā santi devā santi devā  santi devā nimmāna ratinaḥ santi devā paranimmitavasavattinaḥ santi devā brahmakāyikā
translated: ‘There are the gods of the heaven of the Four Great Kings,

original: santi devā tatuttari.🔽Yathārūpāya saddhāya samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tattha upapannā, mayhampi tathārūpā saddhā saṁvijjati.
analyzed: santi devā tatuttari  yathārūpāya saddhāya samannāgatā tāḥ devatāḥ itas cutā tattha upapannā mayham pi tathārūpā saddhā savijjati
translated: the gods of the heaven of the Thirty-three, the Yama gods, the gods of the Delightful, the gods who delight in creation, the gods who control what is created by others, and the gods of the Brahma world.🔽These gods arise from a still higher level of noble virtue, noble concentration, and noble wisdom.

original: Yathārūpena sīlena samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tattha upapannā, mayhampi tathārūpaṁ sīlaṁ saṁvijjati.
analyzed: yathārūpena sīlena samannāgatā tāḥ devatāḥ itas cutā tattha upapannā mayham pi tathārūpam sīlam savijjati
translated: I, too, have such virtue, such concentration, and such wisdom.🔽I, too, will be reborn in such a world.’

original: Yathārūpena sutena samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tattha upapannā, mayhampi tathārūpaṁ sutaṁ saṁvijjati.🔽Yathārūpena cāgena samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tattha upapannā, mayhampi tathārūpo cāgo saṁvijjati.
analyzed: yathārūpena sutena samannāgatā tāḥ devatāḥ itas cutā tattha upapannā mayham pi tathārūpam sutam savijjati  yathārūpena cāgena samannāgatā tāḥ devatāḥ itas cutā tattha upapannā mayham pi tathārūpaḥ cāgo savijjati
translated: I have heard the same teachings, I have the same generosity,

original: Yathārūpāya paññāya samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tattha upapannā, mayhampi tathārūpā paññā saṁvijjatī’ti.🔽Yasmiṁ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako attano ca tāsañca devatānaṁ saddhañca sīlañca
analyzed: yathārūpāya paññāya samannāgatā tāḥ devatāḥ itas cutā tattha upapannā mayham pi tathārūpā paññā savijjati iti  yasmi mahānāma samaye ariya sāvakaḥ ca tāsam ca devatānam saddham ca sīlam ca
translated: I have the same wisdom as those deities who have passed away here and been reborn there.

original: sutañca cāgañca paññañca anussarati nevassa tasmiṁ samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṁ cittaṁ🔽hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṁ cittaṁ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṁ cittaṁ hoti;
analyzed: sutam ca cāgam ca paññam ca anussarati na iva assa tasmin samaye rāga pariyuṭṭhitam citta  hoti na dosa pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti na moha pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti
translated: ’ On that occasion, Mahanama, the heart of the ariyan disciple is unafflicted, undefiled, and free from enmity, hatred, and malevolence.🔽“When the ariyan disciple recollects his own virtues in this way, his mind becomes placid, joy arises, and the defilements of mind are abandoned.

original: ujugatamevassa tasmiṁ samaye cittaṁ hoti tā devatā ārabbha.
analyzed: uju gatam eva assa tasmin samaye cittam hoti tāḥ devatāḥ ārabbha
translated: This is the way, Mahanama, that leads to the cessation of the defilements of mind.

original: Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṁ, labhati dhammavedaṁ, labhati dhammūpasaṁhitaṁ pāmojjaṁ.
analyzed: ujugatacittaḥ kho pana mahā nāma ariya sāvakaḥ labhati attha veda labhati dhamma veda labhati dhamma upasahitam pāmojja
translated: A noble disciple with a mind that is straight has a sense of what is proper and a sense of what is improper.

original: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vediyati, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.
analyzed: pamuditassa pīti jāyati pīti manassa kāyo passambhati passaddha kāyo sukham vediyati sukhinaḥ cittam samādhiyati
translated: One who is joyful has rapture. One with a rapt mind has a tranquil body. One with a tranquil body feels bliss. And one who is blissful has concentration.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, mahānāma:
analyzed: ayam vuccati mahānāma
translated: This is called

original: ‘ariyasāvako visamagatāya pajāya samappatto viharati, sabyāpajjāya pajāya abyāpajjo viharati, dhammasotaṁ samāpanno devatānussatiṁ bhāveti’.
analyzed: ariya sāvakaḥ visama gatāya pajāya samappattaḥ viharati sa byāpajjāya pajāya a byāpajjaḥ viharati dhamma sotam samāpannaḥ devatā anussatim bhāveti
translated: a noble disciple who, with the destruction of the five lower fetters, will reappear spontaneously in the Pure Abodes and there attain final Nibbana, without ever returning from that world.

original: Yo so, mahānāma, ariyasāvako āgataphalo viññātasāsano, so iminā vihārena bahulaṁ viharatī”ti.
analyzed: yaḥ saḥ mahānāma ariyasāvakaḥ āgata phalaḥ viññāta sāsano saḥ iminā vihārena bahulam viharati iti
translated: A noble disciple who has attained the fruit and understood the teaching often dwells in this way.”

original: Dasamaṁ.🔽Āhuneyyavaggo paṭhamo.
analyzed: dasama  āhuneyya vaggaḥ paṭhamaḥ
translated: The tenth.

original: Tassuddānaṁ
analyzed: tassa uddāna
translated: The first sub-chapter on those worthy of offerings is finished.🔽The summary:

original: Dve āhuneyyā indriya,
analyzed: dve āhuneyyāḥ indriya
translated: Two worthy of offerings, faculties,

original: balāni tayo ājānīyā;
analyzed: balāni tayoḥ ājānīyā
translated: powers, three thoroughbreds;

original: Anuttariya anussatī,
analyzed: anuttariya anussatī
translated: The unsurpassed recollections,

analyzed: mahānāmena te dasāti  aṅguttara nikāya  sāraṇīya vagga
translated: with Mahanama, ten.🔽The Book of the Tens🔽The Chapter on What is Pleasing and Beneficial

original: Paṭhamasāraṇīyasutta
analyzed: paṭhama sāraṇīya sutta
translated: 1. The First Discrimination

original: “Chayime, bhikkhave, dhammā sāraṇīyā.
analyzed: chayime bhikkhave dhammā sāraṇīyā
translated: “Monks, there are these six endearing qualities.

original: Katame cha?
analyzed: katame cha
translated: What six?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno mettaṁ kāyakammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca, ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo.🔽Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno mettaṁ vacīkammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca, ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhunaḥ mettam kāya kammam paccupaṭṭhitam hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ca iva rahaḥ ca ayam pi dhammo sāraṇīyo  puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhunaḥ mettam vacī kammam paccupaṭṭhitam hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ca iva raho ca ayam pi dhammo sāraṇīyo
translated: Here, a monk has established good will toward his companions in the holy life, both senior and junior, and toward those of middle standing—in their presence as well as in their absence. This endearing quality is endearing to many, endearing to many people.🔽Again, a monk has established good will toward his companions in the holy life, both senior and junior, and toward those of middle standing—in their presence as well as in their absence. This endearing quality is endearing to many, endearing to many people.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno mettaṁ manokammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca, ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo.🔽Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ye te lābhā dhammikā dhammaladdhā antamaso pattapariyāpannamattampi
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhunaḥ mettam manaḥ kammam paccupaṭṭhitam hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ca iva rahaḥ ca ayam pi dhammo sāraṇīyo  puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu ye te lābhā dhammikā dhamma laddhā antamasaḥ patta pariyāpanna mattam pi
translated: Again, a monk has established good will toward his companions in the holy life, both senior and junior, and toward those of middle standing—in their presence as well as in their absence. This endearing quality is endearing to many, endearing to many people.🔽Again, a monk does not consume fresh or cooked food by himself alone, having had it brought from a monastic’s dwelling or from a non-monastic’s dwelling. This endearing quality is endearing to many, endearing to many people.🔽Again, a monk does not consume fresh or cooked food by himself alone, having had it brought from a monastic’s dwelling or from a non-monastic’s dwelling. This endearing quality is endearing to many, endearing to many people.

original: tathārūpehi lābhehi appaṭivibhattabhogī hoti sīlavantehi sabrahmacārīhi sādhāraṇabhogī,🔽ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo.
analyzed: tathārūpehi lābhehi appaṭivibhatta bhogī hoti sīlavantehi sabrahmacārīhi sādhāraṇa bhogī 🔽ayam pi dhammo sāraṇīyo
translated: Again, a monk does not consume fresh or cooked food by himself alone, having had it brought from a monastic’s dwelling or from a non-monastic’s dwelling. This endearing quality is endearing to many, endearing to many people.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yāni tāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu yāni tāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni a sabalāni
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu’s virtues are unbroken, flawless, unblemished, unblotched, freeing, praised by the wise, ungrasped, leading to concentration.

original: akammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhisaṁvattanikāni tathārūpehi
analyzed: a kammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni a parāmaṭṭhāni samādhi savattanikāni tathārūpehi
translated: “And further, the monk dwells both in public and in private possessing in common with his companions in the holy life those virtues that are unbroken, untorn, unblotched, unmottled, liberating, commended by the wise, not misapprehended, and conducive to concentration.

original: sīlehi sīlasāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca, ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo.🔽Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yāyaṁ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa
analyzed: sīlehi sīla sāmañña gataḥ viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ca iva raho ca ayam pi dhammo sāraṇīyo  puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu yā ayam diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa
translated: This is the second thing that is conducive to affection, to respect, to esteem, to tolerance, to inclusion, to non-dispute, to concord, and to unity.

original: sammā dukkhakkhayāya tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhisāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi🔽āvi ceva raho ca, ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo.
analyzed: sammā dukkha kkhayāya tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhi sāmañña gataḥ viharati sabrahmacārīhi  āvi ca iva raho ca ayam pi dhammo sāraṇīyo
translated: “And further, the monk dwells both in public and in private possessing in common with his companions in the holy life that view that is noble and emancipating, and which leads the one who practices in accordance with it to the complete destruction of suffering.🔽This is the third thing that is conducive to affection, to respect, to esteem, to tolerance, to inclusion, to non-dispute, to concord, and to unity.

original: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cha dhammā sāraṇīyā”ti.🔽Paṭhamaṁ.
analyzed: ime kho bhikkhave cha dhammā sāraṇīyā ati  paṭhama
translated: “These are the six things that are conducive to affection, to respect, to esteem, to tolerance, to inclusion, to non-dispute, to concord, and to unity.”🔽The first section for recitation on the things conducive to affection is finished.

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 6.12🔽2. Sāraṇīyavagga
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya  sāraṇīya vagga
translated: The Book of the Sixes

original: Dutiyasāraṇīyasutta
analyzed: dutiya sāraṇīya sutta
translated: The Things Conducive to Affection (Sāraṇīya Sutta)

original: “Chayime, bhikkhave, dhammā sāraṇīyā piyakaraṇā garukaraṇā saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattanti.
analyzed: cha ime bhikkhave dhammā sāraṇīyā piya karaṇā garu karaṇā saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya savattanti
translated: “Monks, these six things are conducive to affection, to respect, to esteem, to tolerance, to inclusion, to non-dispute, to concord, and to unity.

original: Katame cha?
analyzed: katame cha
translated: What six?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno mettaṁ kāyakammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca,
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhunaḥ mettam kāya kammam paccupaṭṭhitam hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ca iva rahaḥ ca
translated: Here, a bhikkhu is friendly and compassionate towards his companions in the holy life, out of esteem for them, and he has a sense of shame.

original: ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.
analyzed: ayam pi dhammo sāraṇīyaḥ piya karaṇaḥ garu karaṇaḥ saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya savattati
translated: This is a quality that creates love and respect, that leads to helpfulness, to non-dispute, to concord, and to unity.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno mettaṁ vacīkammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti …pe….
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhunaḥ mettam vacī kammam paccupaṭṭhitam hoti pe
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu is friendly and compassionate towards his companions in the holy life, out of esteem for them, and he is modest.

original: Mettaṁ manokammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca, ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.
analyzed: mettam mano kammam paccupaṭṭhitam hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ca iva raho ca ayam pi dhammo sāraṇīyaḥ piya karaṇaḥ garu karaṇaḥ saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya savattati
translated: This is a quality that creates love and respect, that leads to helpfulness, to non-dispute, to concord, and to unity.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ye te lābhā dhammikā dhammaladdhā antamaso pattapariyāpannamattampi🔽tathārūpehi lābhehi appaṭivibhattabhogī hoti sīlavantehi sabrahmacārīhi sādhāraṇabhogī,
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu ye te lābhā dhammikā dhamma laddhā antamasaḥ patta pariyāpanna mattam pi 🔽tathārūpehi lābhehi appaṭivibhatta bhogī hoti sīlavantehi sabrahmacārīhi sādhāraṇa bhogī
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu does not share with his companions in the holy life any gains that are in accordance with the Dhamma and righteously obtained, not even as much as a mere bowl of alms.🔽He is not one who enjoys relinquishing, who delights in relinquishing, who is bent on relinquishing, who does not brood over what is past, who does not crave for the future, and who is not tied to the present.

original: ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.
analyzed: ayam pi dhammo sāraṇīyaḥ piya karaṇaḥ garu karaṇaḥ saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya savattati
translated: This quality of being easy to correct is endearing and inspiring, and it leads to being inclusive, to non-dispute, to concord, and to unity.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yāni tāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni🔽akammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhisaṁvattanikāni tathārūpehi
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu yāni tāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni a sabalāni  a kammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni a parāmaṭṭhāni samādhi savattanikāni tathārūpehi
translated: “Again, a monk’s virtues are unbroken, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not misapprehended, and conducive to concentration.

original: sīlehi sīlasāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca, ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo
analyzed: sīlehi sīla sāmañña gataḥ viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ca iva raho ca ayam pi dhammo sāraṇīyo
translated: In line with having virtues that are unbroken … conducive to concentration, he dwells with his fellow monastics in line with the Teaching, both in public and in private.

original: piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.
analyzed: piya karaṇaḥ garu karaṇaḥ saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyai ekībhāvāya savattati
translated: This quality of being easy to correct is endearing and inspiring, and it leads to being inclusive, to non-dispute, to concord, and to unity.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yāyaṁ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu yā ayam diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa
translated: “Again, a monk’s view is noble and liberating, and it leads one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering.

original: sammā dukkhakkhayāya tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhisāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca,
analyzed: sammā dukkha kkhayāya tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhi sāmañña gataḥ viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ca iva raho ca
translated: In line with having a view that is noble and liberating, and it leads one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering, he dwells with his fellow monastics in line with the Teaching, both in public and in private.

original: ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.
analyzed: ayam pi dhammo sāraṇīyaḥ piya karaṇaḥ garu karaṇaḥ saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya savattati
translated: This is a quality that’s heart-warming and endearing, leading to being summoned, to non-disputation, to sameness, to unity.

original: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cha dhammā sāraṇīyā piyakaraṇā garukaraṇā saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattantī”ti.🔽Dutiyaṁ.🔽Aṅguttara Nikāya 6.13
analyzed: ime kho bhikkhave cha dhammā sāraṇīyā piya karaṇā garu karaṇā saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya savattanti iti  dutiya  aṅguttara nikāya
translated: These are the six qualities that are heart-warming and endearing, leading to being summoned, to non-disputation, to sameness, to unity.”🔽The second section on what is heart-warming is finished.

original: 2. Sāraṇīyavagga
analyzed: sāraṇīya vagga
translated: The Book of the Sixes🔽The Chapter on What is Heart-warming

original: Nissāraṇīyasutta
analyzed: nissāraṇīya sutta
translated: What is Heart-wrenching

original: “Chayimā, bhikkhave, nissāraṇīyā dhātuyo.
analyzed: chayimāḥ bhikkhave nissāraṇīyāḥ dhātuyaḥ
translated: “Monks, there are these six heart-wrenching properties.

original: Katamā cha?
analyzed: katamā cha
translated: Which six?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṁ vadeyya:
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu evam vadeyya
translated: There is the case where a monk might say,

original: ‘mettā hi kho me cetovimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā;
analyzed: mettā hi kho me cetaḥ vimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yā anīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā su samāraddhā
translated: ‘Although I’ve developed and cultivated the heart’s release through loving-kindness, made it my vehicle, made it my basis, made it my island, made it my recourse, made it my shelter,

original: atha ca pana me byāpādo cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
analyzed: atha ca pana me byāpādaḥ cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhati iti
translated: still ill will keeps overpowering my mind.’

original: So ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo: ‘māyasmā evaṁ avaca; mā bhagavantaṁ abbhācikkhi, na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṁ, na hi bhagavā evaṁ vadeyya.
analyzed: saḥ mā hevantissa vacanīyaḥ mā ayasmai evam avaca mā bhagavantam abbhācikkhi na hi sādhu bhagavataḥ na hi bhagavā evam vadeyya
translated: He should be told, ‘Don’t say that. You shouldn’t speak in that way. Don’t misrepresent the Blessed One, for it’s not right to misrepresent the Blessed One, and the Blessed One wouldn’t say that.

original: Aṭṭhānametaṁ, āvuso, anavakāso yaṁ mettāya cetovimuttiyā bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya;
analyzed: aṭṭhānam ete āvuso anavakāsaḥ yam mettāya cetovimuttiyāḥ bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya su samāraddhāya
translated: It is impossible, friends, it cannot happen that a bhikkhu who develops and cultivates the liberation of mind by loving-kindness, makes much of it, wields it, makes it his vehicle, makes it his basis, makes it his resort, wields it as his domain,

original: atha ca panassa byāpādo cittaṁ pariyādāya ṭhassati, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: atha ca panassa byāpādaḥ cittam pariyādāya na itam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: that his mind will be obsessed by ill will.

original: Nissaraṇañhetaṁ, āvuso, byāpādassa yadidaṁ mettācetovimuttī’ti.
analyzed: nissaraṇam ha itas āvuso byāpādassa yat idam mettā cetaḥ vimutti iti
translated: For this is the escape from ill will, friends, namely, the liberation of mind by loving-kindness.’

original: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṁ vadeyya:
analyzed: idha pana bhikkhave bhikkhu evam vadeyya
translated: “Here, bhikkhus, someone might say:

original: ‘karuṇā hi kho me cetovimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā;
analyzed: karuṇā hi kho me cetaḥ vimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yā anīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā su samāraddhā
translated: ‘Although I have developed and cultivated the liberation of mind by compassion…

original: atha ca pana me vihesā cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
analyzed: atha ca pana me vihesā cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhati iti
translated: nevertheless my mind is obsessed by cruelty.’🔽He should be told: ‘Do not say so. Do not misrepresent the Blessed One, for it is not right to misrepresent him.

original: So ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo: ‘māyasmā evaṁ avaca; mā bhagavantaṁ abbhācikkhi, na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṁ, na hi bhagavā evaṁ vadeyya.
analyzed: saḥ mā hevantissa vacanīyaḥ mā ayasmai evam avaca mā bhagavantam abbhācikkhi na hi sādhu bhagavataḥ na hi bhagavā evam vadeyya
translated: The Blessed One would never say such a thing.

original: Aṭṭhānametaṁ, āvuso, anavakāso yaṁ karuṇāya cetovimuttiyā bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya;
analyzed: aṭṭhānam ete āvuso anavakāsaḥ yam karuṇāya cetaḥ vimuttiyāḥ bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya su samāraddhāya
translated: It is impossible, friends, it cannot happen that a bhikkhu who develops and cultivates the liberation of mind by compassion, makes much of it, wields it well, and has full mastery over it,

original: atha ca panassa vihesā cittaṁ pariyādāya ṭhassati, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: atha ca panassa vihesā cittam pariyādāya na itam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: that his mind will be obsessed by ill will. That possibility does not exist.

original: Nissaraṇañhetaṁ, āvuso, vihesāya yadidaṁ karuṇācetovimuttī’ti.
analyzed: nissaraṇam ha itas āvuso vihesāya yat idam karuṇā cetaḥ vimutti iti
translated: For this is the escape from ill will, friends: the liberation of mind by compassion.’

original: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṁ vadeyya:
analyzed: idha pana bhikkhave bhikkhu evam vadeyya
translated: “Here, bhikkhus, someone might say:

original: ‘muditā hi kho me cetovimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā;
analyzed: muditā hi kho me cetaḥ vimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yā anīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā su samāraddhā
translated: ‘Although I have developed and cultivated the liberation of mind by altruistic joy, made much of it, wields it well, and have full mastery over it,

original: atha ca pana me arati cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
analyzed: atha ca pana me arati cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhati iti
translated: still my mind is obsessed by worry.’

original: So ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo: ‘māyasmā evaṁ avaca; mā bhagavantaṁ abbhācikkhi, na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṁ, na hi bhagavā evaṁ vadeyya.
analyzed: saḥ mā hevantissa vacanīyaḥ mā ayasmai evam avaca mā bhagavantam abbhācikkhi na hi sādhu bhagavataḥ na hi bhagavā evam vadeyya
translated: He should be told: ‘Do not say so. Do not misrepresent the Blessed One, for it is not right to misrepresent the Blessed One, and the Blessed One would not say so.

original: Aṭṭhānametaṁ, āvuso, anavakāso yaṁ muditāya cetovimuttiyā bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya;🔽atha ca panassa arati cittaṁ pariyādāya ṭhassati, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: aṭṭhānam ete āvuso anavakāsaḥ yam muditāya cetovimuttiyāḥ bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya su samāraddhāya  atha ca panassa arati cittam pariyādāya na itam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: It is impossible, friends, it cannot happen that a bhikkhu who develops and cultivates the liberation of mind by altruistic joy, makes much of it, wields it, makes it his vehicle, handles it, and has full mastery over it,🔽that his mind will be overcome and oppressed by sensual lust.

original: Nissaraṇañhetaṁ, āvuso, aratiyā yadidaṁ muditācetovimuttī’ti.
analyzed: nissaraṇam ha itas āvuso aratiyāḥ yat idam muditā cetaḥ vimuttī iti
translated: For this is the escape from sensual lust, friends, that is to say, the liberation of mind by altruistic joy.’

original: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṁ vadeyya:
analyzed: idha pana bhikkhave bhikkhu evam vadeyya
translated: “Here, bhikkhus, someone might say thus:

original: ‘upekkhā hi kho me cetovimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā;
analyzed: upekkhā hi kho me cetaḥ vimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yā anīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā su samāraddhā
translated: ‘I develop and cultivate the liberation of mind by equanimity, make much of it, wield it, make it my vehicle, handle it, and have full mastery over it;

original: atha ca pana me rāgo cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
analyzed: atha ca pana me rāgaḥ cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhati iti
translated: yet lust still overwhelms and oppresses my mind.’🔽He should be told: ‘Do not say so, friend. Do not misrepresent the Blessed One, for it is not right to misrepresent him.

original: So ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo: ‘māyasmā evaṁ avaca; mā bhagavantaṁ abbhācikkhi, na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṁ, na hi bhagavā evaṁ vadeyya.
analyzed: saḥ mā hevantissa vacanīyaḥ mā ayasmai evam avaca mā bhagavantam abbhācikkhi na hi sādhu bhagavataḥ na hi bhagavā evam vadeyya
translated: The Blessed One would not speak thus.

original: Aṭṭhānametaṁ, āvuso, anavakāso yaṁ upekkhāya cetovimuttiyā bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya;
analyzed: aṭṭhānam ete āvuso anavakāsaḥ yam upekkhāya cetaḥ vimuttiyāḥ bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya su samāraddhāya
translated: It is impossible, friends, it cannot happen that a bhikkhu who develops and cultivates the liberation of mind by equanimity, makes much of it, consolidates it, cultivates it, and undertakes it well,

original: atha ca panassa rāgo cittaṁ pariyādāya ṭhassati, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: atha ca panassa rāgaḥ cittam pariyādāya na itam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: that lust will invade his mind. That possibility does not exist.

original: Nissaraṇañhetaṁ, āvuso, rāgassa yadidaṁ upekkhācetovimuttī’ti.
analyzed: nissaraṇam ha itas āvuso rāgassa yat idam upekkhā cetaḥ vimutti iti
translated: For this is the escape from lust, friends: the liberation of mind by equanimity.’

original: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṁ vadeyya:
analyzed: idha pana bhikkhave bhikkhu evam vadeyya
translated: “Here, bhikkhus, someone might say:

original: ‘animittā hi kho me cetovimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā;
analyzed: animittā hi kho me cetaḥ vimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yā anīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā su samāraddhā
translated: ‘I have developed and cultivated the mind-deliverance of the signless, made it my vehicle, made it my basis, made it my island, made it my refuge, made it my resort.

original: atha ca pana me nimittānusāri viññāṇaṁ hotī’ti.
analyzed: atha ca pana me nimitta anusāri viññāṇam hoti iti
translated: Yet my consciousness still pursues the sign.’

original: So ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo: ‘māyasmā evaṁ avaca; mā bhagavantaṁ abbhācikkhi, na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṁ, na hi bhagavā evaṁ vadeyya.
analyzed: saḥ mā hevantissa vacanīyaḥ mā ayasmai evam avaca mā bhagavantam abbhācikkhi na hi sādhu bhagavataḥ na hi bhagavā evam vadeyya
translated: He should be told: ‘Do not say so. Do not misrepresent the Blessed One, for it is not right to misrepresent the Blessed One, and the Blessed One would not say so.

original: Aṭṭhānametaṁ, āvuso, anavakāso yaṁ animittāya cetovimuttiyā bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya;
analyzed: aṭṭhānam ete āvuso anavakāsaḥ yam animittāya cetovimuttiyāḥ bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya su samāraddhāya
translated: It is impossible, friends, it cannot happen that a bhikkhu who develops and cultivates the signless concentration of mind, making much of it, taking it as a basis, firmly grasping it, and giving thorough attention to it,

original: atha ca panassa nimittānusāri viññāṇaṁ bhavissati, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: atha ca panassa nimitta anusāri viññāṇam bhavissati na itam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: would have consciousness that follows clinging.

original: Nissaraṇañhetaṁ, āvuso, sabbanimittānaṁ yadidaṁ animittācetovimuttī’ti.
analyzed: nissaraṇam ha itas āvuso sabba nimittānam yat idam animittā cetas vimutti iti
translated: For this, friends, is the escape from all signs, that is, the signless concentration of mind.’

original: Idha pana bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṁ vadeyya:
analyzed: idha pana bhikkhave bhikkhu evam vadeyya
translated: “Here, bhikkhus, someone might say thus:

original: ‘asmīti kho me vigataṁ, ayamahamasmīti ca na samanupassāmi;
analyzed: asmi iti kho me vigata ayam aham asmi iti ca na samanupassāmi
translated: ‘Though the conceit “I am” has been abandoned in me, still I see myself as such-and-such.

original: atha ca pana me vicikicchākathaṅkathāsallaṁ cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
analyzed: atha ca pana me vicikicchā kathaṅkathā sallam cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhati iti
translated: Yet the dart of uncertainty and doubt still persists in me.’

original: So ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo: ‘māyasmā evaṁ avaca; mā bhagavantaṁ abbhācikkhi, na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṁ, na hi bhagavā evaṁ vadeyya.
analyzed: saḥ mā hevantissa vacanīyaḥ mā ayasmai evam avaca mā bhagavantam abbhācikkhi na hi sādhu bhagavataḥ na hi bhagavā evam vadeyya
translated: He should be told: ‘Do not say so. Do not misrepresent the Blessed One, for it is not right to misrepresent him. The Blessed One would not speak thus.

original: Aṭṭhānametaṁ, āvuso, anavakāso yaṁ asmīti vigate ayamahamasmīti ca na samanupassato;
analyzed: aṭṭhānam ete āvuso anavakāsaḥ yam asmi iti vigate ayam aham asmi iti ca na samanupassato
translated: It is impossible, friends, it cannot happen that a bhikkhu who has abandoned the conceit “I am” and does not see himself as such-and-such

original: atha ca panassa vicikicchākathaṅkathāsallaṁ cittaṁ pariyādāya ṭhassati, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: atha ca panassa vicikicchā kathaṅkathā sallam cittam pariyādāya na itam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: But it is impossible that his mind will be preoccupied with doubt and uncertainty.

original: Nissaraṇañhetaṁ, āvuso, vicikicchākathaṅkathāsallassa yadidaṁ asmīti mānasamugghāto’ti.
analyzed: nissaraṇam ha itas āvuso vicikicchā kathaṅkathā sallassa yat idam asmi iti mānasa mugghāto ti
translated: Because this is the escape from doubt and uncertainty: the giving up, relinquishing, releasing, and letting go of all things.”

original: Imā kho, bhikkhave, cha nissāraṇīyā dhātuyo”ti.🔽Tatiyaṁ.
analyzed: imāḥ kho bhikkhave cha nissāraṇīyāḥ dhātuyo ti  tatiya
translated: “These, bhikkhus, are the six properties that should be penetrated.”🔽The third section on the six properties that should be penetrated is finished.

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 6.14🔽2. Sāraṇīyavagga
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya  sāraṇīya vagga
translated: The Book of the Sixes

original: Bhaddakasutta
analyzed: bhaddaka sutta
translated: The Fortunate One

original: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi:
analyzed: tatra kho āyasmā sāriputtaḥ bhikkhū āmantesi
translated: There the Venerable Sāriputta addressed the bhikkhus thus:

original: “āvuso bhikkhave”ti.
analyzed: āvuso bhikkhave ti
translated: “Friends, bhikkhus.”

original: “Āvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosuṁ.
analyzed: āvuso ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa
translated: “Friend,” those bhikkhus replied.

original: Āyasmā sāriputto etadavoca:
analyzed: āyasmā sāriputtaḥ etat avoca
translated: Sāriputta said this:

original: “Tathā tathā, āvuso, bhikkhu vihāraṁ kappeti yathā yathāssa vihāraṁ kappayato na bhaddakaṁ maraṇaṁ hoti, na bhaddikā kālakiriyā.
analyzed: tathā tathā āvuso bhikkhu vihāram kappeti yathā yathā assa vihāram kappayataḥ na bhaddakam maraṇam hoti na bhaddikā kālakiriyā
translated: “Friends, a bhikkhu should conduct himself in such a way that when he dies his death will not be untimely, that his death will be fortunate, not unfortunate.

original: Kathañcāvuso, bhikkhu tathā tathā vihāraṁ kappeti yathā yathāssa vihāraṁ kappayato na bhaddakaṁ maraṇaṁ hoti, na bhaddikā kālakiriyā?
analyzed: katham ca āvuso bhikkhu tathā tathā vihāram kappeti yathā yathā assa vihāram kappayataḥ na bhaddakam maraṇam hoti na bhaddikā kālakiriyā
translated: And how is it that a monk conducts himself in a way that does not lead to a bad destination, to hell?

original: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu kammārāmo hoti kammarato kammārāmataṁ anuyutto, bhassārāmo hoti
analyzed: idha āvuso bhikkhu kamma ārāmaḥ hoti kamma rataḥ kamma ārāma tam anuyuttaḥ bhassa ārāmaḥ hoti
translated: There is the case where a monk delights in work, takes delight in work, rejoices in work.

original: bhassarato bhassārāmataṁ anuyutto, niddārāmo hoti niddārato niddārāmataṁ anuyutto,
analyzed: bhassa rataḥ bhassārāma tam anuyuttaḥ niddā rāmaḥ hoti niddā rataḥ niddārāma tam anuyuttaḥ
translated: He delights in talk, takes delight in talk, rejoices in talk.🔽He delights in sleep, takes delight in sleep, rejoices in sleep.🔽He delights in company, takes delight in company, rejoices in company.

original: saṅgaṇikārāmo hoti saṅgaṇikarato saṅgaṇikārāmataṁ anuyutto, saṁsaggārāmo hoti saṁsaggarato
analyzed: saṅgaṇikā ārāmaḥ hoti saṅgaṇika rataḥ saṅgaṇikā ārāmataḥ anuyuttaḥ sa sagga ārāmaḥ hoti sa sagga rataḥ
translated: He delights in connection, takes delight in connection, rejoices in connection.

original: saṁsaggārāmataṁ anuyutto, papañcārāmo hoti papañcarato papañcārāmataṁ anuyutto.
analyzed: anuyutto papañca ārāmaḥ hoti papañca rataḥ papañca ārāma tam anuyuttaḥ
translated: He delights in proliferation, takes delight in proliferation, rejoices in proliferation.

original: Evaṁ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu tathā tathā vihāraṁ kappeti yathā yathāssa vihāraṁ kappayato na bhaddakaṁ maraṇaṁ hoti, na bhaddikā kālakiriyā.
analyzed: evam kho āvuso bhikkhu tathā tathā vihāram kappeti yathā yathā assa vihāram kappayataḥ na bhaddakam maraṇam hoti na bhaddikā kālakiriyā
translated: This is how a monk conducts himself in a way that does not lead to a bad destination, to hell.

original: Ayaṁ vuccatāvuso:
analyzed: ayam vuccati avuso
translated: This, friends, is called

original: ‘bhikkhu sakkāyābhirato nappajahāsi sakkāyaṁ sammā dukkhassa antakiriyāya’.
analyzed: bhikkhu sakkāya abhirataḥ na ppajahāsi sakkāyam sammā dukkhassa anta kiriyāya
translated: ‘The monk who delights in self is not abandoning self for the complete ending of suffering.’

original: Tathā tathāvuso, bhikkhu vihāraṁ kappeti yathā yathāssa vihāraṁ kappayato bhaddakaṁ maraṇaṁ hoti, bhaddikā kālakiriyā.
analyzed: tathā tathā āvuso bhikkhu vihāram kappeti yathā yathā assa vihāram kappayataḥ bhaddakam maraṇam hoti bhaddikā kālakiriyā
translated: ‘The monk delights in and enjoys conceiving in terms of the five aggregates subject to clinging, and does not abandon his conceivings in regard to them, which would lead to the cessation of conceiving.’

original: Kathañcāvuso, bhikkhu tathā tathā vihāraṁ kappeti yathā yathāssa vihāraṁ kappayato bhaddakaṁ maraṇaṁ hoti, bhaddikā kālakiriyā?🔽Idhāvuso, bhikkhu na kammārāmo hoti na kammarato na kammārāmataṁ anuyutto, na bhassārāmo
analyzed: katham ca āvuso bhikkhu tathā tathā vihāram kappeti yathā yathā assa vihāram kappayataḥ bhaddakam maraṇam hoti bhaddikā kālakiriyā  idha āvuso bhikkhu na kamma ārāmaḥ hoti na kamma rataḥ na kamma ārāma tam anuyuttaḥ na bhassa ārāmaḥ
translated: “And how, friends, does a monk construe his life so that his death will be fortunate and good?🔽How does a monk construe his life so that, when his body dissolves, he will not sink in the sea?

original: hoti na bhassarato na bhassārāmataṁ anuyutto, na niddārāmo hoti na niddārato na niddārāmataṁ🔽anuyutto, na saṅgaṇikārāmo hoti na saṅgaṇikarato na saṅgaṇikārāmataṁ anuyutto, na🔽saṁsaggārāmo hoti na saṁsaggarato na saṁsaggārāmataṁ anuyutto, na papañcārāmo hoti
analyzed: hoti na bhassa rataḥ na bhassārāmataṃ anuyuttaḥ na niddā rāmaḥ hoti na niddā rataḥ na 🔽anuyuttaḥ na saṅgaṇikā ārāmaḥ hoti na saṅgaṇika rataḥ na saṅgaṇikā ārāmataṃ anuyuttaḥ na 🔽sasagga ārāmaḥ hoti na sasagga rataḥ na sasagga ārāmatam anuyuttaḥ na papañca ārāmaḥ hoti
translated: Here, a monk is not devoted to doing, to talking, to sleeping, to indulging in personal associations, to pursuing worldly talk, to pursuing the pursuit of sensual pleasure.🔽He is devoted to destruction, to abandoning, to dispassion, to stilling, to complete understanding, to Nibbana.

original: na papañcarato na papañcārāmataṁ anuyutto.
analyzed: na papañca rataḥ na papañca arāmatam anuyuttaḥ
translated: he does not pursue delight in proliferation or in the enjoyment of proliferation.

original: Evaṁ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu tathā tathā vihāraṁ kappeti yathā yathāssa vihāraṁ kappayato bhaddakaṁ maraṇaṁ hoti, bhaddikā kālakiriyā.
analyzed: evam kho āvuso bhikkhu tathā tathā vihāram kappeti yathā yathā assa vihāram kappayataḥ bhaddakam maraṇam hoti bhaddikā kālakiriyā
translated: It’s in such a way that a monk conducts himself that his death is fortunate, his demise is fortunate.

analyzed: ayam vuccati avuso
translated: This is called

analyzed: bhikkhu nibbāna abhirataḥ pajahāsi sakkāyam sammā dukkhassa anta kiriyāya ati  yaḥ papañca manuyuttaḥ  papañca abhirataḥ mago
translated: a monk who delights in extinguishment and abandons the conceit ‘I am.’🔽The fool who pursues proliferation,

original: Virādhayī so nibbānaṁ,
analyzed: virādhayī saḥ nibbāna
translated: who delights in proliferation,🔽disappoints in regard to extinguishment,

original: yogakkhemaṁ anuttaraṁ.
analyzed: yogakkhemam anuttara
translated: the unsurpassed security from bondage.

analyzed: yaḥ ca papañcam hitvāna  nip pa pañca pade ra taḥ  ārādhayī saḥ nibbāna
translated: But one who, having abandoned proliferation,🔽delights in the state free of proliferation,🔽succeeds in regard to extinguishment,

analyzed: bhikkhu nibbāna abhirataḥ pajahāsi sakkāyam sammā dukkhassa anta kiriyāya ati  yaḥ papañca manuyuttaḥ  papañca abhirataḥ mago

analyzed: nakula pitu sutta
translated: The Lay Follower Nakula’s Father

original: Ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā bhaggesu viharati susumāragire bhesakaḷāvane migadāye.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā bhaggesu viharati susumāra gire bhesakaḷā vane migadāye
translated: One time the Blessed One was staying in the Bhaggas’ country at Sumsumaragira in the Bhesakala Grove, the Deer Park.

original: Tena kho pana samayena nakulapitā gahapati ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena nakula pitā gahapati ābādhikaḥ hoti dukkhitaḥ bāḷha gilānaḥ
translated: Now on that occasion the lay follower Nakula’s father was diseased, in pain, severely ill.

original: Atha kho nakulamātā gahapatānī nakulapitaraṁ gahapatiṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha khalu nakula mātā gahapatānī nakula pitaram gahapatim etat avoca
translated: Then the lay follower Nakula’s mother said to him,

original: “Mā kho tvaṁ, gahapati, sāpekkho kālamakāsi.
analyzed: mā kho tva gahapati sa apekkhaḥ kālam akāsi
translated: “Husband, don’t die full of concern.

original: Dukkhā, gahapati, sāpekkhassa kālakiriyā;
analyzed: dukkhā gahapati sa apekkhassa kālakiriyā
translated: It’s painful to die full of concern,

original: garahitā ca bhagavatā sāpekkhassa kālakiriyā.
analyzed: garahitā ca bhagavatā sa apekkhassa kālakiriyā
translated: and the Blessed One has criticized dying full of concern.

original: Siyā kho pana te, gahapati, evamassa:
analyzed: siyā kho pana te gahapati evam assa
translated: “Husband, it may be that you think:

original: ‘na nakulamātā gahapatānī mamaccayena sakkhissati dārake posetuṁ, gharāvāsaṁ santharitun’ti.
analyzed: na nakula mātā gahapatānī mamaccayena sakkhissati dārake posetu gharāvāsam santharitunti
translated: ‘After I’m gone, Nakula’s mother won’t be able to take care of the children or manage the work of the household.’

original: Na kho panetaṁ, gahapati, evaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ.
analyzed: na kho pana ita gahapati evam daṭṭhabba
translated: But you shouldn’t see it that way.

original: Kusalāhaṁ, gahapati, kappāsaṁ kantituṁ veṇiṁ olikhituṁ.
analyzed: kusalā aha gahapati kappāsam kantitum veṇim olikhitu
translated: I’m skilled at spinning and weaving.

original: Sakkomahaṁ, gahapati, tavaccayena dārake posetuṁ, gharāvāsaṁ santharituṁ.
analyzed: sakkomaha gahapati tavaccayena dārake posetu gharāvāsam santharitu
translated: I can support your children and maintain the household.

original: Tasmātiha tvaṁ, gahapati, mā sāpekkho kālamakāsi.
analyzed: tasmā atiha tva gahapati mā sa apekkhaḥ kālam akāsi
translated: So, householder, don’t die full of longing.

original: Dukkhā, gahapati, sāpekkhassa kālakiriyā;
analyzed: dukkhā gahapati sa apekkhassa kālakiriyā
translated: It’s painful to die full of longing,

original: garahitā ca bhagavatā sāpekkhassa kālakiriyā.
analyzed: garahitā ca bhagavatā sa apekkhassa kālakiriyā
translated: and it’s blamed by the Buddha.

original: Siyā kho pana te, gahapati, evamassa:

translated: Householder, you may think:

analyzed: nakula mātā gahapatānī mamaccayena aññam gharam gamissati iti
translated: ‘After my death, Nakula’s mother will take another husband.’

original: Na kho panetaṁ, gahapati, evaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ.
analyzed: na kho pana ita gahapati evam daṭṭhabba
translated: But you shouldn’t see it like this.

original: Tvañceva kho, gahapati, jānāsi ahañca, yaṁ no soḷasavassāni gahaṭṭhakaṁ brahmacariyaṁ samāciṇṇaṁ.
analyzed: tvam ca iva kho gahapati jānāsi aham ca yam naḥ soḷasa vassāni gahaṭṭhakam brahmacariyam
translated: You and I know that we’ve practiced the spiritual life for sixteen years.

original: Tasmātiha tvaṁ, gahapati, mā sāpekkho kālamakāsi.
analyzed: tasmā atiha tva gahapati mā sa apekkhaḥ kālam akāsi
translated: So, householder, don’t die full of longing.

original: Dukkhā, gahapati, sāpekkhassa kālakiriyā;

translated: It’s painful to die full of longing,

original: garahitā ca bhagavatā sāpekkhassa kālakiriyā.

translated: and it’s blamed by the Buddha.

original: Siyā kho pana te, gahapati, evamassa:

translated: ‘After my death, Nakula’s mother will not want to see the Buddha or the community of monks.’

original: Na kho panetaṁ, gahapati, evaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ.
analyzed: na kho pana ita gahapati evam daṭṭhabba
translated: But you should not see it like that.

original: Ahañhi, gahapati, tavaccayena dassanakāmatarā ceva bhavissāmi bhagavato, dassanakāmatarā ca bhikkhusaṅghassa.
analyzed: aham hi gahapati tavaccayena dassana kāmatarā ca iva bhavissāmi bhagavataḥ dassana kāmatarā ca bhikkhu saṅghassa
translated: After your death, I will want to see the Buddha and the community of monks even more.

original: Tasmātiha tvaṁ, gahapati, mā sāpekkho kālamakāsi.
analyzed: tasmā atiha tva gahapati mā sa apekkhaḥ kālam akāsi
translated: So don’t die full of anxiety.

original: Dukkhā, gahapati, sāpekkhassa kālakiriyā;
analyzed: dukkhā gahapati sa apekkhassa kālakiriyā
translated: It’s painful to die full of anxiety,

analyzed: na nakula mātā gahapatānī mamaccayena sīlesu paripūra kārinī iti
