original: Tassa yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ cetasā anuvitakkayato anuvicārayato manasānupekkhato anuttare upadhisaṅkhaye cittaṁ vimuccati.
analyzed: tassa yathāsutam yathā pariyattam dhammam cetasā anuvitakkayataḥ anuvicārayataḥ manasā an upekkhataḥ anuttare upadhi saṅkhaye cittam vimuccati
translated: As he does so, his mind is freed from the corruptions without remainder.

original: Ayaṁ, ānanda, chaṭṭho ānisaṁso kālena atthupaparikkhāya.
analyzed: ayaṃ ānanda chaṭṭho ānisasaḥ kālena attha upaparikkhāya
translated: This is the sixth benefit of listening to the Teaching at the right time and examining the meaning at the right time.

original: Ime kho, ānanda, cha ānisaṁsā kālena dhammassavane kālena atthupaparikkhāyā”ti.
analyzed: ime kho ānanda cha ānisasā kālena dhammassavane kālena attha upaparikkhāya ati
translated: These are the six benefits of listening to the Teaching at the right time and examining the meaning at the right time.”

original: Dutiyaṁ.
analyzed: dutiya
translated: The second section on the right time is finished.

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 6.57🔽6. Mahāvagga
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya  mahāvagga
translated: The Book of the Sixes🔽The Greater Section

original: Chaḷabhijātisutta
analyzed: chaṭ abhijāti sutta
translated: The Six Classes of People

original: Ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate
translated: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha on the Vulture Peak Mountain.

original: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha khalu āyasmai ānandaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ khalu āyasmai ānandaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: Then Venerable Ānanda went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,

original: “pūraṇena, bhante, kassapena chaḷabhijātiyo paññattā—
analyzed: pūraṇena bhante kassapena chaḍ abhijātiyaḥ paññattā
translated: “Sir, Pūraṇa Kassapa describes six kinds of rebirth:

original: kaṇhābhijāti paññattā, nīlābhijāti paññattā, lohitābhijāti paññattā, haliddābhijāti paññattā, sukkābhijāti paññattā, paramasukkābhijāti paññattā.🔽Tatridaṁ, bhante, pūraṇena kassapena kaṇhābhijāti paññattā, orabbhikā sūkarikā sākuṇikā🔽māgavikā luddā macchaghātakā corā coraghātakā bandhanāgārikā ye vā panaññepi keci kurūrakammantā.
analyzed: kaṇhā abhijāti paññattā nīlā abhijāti paññattā lohitābhijāti paññattā haliddā abhijāti paññattā sukkā abhijāti paññattā paramasukkā abhijāti paññattā  tatrida bhante pūraṇena kassapena kaṇhā abhijāti paññattā orabbhikā sūkarikā sākuṇikā  māgavikāḥ luddāḥ maccha ghātakā corā cora ghātakā bandhanāgārikāḥ ye vā pana aññe pi keci kurūra kammantā
translated: the black rebirth, the blue rebirth, the red rebirth, the yellow rebirth, the white rebirth, and the ultimate white rebirth.🔽The black rebirth is for those who kill living creatures, steal, and commit sexual misconduct; who use false speech, divisive speech, harsh speech, and gossip; and who are covetous, malicious, and have wrong view.

original: Tatridaṁ, bhante, pūraṇena kassapena nīlābhijāti paññattā, bhikkhū kaṇṭakavuttikā ye vā panaññepi keci kammavādā kriyavādā.
analyzed: tatrida bhante pūraṇena kassapena nīlābhijāti paññattā bhikkhū kaṇṭakavuttikā ye vā pana aññe pi keci kamma vādā kriya vādā
translated: The blue rebirth is for those who are butchers, slaughterers, pig keepers, chicken keepers, hunters, fishermen, thieves, bandits, or work in slaughterhouses.🔽The red rebirth is for those who are monks who live off bamboo shoots, or for those who follow other paths and other religions.”

original: Tatridaṁ, bhante, pūraṇena kassapena lohitābhijāti paññattā, nigaṇṭhā ekasāṭakā.
analyzed: tatrida bhante pūraṇena kassapena lohitābhijāti paññattā nigaṇṭhā eka sāṭakā
translated: Pūraṇa Kassapa has declared the red-robe sect of the Niganthas to be the red-born class.

original: Tatridaṁ, bhante, pūraṇena kassapena haliddābhijāti paññattā, gihī odātavasanā acelakasāvakā.
analyzed: tatrida bhante pūraṇena kassapena haliddā abhijāti paññattā gihī odāta vasanā acelaka sāvakā
translated: Pūraṇa Kassapa has declared the white-clothed householders who are disciples of the naked ascetics to be the yellow-born class.

original: Tatridaṁ, bhante, pūraṇena kassapena sukkābhijāti paññattā, ājīvakā ājīvakiniyo.
analyzed: tatrida bhante pūraṇena kassapena sukka abhijāti paññattāḥ ājīvakāḥ ājīvakiniyo
translated: Pūraṇa Kassapa has declared the Ājīvaka ascetics and Ājīvaka nuns to be the white-born class.

original: Tatridaṁ, bhante, pūraṇena kassapena paramasukkābhijāti paññattā, nando vaccho kiso saṅkicco makkhali gosālo.
analyzed: tatrida bhante pūraṇena kassapena paramasukkābhijāti paññattā nandaḥ vacchaḥ kisaḥ saṅkiccaḥ makkhali gosālo
translated: Pūraṇa Kassapa has declared Nanda Vaccha, Kisa Saṅkicca, and Makkhali Gosāla to be the most white-born class.

original: Pūraṇena, bhante, kassapena imā chaḷabhijātiyo paññattā”ti.
analyzed: pūraṇena bhante kassapena imāḥ chaḍ abhijātiyaḥ paññattā ati
translated: These are the six classes declared by Pūraṇa Kassapa.”

original: “Kiṁ panānanda, pūraṇassa kassapassa sabbo loko etadabbhanujānāti imā chaḷabhijātiyo paññāpetun”ti?
analyzed: kim pana ānanda pūraṇassa kassapassa sabbaḥ lokaḥ etat abbhanujānāti imāḥ chaḍ abhijātiyaḥ paññāpetunti
translated: “But, Ānanda, does the entire world agree with Pūraṇa Kassapa about these six classes?”

original: “No hetaṁ, bhante.
analyzed: naḥ heta bhante
translated: “No, venerable sir.”

original: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, puriso daliddo assako anāḷhiko, tassa akāmakassa bilaṁ olaggeyyuṁ: ‘idaṁ te, ambho purisa, maṁsañca khāditabbaṁ, mūlañca anuppadātabban’ti.
analyzed: seyyathā api ānanda purisaḥ daliddaḥ assakaḥ a nāḷhikaḥ tassa akāmakassa bilam olaggeyyu idam te ambho purisa masañca khāditabba mūlañca anuppadātabbanti
translated: Suppose a poor, destitute, and lowly man were to be seized by his enemies and they said to him, ‘We will impale you on a stake, we will kill you, we will destroy you.’

original: Evamevaṁ kho, ānanda, pūraṇena kassapena appaṭiññāya etesaṁ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ imā chaḷabhijātiyo paññattā, yathā taṁ bālena abyattena akhettaññunā akusalena.
analyzed: evam evam kho ānanda pūraṇena kassapena appaṭiññāya etesam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam imāḥ chaḍ abhijātiyaḥ paññattāḥ yathā tam bālena abyattena a khettaññunā akusalena
translated: In the same way, Ānanda, Pūraṇa Kassapa, without the consent of those ascetics and brahmins, has proclaimed these six classes of rebirth. He is foolish, inexperienced, and incompetent, and has no teacher.

original: Ahaṁ kho panānanda, chaḷabhijātiyo paññāpemi.
analyzed: aham kho pana ānanda chaḍ abhijātiyaḥ paññāpemi
translated: But, Ānanda, I proclaim the six classes of rebirth.

original: Taṁ suṇāhi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
analyzed: tam suṇāhi sādhukam manasi karohi bhāsissāmi iti
translated: Listen and attend closely to what I shall say.”

original: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.
analyzed: eva bhante iti kho āyasmai ānandaḥ bhagavataḥ paccassosi
translated: “Yes, venerable sir,” Ānanda replied.

original: Bhagavā etadavoca:
analyzed: bhagavān etat avoca
translated: The Blessed One said this:

original: “katamā cānanda, chaḷabhijātiyo?🔽Idhānanda, ekacco kaṇhābhijātiyo samāno kaṇhaṁ dhammaṁ abhijāyati.
analyzed: katamāḥ ca ānanda chaḍ abhijātiyaḥ  idha ānanda ekaccaḥ kaṇha abhijātiyaḥ samāno kaṇham dhammam abhijāyati
translated: “What are the six classes of rebirth?🔽Here someone of a dark class is reborn in a dark class.

original: Idha panānanda, ekacco kaṇhābhijātiyo samāno sukkaṁ dhammaṁ abhijāyati.
analyzed: idha pana ānanda ekaccaḥ kaṇha abhijātiyaḥ samāno sukkam dhammam abhijāyati
translated: Here someone of a dark class is reborn in a bright class.

original: Idha panānanda, ekacco kaṇhābhijātiyo samāno akaṇhaṁ asukkaṁ nibbānaṁ abhijāyati.
analyzed: idha pana ānanda ekaccaḥ kaṇha abhijātiyaḥ samānaḥ a kaṇham a sukkam nibbānam abhijāyati
translated: “Here, Ananda, someone of black nature begets black states.

original: Idha panānanda, ekacco sukkābhijātiyo samāno kaṇhaṁ dhammaṁ abhijāyati.🔽Idha panānanda, ekacco sukkābhijātiyo samāno sukkaṁ dhammaṁ abhijāyati.
analyzed: idha pana ānanda ekaccaḥ sukka abhijātiyaḥ samāno kaṇham dhammam abhijāyati  idha pana ānanda ekaccaḥ sukka abhijātiyaḥ samānaḥ sukkam dhammam abhijāyati
translated: “Here, Ananda, someone of white nature begets black states.🔽“Here, Ananda, someone of white nature begets white states.

original: Idha panānanda, ekacco sukkābhijātiyo samāno akaṇhaṁ asukkaṁ nibbānaṁ abhijāyati.
analyzed: idha pana ānanda ekaccaḥ sukka abhijātiyaḥ samānaḥ a kaṇham a sukkam nibbānam abhijāyati
translated: “Here, Ananda, someone of white nature begets an undarkened, unbrightened state that is beyond the black and the white.

original: Kathañcānanda, kaṇhābhijātiyo samāno kaṇhaṁ dhammaṁ abhijāyati?🔽Idhānanda, ekacco nīce kule paccājāto hoti—caṇḍālakule vā nesādakule vā venakule
analyzed: kathañca ānanda kaṇha abhijātiyaḥ samānaḥ kaṇham dhammam abhijāyati  idha ānandaḥ ekaccaḥ nīce kule paccājātaḥ hoti caṇḍāla kule vā nesāda kule vā vena kule
translated: “And how, Ananda, does someone of black nature beget black states?

original: vā rathakārakule vā pukkusakule vā, dalidde appannapānabhojane kasiravuttike, yattha
analyzed: vā rathakāra kule vā pukkusa kule vā dalidde appanna pāna bhojane kasira vuttike yattha
translated: “Here, Ananda, someone is born in a low family—a family of caṇḍālas, bamboo-workers, hunters, cartwrights, or flower-scavengers—a poor family, of meager food and drink, which subsists with difficulty, where food and clothing are obtained with difficulty;

original: kasirena ghāsacchādo labbhati.
analyzed: kasirena ghāsa chādaḥ labbhati
translated: and where there is no money, silver, or gold.

original: So ca hoti dubbaṇṇo duddasiko okoṭimako bavhābādho kāṇo vā kuṇī vā khañjo vā pakkhahato
analyzed: so ca hoti dubbaṇṇaḥ duddasikaḥ okoṭimakaḥ bavhābādhaḥ kāṇaḥ vā kuṇī vā khañjaḥ vā pakkha hato
translated: And he is ugly, unsightly, and misshapen, sickly, blind, crippled, or paralyzed.

original: vā, na lābhī annassa pānassa vatthassa yānassa mālāgandhavilepanassa seyyāvasathapadīpeyyassa.
analyzed: vā na lābhī annassa pānassa vatthassa yānassa mālā gandha vilepanassa seyyā āvasatha padīpeyyassa
translated: He doesn’t get any food, drink, clothing, vehicles; garlands, fragrances, and makeup; or bed, lodging, and lighting.

original: So kāyena duccaritaṁ carati, vācāya duccaritaṁ carati, manasā duccaritaṁ carati.
analyzed: saḥ kāyena duccaritam carati vācāya duccaritam carati manasā duccaritam carati
translated: He misconducts himself by body, speech, and mind.

original: So kāyena duccaritaṁ caritvā, vācāya duccaritaṁ caritvā, manasā duccaritaṁ caritvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjati.
analyzed: saḥ kāyena duccaritam caritvā vācāya duccaritam caritvā manasā duccaritam caritvā kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā apāyam duggatim vinipātam nirayam upapajjati
translated: Because of misconduct by body, speech, and mind, with the breakup of the body, after death, he is reborn in a lower realm, a bad destination, a state of suffering, hell.

original: Evaṁ kho, ānanda, kaṇhābhijātiyo samāno kaṇhaṁ dhammaṁ abhijāyati.
analyzed: evam kho ānanda kaṇha abhijātiyaḥ samānaḥ kaṇham dhammam abhijāyati
translated: That’s how one of an inherently dark nature becomes one of a dark nature.

original: Kathañcānanda, kaṇhābhijātiyo samāno sukkaṁ dhammaṁ abhijāyati?🔽Idhānanda, ekacco nīce kule paccājāto hoti—caṇḍālakule vā …pe…
analyzed: kathañca ānanda kaṇha abhijātiyaḥ samānaḥ sukkam dhammam abhijāyati  idha ānanda ekaccaḥ nīce kule paccājātaḥ hoti caṇḍāla kule vā pe
translated: “And how does one of an inherently dark nature become one of a bright nature?

original: seyyāvasathapadīpeyyassa.
analyzed: seyya āvasatha padī peyyassa
translated: It’s when someone is born in a low family—a family of outcasts, bamboo-workers, hunters, chariot-makers, or waste-collectors—poor, with little to eat or drink, where life is tough, and food and shelter are hard to find.🔽He gets food, drink, clothing, vehicles; garlands, fragrances, and makeup; and bed, lodging, and lighting.

original: So kāyena sucaritaṁ carati, vācāya sucaritaṁ carati, manasā sucaritaṁ carati.
analyzed: saḥ kāyena su caritam carati vācāya su caritam carati manasā su caritam carati
translated: He conducts himself well by body, speech, and mind.

original: So kāyena sucaritaṁ caritvā, vācāya sucaritaṁ caritvā, manasā sucaritaṁ caritvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjati.
analyzed: saḥ kāyena su caritam caritvā vācāya su caritam caritvā manasā su caritam caritvā kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā sugatim saggam lokam upapajjati
translated: Having done so, with the breakup of the body, after death, he is reborn in a good destination, in a heavenly world.

original: Evaṁ kho, ānanda, kaṇhābhijātiyo samāno sukkaṁ dhammaṁ abhijāyati.
analyzed: evam kho ānanda kaṇha abhijātiyaḥ samānaḥ sukkam dhammam abhijāyati
translated: This is how one of dark nature gives rise to a bright result.

original: Kathañcānanda, kaṇhābhijātiyo samāno akaṇhaṁ asukkaṁ nibbānaṁ abhijāyati?
analyzed: katham ca ānanda kaṇha abhijātiyaḥ samānaḥ a kaṇham a sukkam nibbānam abhijāyati
translated: “And how, Ananda, does one of dark nature give rise to an unblack, unwhite result that leads to the destruction of action?

original: Idhānanda, ekacco nīce kule paccājāto hoti—caṇḍālakule vā …pe…
analyzed: idha ānanda ekaccaḥ nīce kule paccājātaḥ hoti caṇḍāla kule vā pe
translated: Here, Ananda, someone is born into a low family—one of low birth, poor, with little food and drink, where it is hard to make a living, and there is no surplus;

original: so ca hoti dubbaṇṇo duddasiko okoṭimako.
analyzed: saḥ ca hoti dubbaṇṇaḥ duddasikaḥ okoṭimakaḥ
translated: and he is ugly, unsightly, and deformed.

original: So kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.🔽So evaṁ pabbajito samāno pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe,🔽catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacitto, satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṁ bhāvetvā akaṇhaṁ
analyzed: saḥ kesa massum ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasma anagāriyam pabbajati  so evam pabbajitaḥ samāno pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetasaḥ upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe  catūsu sati paṭṭhānesu su patiṭṭhita cittaḥ satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtam bhāvetvā
translated: He shaves off his hair and beard, puts on the yellow robe, and goes forth from the home life into homelessness.

original: asukkaṁ nibbānaṁ abhijāyati.
analyzed: asukkam nibbānam abhijāyati
translated: Having gone forth, he abandons the five lower fetters.🔽With the destruction of the five lower fetters he is reborn spontaneously, to attain final Nibbana there without returning from that world.🔽This is how one of dark nature gives rise to an unblack, unwhite result that leads to the destruction of action.

original: Evaṁ kho, ānanda, kaṇhābhijātiyo samāno akaṇhaṁ asukkaṁ nibbānaṁ abhijāyati.
analyzed: evam kho ānanda kaṇha abhijātiyaḥ samānaḥ a kaṇham a sukkam nibbānam abhijāyati
translated: That’s how one of dark nature becomes one of neither dark nor bright nature in the end.

original: Kathañcānanda, sukkābhijātiyo samāno kaṇhaṁ dhammaṁ abhijāyati?🔽Idhānanda, ekacco ucce kule paccājāto hoti—khattiyamahāsālakule vā brāhmaṇamahāsālakule
analyzed: kathañca ānanda sukka abhijātiyaḥ samāno kaṇham dhammam abhijāyati  idha ānanda ekaccaḥ ucce kule paccājātaḥ hoti khattiya mahāsāla kule vā brāhmaṇa mahāsāla kule
translated: “And how, Ānanda, does one of bright nature become one of dark nature in the end?

original: vā gahapatimahāsālakule vā, aḍḍhe mahaddhane mahābhoge pahūtajātarūparajate pahūtavittūpakaraṇe pahūtadhanadhaññe.
analyzed: vā gahapati mahāsāla kule vā aḍḍhe mahat dhane mahā bhoge pahūta jātarūpa rajate pahūta vittu upakaraṇe pahūta dhana dhaññe
translated: There is the case where a certain person is born into a high family—a noble warrior family, a priestly family, or a well-to-do householder family—one that is rich, of great wealth, of great possessions, with many thousands of millions, with an abundance of money, grain, silver, & gold, with an abundance of livestock & servants.🔽He is well-born on both his mother’s and father’s sides, of pure descent, irrefutable & impeccable with regard to birth going back to the seventh paternal generation.

original: So ca hoti abhirūpo dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato, lābhī annassa pānassa vatthassa yānassa mālāgandhavilepanassa seyyāvasathapadīpeyyassa.
analyzed: so ca hoti abhirūpaḥ dassanīyaḥ pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇa pokkharatāya samannāgataḥ lābhī annassa pānassa vatthassa yānassa mālā gandha vilepanassa seyyā āvasatha padīpeyyassa
translated: He is handsome, attractive, graceful, possessing supreme beauty of complexion, possessing supreme birth & supreme presence. He obtains food, drink, clothing, & vehicles; garlands, scents, & ointments; bedding, shelter, & light.

original: So kāyena duccaritaṁ carati, vācāya duccaritaṁ carati, manasā duccaritaṁ carati.
analyzed: saḥ kāyena duccaritam carati vācāya duccaritam carati manasā duccaritam carati
translated: He engages in misconduct by body, speech, & mind.

original: So kāyena duccaritaṁ caritvā, vācāya duccaritaṁ caritvā, manasā duccaritaṁ caritvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjati.
analyzed: saḥ kāyena duccaritam caritvā vācāya duccaritam caritvā manasā duccaritam caritvā kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā apāyam duggatim vinipātam nirayam upapajjati
translated: After death, he is reborn in a lower realm, a bad realm, a lower world, hell.

original: Evaṁ kho, ānanda, sukkābhijātiyo samāno kaṇhaṁ dhammaṁ abhijāyati.
analyzed: evam kho ānanda sukka abhijātiyaḥ samānaḥ kaṇham dhammam abhijāyati
translated: That’s how one of good heredity comes to have a bad destination.

original: Kathañcānanda, sukkābhijātiyo samāno sukkaṁ dhammaṁ abhijāyati?🔽Idhānanda, ekacco ucce kule paccājāto hoti—khattiyamahāsālakule vā …pe…
analyzed: kathañca ānanda sukka abhijātiyaḥ samānaḥ sukkam dhammam abhijāyati  idha ānanda ekaccaḥ ucce kule paccājātaḥ hoti khattiya mahāsāla kule vā pe
translated: And how does one of good heredity come to have a good destination?

original: seyyāvasathapadīpeyyassa.🔽So kāyena sucaritaṁ carati, vācāya sucaritaṁ carati, manasā sucaritaṁ carati.
analyzed: seyya āvasatha padī peyyassa  saḥ kāyena su caritam carati vācāya su caritam carati manasā su caritam carati
translated: It’s when someone is born into a high family—an affluent khattiya family, an affluent brahmin family, or an affluent householder family—one that is rich, with great wealth and property, with much livestock, money, and grain, with abundant food and provisions, with heaps of silver and gold, and stores of valuables.🔽He has a good complexion, is well-built, inspiring, and attractive, with a noble presence, fair skin, a fine head of hair, and a clear voice.🔽He practices good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

original: So kāyena sucaritaṁ caritvā, vācāya sucaritaṁ caritvā, manasā sucaritaṁ caritvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjati.
analyzed: saḥ kāyena su caritam caritvā vācāya su caritam caritvā manasā su caritam caritvā kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā sugatim saggam lokam upapajjati
translated: After death, he is reborn in a good place, a heavenly world.

original: Evaṁ kho, ānanda, sukkābhijātiyo samāno sukkaṁ dhammaṁ abhijāyati.
analyzed: evam kho ānanda sukka abhijātiyaḥ samānaḥ sukkam dhammam abhijāyati
translated: That’s how one of good heredity comes to have a good destination.

original: Kathañcānanda, sukkābhijātiyo samāno akaṇhaṁ asukkaṁ nibbānaṁ abhijāyati?🔽Idhānanda, ekacco ucce kule paccājāto hoti—khattiyamahāsālakule vā brāhmaṇamahāsālakule
analyzed: katham ca ānanda sukka abhijātiyaḥ samānaḥ a kaṇham a sukkam nibbānam abhijāyati  idha ānanda ekaccaḥ ucce kule paccājātaḥ hoti khattiya mahāsāla kule vā brāhmaṇa mahāsāla kule
translated: “And how does one of fair complexion become one of neither-black-nor-white complexion?

original: vā gahapatimahāsālakule vā, aḍḍhe mahaddhane mahābhoge pahūtajātarūparajate pahūtavittūpakaraṇe pahūtadhanadhaññe.
analyzed: vā gahapati mahāsāla kule vā aḍḍhe mahat dhane mahā bhoge pahūta jātarūpa rajate pahūta vittu upakaraṇe pahūta dhana dhaññe
translated: “There is the case where a certain person is born into a high family—a noble warrior family, a priestly family, or a well-to-do householder family—one that is rich, of great wealth & property, with much gold & silver, with many possessions & treasures, with ample money & grain.🔽He is well-born on both his mother’s and father’s sides, of pure descent, unassailable & impeccable with regard to birth going back to the seventh paternal generation.

original: So ca hoti abhirūpo dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato, lābhī annassa pānassa vatthassa yānassa mālāgandhavilepanassa seyyāvasathapadīpeyyassa.
analyzed: so ca hoti abhirūpaḥ dassanīyaḥ pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇa pokkharatāya samannāgataḥ lābhī annassa pānassa vatthassa yānassa mālā gandha vilepanassa seyyā āvasatha padīpeyyassa
translated: He is handsome, graceful, & pleasing, possessing supreme beauty of complexion, with a face like the bright moon, a leader in the matter of looks. He obtains food, drink, clothing, & vehicles; garlands, scents, & unguents; bedding, shelter, & light.

original: So kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
analyzed: saḥ kesa massum ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasma anagāriyam pabbajati
translated: He shaves off his hair & beard, dresses in ocher robes, and goes forth from the home life into homelessness.

original: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe,
analyzed: so evam pabbajitaḥ samāno pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetasaḥ upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
translated: Having gone forth, he abandons the five hindrances—those corruptions of awareness that weaken discernment—

original: catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacitto, satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṁ bhāvetvā akaṇhaṁ
analyzed: catūsu sati paṭṭhānesu su patiṭṭhita cittaḥ satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtam bhāvetvā
translated: with his mind well established in the four ways of attending to mindfulness,

original: asukkaṁ nibbānaṁ abhijāyati.
analyzed: asukkam nibbānam abhijāyati
translated: he attains nibbāna, which has no darkness or light,

original: Evaṁ kho, ānanda, sukkābhijātiyo samāno akaṇhaṁ asukkaṁ nibbānaṁ abhijāyati.
analyzed: evam kho ānanda sukka abhijātiyaḥ samānaḥ a kaṇham a sukkam nibbānam abhijāyati
translated: This is how one of good birth attains nibbāna, which has no darkness or light.

original: Imā kho, ānanda, chaḷabhijātiyo”ti.
analyzed: imāḥ khalu ānanda chaḍ abhijātiyāḥ ti
translated: These are the six kinds of birth.”

original: Tatiyaṁ.🔽Aṅguttara Nikāya 6.58
analyzed: tatiya  aṅguttara nikāya
translated: The third section on birth is finished.🔽The Book of the Sixes

original: 6. Mahāvagga
analyzed: mahāvagga
translated: The Greater Section

original: Āsavasutta
analyzed: āsava sutta
translated: The Corruptions

original: “Chahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṁ puññakkhettaṁ lokassa.
analyzed: chahi bhikkhave dhammehi samannāgataḥ bhikkhu āhuneyyaḥ hoti pāhuneyyaḥ dakkhiṇeyyaḥ añjali karaṇīyaḥ anuttaram puññakkhettam lokassa
translated: “Bhikkhus, a bhikkhu endowed with six qualities is worthy of gifts, worthy of hospitality, worthy of offerings, worthy of reverential salutation, an unsurpassed field of merit for the world.

original: Katamehi chahi?
analyzed: katamehi chahi
translated: What are the six?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ye āsavā saṁvarā pahātabbā te saṁvarena pahīnā honti,🔽ye āsavā paṭisevanā pahātabbā te paṭisevanāya pahīnā honti,🔽ye āsavā adhivāsanā pahātabbā te adhivāsanāya pahīnā honti,
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhuno ye āsavā savarā pahātabbā te savarena pahīnāḥ honti  ye āsavā paṭisevanā pahātabbā te paṭisevanāya pahīnāḥ honti  ye āsavāḥ adhivāsanā pahātabbā te adhivāsanāya pahīnāḥ honti
translated: Here, a bhikkhu has abandoned the corruptions that should be abandoned by restraint,🔽the corruptions that should be abandoned by using,🔽the corruptions that should be abandoned by enduring,

original: ye āsavā parivajjanā pahātabbā te parivajjanāya pahīnā honti,
analyzed: ye āsavā parivajjanā pahātabbā te parivajjanāya pahīnāḥ honti
translated: the corruptions that should be abandoned by avoiding,

original: ye āsavā vinodanā pahātabbā te vinodanāya pahīnā honti,🔽ye āsavā bhāvanā pahātabbā te bhāvanāya pahīnā honti.
analyzed: ye āsavāḥ vinodanā pahātabbā te vinodanāya pahīnāḥ honti  ye āsavāḥ bhāvanā pahātabbā te bhāvanāya pahīnāḥ honti
translated: The taints that are to be abandoned by dispelling are abandoned by dispelling.🔽The taints that are to be abandoned by development are abandoned by development.

original: Katame ca, bhikkhave, āsavā saṁvarā pahātabbā ye saṁvarena pahīnā honti?
analyzed: katame ca bhikkhave āsavā savarā pahātabbā ye savarena pahīnāḥ honti
translated: “And which taints are to be abandoned by restraint?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yoniso cakkhundriyasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati.🔽Yaṁ hissa, bhikkhave, cakkhundriyasaṁvaraṁ asaṁvutassa viharato uppajjeyyuṁ āsavā
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yonisas cakkhu indriya savara savutaḥ viharati  yam hissa bhikkhave cakkhu indriya savaram a savutassa viharataḥ uppajjeyyuṃ āsavā
translated: There is the case where a monk, reflecting appropriately, dwells restrained in the eye faculty.

original: vighātapariḷāhā, cakkhundriyasaṁvaraṁ saṁvutassa viharato evaṁsa te āsavā vighātapariḷāhā na honti.
analyzed: vighāta pariḷāhā cakkhu indriya savaram savutassa viharato te āsavā vighāta pariḷāhāḥ na honti
translated: Those taints that would arise if he were to dwell unrestrained in the eye faculty do not arise for him when he dwells restrained.

original: Paṭisaṅkhā yoniso sotindriya …pe…🔽ghānindriya …
analyzed: paṭisaṅkhā  ghānindriya
translated: Reflecting appropriately, he dwells restrained in the ear faculty…🔽in the nose faculty…

original: jivhindriya …
analyzed: jivhindriya
translated: in the tongue faculty…

original: kāyindriya …
analyzed: kāyindriya
translated: in the body faculty…

original: manindriyasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati.
analyzed: viharati
translated: in the intellect faculty.

original: Yaṁ hissa, bhikkhave, manindriyasaṁvaraṁ asaṁvutassa viharato uppajjeyyuṁ āsavā vighātapariḷāhā, manindriyasaṁvaraṁ saṁvutassa viharato evaṁsa te āsavā vighātapariḷāhā na honti.
analyzed: yam hissa bhikkhave manindriya savaram a savutassa viharato uppajjeyyuṃ āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ manindriya savaram savutassa viharato te āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ na honti
translated: For those effluents, vexation, and fever that would arise if he were to live without restraint over the mind faculty do not arise for him when he practices restraint.

original: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, āsavā saṁvarā pahātabbā ye saṁvarena pahīnā honti.
analyzed: ime vuccanti bhikkhave āsavā savarā pahātabbā ye savarena pahīnāḥ honti
translated: These are called the effluents to be abandoned by restraint, which are abandoned by restraint.

original: Katame ca, bhikkhave, āsavā paṭisevanā pahātabbā ye paṭisevanāya pahīnā honti?
analyzed: katame ca bhikkhave āsavā paṭisevanā pahātabbā ye paṭisevanāya pahīnāḥ honti
translated: “And what are the effluents to be abandoned by using, which are abandoned by using?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yoniso cīvaraṁ paṭisevati:
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yonisas cīvaram paṭisevati
translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu uses wise consideration in receiving robe material:

original: ‘yāvadeva sītassa paṭighātāya, uṇhassa paṭighātāya, ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṁ paṭighātāya, yāvadeva hirikopīnapaṭicchādanatthaṁ’.
analyzed: yāvat eva sītassa paṭighātāya uṇhassa paṭighātāya ḍasama kasa vāta ātapa sarīsapa samphassānam paṭighātāya yāvat eva hiri kopīna paṭicchādana ttha
translated: ‘This robe material will last for a day or two days or three days or four days or five days or six days or seven days.’

original: Paṭisaṅkhā yoniso piṇḍapātaṁ paṭisevati:
analyzed: paṭisaṅkhā yonisaḥ piṇḍapātam paṭisevati
translated: He uses wise consideration in receiving almsfood:

original: ‘neva davāya na madāya na maṇḍanāya na vibhūsanāya, yāvadeva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā
analyzed: na iva davāya na madāya na maṇḍanāya na vibhūsanāya yāvat eva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā
translated: ‘This almsfood will last for a day or two days or three days or four days or five days or six days or seven days.’

original: yāpanāya, vihiṁsūparatiyā brahmacariyānuggahāya, iti purāṇañca vedanaṁ paṭihaṅkhāmi,
analyzed: yāpanāya brahmacariya anuggahāya iti purāṇam ca vedanam paṭihaṅkhāmi
translated: for the support of those who are sick, for the use of those who are not sick, for the support of those who are training, for the support of the Community, for the use of the Community.

original: navañca vedanaṁ na uppādessāmi, yātrā ca me bhavissati anavajjatā ca phāsuvihāro ca’.
analyzed: navam ca vedanam na uppādessāmi yātrā ca me bhavissati anavajja tā ca phāsu vihāraḥ ca
translated: I will put an end to old feelings without arousing new feelings, and I will maintain myself in comfort.’

original: Paṭisaṅkhā yoniso senāsanaṁ paṭisevati:
analyzed: paṭisaṅkhā yonisaḥ senāsanam paṭisevati
translated: He uses a resting place after careful consideration,

original: ‘yāvadeva sītassa paṭighātāya, uṇhassa paṭighātāya, ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṁ paṭighātāya, yāvadeva utuparissayavinodanapaṭisallānārāmatthaṁ’.
analyzed: yāvat eva sītassa paṭighātāya uṇhassa paṭighātāya ḍasama kasa vāta ātapa sarīsapa samphassānam paṭighātāya yāvat eva utu parissaya vinodana paṭisallāna ārāmattha
translated: thinking: ‘I will ward off the cold with this, or the heat, or the wind, or the rain, or I will ward off the danger from wild beasts, or I will ward off mosquitoes, gadflies, wind, the heat of the sun, and serpents.’

original: Paṭisaṅkhā yoniso gilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṁ paṭisevati:
analyzed: paṭisaṅkhā yonisas gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhāram paṭisevati
translated: He uses medicine after careful consideration,

original: ‘yāvadeva uppannānaṁ veyyābādhikānaṁ vedanānaṁ paṭighātāya, abyābajjhaparamatāyā’ti.
analyzed: yāvat eva uppannānam veyyābādhikānam vedanānam paṭighātāya a byābajjha parama tāya ati
translated: thinking: ‘I will ward off the pains and torments of the present that have arisen because of disturbance of the elements, and I will maintain myself in comfort.’

original: Yaṁ hissa, bhikkhave, appaṭisevato uppajjeyyuṁ āsavā vighātapariḷāhā, paṭisevato evaṁsa te āsavā vighātapariḷāhā na honti.
analyzed: yam hissa bhikkhave appaṭisevataḥ uppajjeyyuṃ āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ paṭisevataḥ te āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ na honti
translated: For those defilements and vexations that might arise in one who does not use these things after careful consideration do not arise for one who uses them after careful consideration.

original: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, āsavā paṭisevanā pahātabbā ye paṭisevanāya pahīnā honti.
analyzed: ime vuccanti bhikkhave āsavā paṭisevanā pahātabbā ye paṭisevanāya pahīnāḥ honti
translated: These are called the taints to be abandoned by resorting, which are abandoned by resorting.

original: Katame ca, bhikkhave, āsavā adhivāsanā pahātabbā ye adhivāsanāya pahīnā honti?🔽Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yoniso khamo hoti sītassa uṇhassa, jighacchāya,🔽pipāsāya, ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṁ, duruttānaṁ durāgatānaṁ vacanapathānaṁ,🔽uppannānaṁ sārīrikānaṁ vedanānaṁ dukkhānaṁ tibbānaṁ kharānaṁ kaṭukānaṁ asātānaṁ amanāpānaṁ
analyzed: katame ca bhikkhave āsavāḥ adhivāsanā pahātabbāḥ ye adhivāsanāya pahīnāḥ honti  idha bhikkhave bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yonisaḥ khamaḥ hoti sītassa uṇhassa jighacchāya  pipāsāya duruttānam durāgatānam vacana pathāna  uppannānam sārīrikānam vedanānam dukkhānam tibbānam kharānam kaṭukānam asātānam amanāpānam
translated: “And what are the taints to be abandoned by enduring, which are abandoned by enduring?🔽Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu is wise; he possesses the wisdom that sees into (the nature of) causes, and he understands as it really is: ‘This is suffering,’ … ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering.’

original: pāṇaharānaṁ adhivāsakajātiko hoti.
analyzed: adhivāsaka jātikaḥ hoti
translated: He is patient, endowed with patience and gentleness, and he does not come to harm through anger.

original: Yaṁ hissa, bhikkhave, anadhivāsato uppajjeyyuṁ āsavā vighātapariḷāhā, adhivāsato evaṁsa te āsavā vighātapariḷāhā na honti.
analyzed: yam hissa bhikkhave anadhivāsataḥ uppajjeyyum āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ adhivāsataḥ te āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ na honti
translated: For whatever taints and troubles would arise in one who does not endure are not present in one who endures.

original: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, āsavā adhivāsanā pahātabbā ye adhivāsanāya pahīnā honti.
analyzed: ime vuccanti bhikkhave āsavāḥ adhivāsanā pahātabbāḥ ye adhivāsanāya pahīnāḥ honti
translated: These are called the taints to be abandoned by enduring, which are abandoned by enduring.

original: Katame ca, bhikkhave, āsavā parivajjanā pahātabbā ye parivajjanāya pahīnā honti?🔽Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yoniso caṇḍaṁ hatthiṁ parivajjeti, caṇḍaṁ assaṁ
analyzed: katame ca bhikkhave āsavā parivajjanā pahātabbā ye parivajjanāya pahīnāḥ honti  idha bhikkhave bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yonisaḥ caṇḍam hatthim parivajjeti caṇḍam assa
translated: “And what are the taints to be abandoned by avoiding?

original: parivajjeti, caṇḍaṁ goṇaṁ parivajjeti, caṇḍaṁ kukkuraṁ parivajjeti, ahiṁ khāṇuṁ kaṇṭakaṭṭhānaṁ🔽sobbhaṁ papātaṁ candanikaṁ oḷigallaṁ, yathārūpe anāsane nisinnaṁ, yathārūpe agocare
analyzed: parivajja iti caṇḍam goṇam parivajja iti caṇḍam kukkuram parivajja iti ahim khāṇum kaṇṭakaṭṭhāna  yathārūpe anāsane nisinna yathārūpe agocare
translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu avoids a wild elephant, a wild horse, a wild bull, a wild dog, a snake, a stump, a bramble patch, a chasm, a cliff, a cesspit, a sewer.🔽He avoids sitting in the kinds of seat on which wise men do not sit.🔽He avoids the kinds of wilderness in which wise men do not dwell.

original: carantaṁ, yathārūpe pāpake mitte bhajantaṁ viññū sabrahmacārī pāpakesu ṭhānesu okappeyyuṁ,🔽so tañca anāsanaṁ tañca agocaraṁ te ca pāpake mitte paṭisaṅkhā yoniso parivajjeti.
analyzed: caranta yathārūpe pāpake mitte bhajantam viññū sabrahmacārī pāpakesu ṭhānesu okappeyyu  saḥ tat ca anāsanam tat ca agocaram te ca pāpake mitte paṭisaṅkhā yonisas parivajjeti
translated: He avoids the kinds of bad friends with whom wise men do not associate.🔽He avoids the kinds of bad talk about which wise men do not inquire.

original: Yaṁ hissa, bhikkhave, aparivajjayato uppajjeyyuṁ āsavā vighātapariḷāhā, parivajjayato evaṁsa te āsavā vighātapariḷāhā na honti.
analyzed: yam hissa bhikkhave a parivajjayataḥ uppajjeyyum āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhā parivajjayataḥ te āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ na honti
translated: For what taints and troubles might arise if he did not avoid these things do not arise for him when he avoids them.

original: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, āsavā parivajjanā pahātabbā ye parivajjanāya pahīnā honti.
analyzed: ime vuccanti bhikkhave āsavā parivajjanā pahātabbā ye parivajjanāya pahīnāḥ honti
translated: These are called the taints to be abandoned by avoiding, which are abandoned by avoiding.

original: Katame ca, bhikkhave, āsavā vinodanā pahātabbā ye vinodanāya pahīnā honti?
analyzed: katame ca bhikkhave āsavā vinodanā pahātabbā ye vinodanāya pahīnāḥ honti
translated: “And what are the taints to be abandoned by destroying, which are abandoned by destroying?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yoniso uppannaṁ kāmavitakkaṁ nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṁ gameti,
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yonisas uppannam kāma vitakkam na adhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvam gameti
translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu does not tolerate an arisen sensual thought; he abandons it, destroys it, dispels it, and wipes it out of existence.

original: paṭisaṅkhā yoniso uppannaṁ byāpādavitakkaṁ …
analyzed: paṭisaṅkhā yonisas uppannam byāpāda vitakkam
translated: He does not tolerate an arisen thought of ill will…

original: uppannaṁ vihiṁsāvitakkaṁ …🔽uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṁ gameti.
analyzed: uppannam vihisā vitakkam  uppanna uppanne pāpake akusale dhamme na adhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvam gameti
translated: an arisen thought of harming…🔽any evil unwholesome states that arise.

original: Yaṁ hissa, bhikkhave, avinodayato uppajjeyyuṁ āsavā vighātapariḷāhā, vinodayato evaṁsa te āsavā vighātapariḷāhā na honti.
analyzed: yam hissa bhikkhave a vinodayataḥ uppajjeyyum āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ vinodayataḥ te āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ na honti
translated: For what reason? Because, bhikkhus, when not destroyed, these taints would result in harm and suffering; but when destroyed, they result in welfare and happiness.

original: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, āsavā vinodanā pahātabbā ye vinodanāya pahīnā honti.
analyzed: ime vuccanti bhikkhave āsavā vinodanā pahātabbā ye vinodanāya pahīnāḥ honti
translated: These are called the taints to be abandoned by destroying, which are abandoned by destroying.🔽“And what are the taints to be abandoned by developing, which are abandoned by developing?

original: Katame ca, bhikkhave, āsavā bhāvanā pahātabbā ye bhāvanāya pahīnā honti?
analyzed: katame ca bhikkhave āsavāḥ bhāvanā pahātabbāḥ ye bhāvanāya pahīnāḥ honti
translated: “And what are the taints to be abandoned by development?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yoniso satisambojjhaṅgaṁ bhāveti vivekanissitaṁ virāganissitaṁ nirodhanissitaṁ vosaggapariṇāmiṁ,
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yonisas sati sambojjhaṅgam bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissitam vosagga pariṇāmi
translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu develops the mindfulness factor of complete awakening …

original: paṭisaṅkhā yoniso dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgaṁ bhāveti …🔽vīriyasambojjhaṅgaṁ bhāveti …
analyzed: paṭisaṅkhā yonisas dhammavicaya sambojjhaṅgam bhāveti  vīriya sambojjhaṅgam bhāveti
translated: the investigation-of-states factor of complete awakening …🔽the energy factor of complete awakening …

original: pītisambojjhaṅgaṁ bhāveti …🔽passaddhisambojjhaṅgaṁ bhāveti …🔽samādhisambojjhaṅgaṁ bhāveti …
analyzed: pīti sambojjhaṅgam bhāveti  passaddhi sambojjhaṅgam bhāveti  samādhi sambojjhaṅgam bhāva iti
translated: the rapture factor of complete awakening …🔽the tranquillity factor of complete awakening …🔽the concentration factor of complete awakening …

original: upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṁ bhāveti vivekanissitaṁ virāganissitaṁ nirodhanissitaṁ vosaggapariṇāmiṁ.
analyzed: upekkhā sambojjhaṅgam bhāveti viveka nissitam virāga nissitam nirodha nissitam vosagga pariṇāmi
translated: the equanimity factor of complete awakening, which is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release.

original: Yaṁ hissa, bhikkhave, abhāvayato uppajjeyyuṁ āsavā vighātapariḷāhā, bhāvayato evaṁsa te āsavā vighātapariḷāhā na honti.
analyzed: yam hissa bhikkhave a bhāvayataḥ uppajjeyyuṃ āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ bhāvayataḥ te āsavāḥ vighāta pariḷāhāḥ na honti
translated: For what taints and fevers might arise in one who does not develop these things do not arise for him when he develops them.

original: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, āsavā bhāvanā pahātabbā ye bhāvanāya pahīnā honti.
analyzed: ime vuccanti bhikkhave āsavā bhāvanā pahātabbā ye bhāvanāya pahīnāḥ honti
translated: These are called the taints to be abandoned by development, and they are abandoned by development.”🔽“Bhikkhus, there are these three things.

original: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, chahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṁ puññakkhettaṁ lokassā”ti.🔽Catutthaṁ.🔽Aṅguttara Nikāya 6.59
analyzed: imehi kho bhikkhave chahi dhammehi samannāgataḥ bhikkhu āhuneyyaḥ hoti pāhuneyyaḥ dakkhiṇeyyaḥ añjali karaṇīyaḥ anuttaram puññakkhettam lokassa ati  catuttha  aṅguttara nikāya
translated: A monk who has these six qualities is worthy of gifts, worthy of hospitality, worthy of offerings, worthy of reverential salutation, an unsurpassed field of merit for the world.”🔽The fourth section on six things is finished.🔽The Book of the Sixes

original: 6. Mahāvagga
analyzed: mahāvagga
translated: The Greater Section

original: Dārukammikasutta
analyzed: dārukammikasutta
translated: The Householder Dārukammika

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā nātike viharati giñjakāvasathe.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavān na atike viharati giñjaka āvasathe
translated: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling at Nādika in the Brick House.

original: Atha kho dārukammiko gahapati yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho dārukammikaṁ gahapatiṁ bhagavā etadavoca:
analyzed: atha khalu dārukammikaḥ gahapati yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnam khalu dārukammikam gahapatim bhagavān etat avoca
translated: Then the householder Dārukammika approached the Blessed One, paid homage to him, and sat down to one side. The Blessed One said to him:

original: “api nu te, gahapati, kule dānaṁ dīyatī”ti?
analyzed: api nu te gahapati kule dānam dīyati iti
translated: “Householder, is almsfood given in your family?”

original: “Dīyati me, bhante, kule dānaṁ.
analyzed: dīyati me bhante kule dāna
translated: “Almsfood is given in our family, venerable sir.

original: Tañca kho ye te bhikkhū āraññikā piṇḍapātikā paṁsukūlikā arahanto vā arahattamaggaṁ vā samāpannā, tathārūpesu me, bhante, bhikkhūsu dānaṁ dīyatī”ti.
analyzed: tat ca kho ye te bhikkhū āraññikā piṇḍapātikā pasukūlikā arahantaḥ vā arahatta maggam vā samāpannā tathārūpesu me bhante bhikkhūsu dānam dīyati iti
translated: But it is given to those bhikkhus who are forest dwellers, almsfood eaters, rag-robe wearers, and of those who are arahants or arahant-path-attainers.”

original: “Dujjānaṁ kho etaṁ, gahapati, tayā gihinā kāmabhoginā puttasambādhasayanaṁ ajjhāvasantena,
analyzed: dujjānam kho eta gahapati tayā gihinā kāma bhoginā putta sambādha sayanam ajjhāvasantena
translated: “Householder, it’s hard for you, living in a house crowded with children,

original: kāsikacandanaṁ paccanubhontena, mālāgandhavilepanaṁ dhārayantena, jātarūparajataṁ
analyzed: kāsika candanam mālā gandha vilepanam dhārayantena jātarūpa rajata
translated: using Kāsī fabrics and sandalwood, wearing garlands, scents, and creams, handling gold and silver,

original: sādiyantena ime vā arahanto ime vā arahattamaggaṁ samāpannāti.
analyzed: ime vai arahantaḥ ime vai arahatta maggam samāpannā ati
translated: to know whether these are arahants or on the path to arahantship.

original: Āraññiko cepi, gahapati, bhikkhu hoti uddhato unnaḷo capalo mukharo vikiṇṇavāco muṭṭhassati asampajāno asamāhito vibbhantacitto pākatindriyo.
analyzed: āraññikaḥ ce pi gahapati bhikkhu hoti uddhataḥ unnaḷaḥ capalaḥ mukharaḥ vikiṇṇa vācaḥ muṭṭhaḥ sati asampajānaḥ asamāhitaḥ vibbhanta cittaḥ pākatindriyaḥ
translated: “If a forest-dwelling monk is restless, puffed up, personally vain, talkative, unalert, and not fully aware of the noble method,

original: Evaṁ so tenaṅgena gārayho.
analyzed: evam saḥ tena aṅgena gārayhaḥ
translated: then he is to be criticized for that.

original: Āraññiko cepi, gahapati, bhikkhu hoti anuddhato anunnaḷo acapalo amukharo avikiṇṇavāco upaṭṭhitassati sampajāno samāhito ekaggacitto saṁvutindriyo.
analyzed: āraññikaḥ ce pi gahapati bhikkhu hoti an uddhataḥ an unnaḷaḥ a capalaḥ a mukharaḥ a vikiṇṇa vācaḥ upaṭṭhita sati sampajānaḥ samāhitaḥ ekagga cittaḥ savuti indriyo
translated: But if a forest-dwelling monk is not restless, puffed up, personally vain, or talkative, but is alert and fully aware of the noble method,

original: Evaṁ so tenaṅgena pāsaṁso.
analyzed: evam saḥ tena aṅgena pāsasaḥ
translated: then he is to be praised for that.

original: Gāmantavihārī cepi, gahapati, bhikkhu hoti uddhato …pe…
analyzed: gāmantavihārī ce pi gahapati bhikkhu hoti uddhato pe
translated: “If a monk who lives in the village area is restless, puffed up, personally vain, talkative, unalert, and not fully aware of the noble method,

original: evaṁ so tenaṅgena gārayho.
analyzed: evam saḥ tena aṅgena gārayhaḥ
translated: then he is to be criticized for that.

original: Gāmantavihārī cepi, gahapati, bhikkhu hoti anuddhato …pe…
analyzed: gāmantavihārī ce pi gahapati bhikkhu hoti anuddhato pe
translated: If a bhikkhu who lives in dependence on a village is not agitated …

original: evaṁ so tenaṅgena pāsaṁso.
analyzed: evam saḥ tena aṅgena pāsasaḥ
translated: he is praiseworthy in that respect.

original: Piṇḍapātiko cepi, gahapati, bhikkhu hoti uddhato …pe…
analyzed: piṇḍapātiko ce pi gahapati bhikkhu hoti uddhataḥ pe
translated: If a bhikkhu who goes for alms is agitated …

original: evaṁ so tenaṅgena gārayho.
analyzed: evam saḥ tena aṅgena gārayhaḥ
translated: he is blameworthy in that respect.

original: Piṇḍapātiko cepi, gahapati, bhikkhu hoti anuddhato …pe…
analyzed: piṇḍapātiko ce pi gahapati bhikkhu hoti anuddhato pe
translated: If a bhikkhu who goes for alms is not agitated …

original: evaṁ so tenaṅgena pāsaṁso.
analyzed: evam saḥ tena aṅgena pāsasaḥ
translated: he is praiseworthy in that respect.

original: Nemantaniko cepi, gahapati, bhikkhu hoti uddhato …pe…
analyzed: nemantanikaḥ ce pi gahapati bhikkhu hoti uddhataḥ pe
translated: If a bhikkhu who gets invitations is agitated …

original: evaṁ so tenaṅgena gārayho.
analyzed: evam saḥ tena aṅgena gārayhaḥ
translated: he is blameworthy in that respect.

original: Nemantaniko cepi, gahapati, bhikkhu hoti anuddhato …pe…
analyzed: nemantanikaḥ ce pi gahapati bhikkhu hoti anuddhato pe
translated: If a bhikkhu who gets invitations is not agitated …

original: evaṁ so tenaṅgena pāsaṁso.
analyzed: evam saḥ tena aṅgena pāsasaḥ
translated: he is praiseworthy in that respect.

original: Paṁsukūliko cepi, gahapati, bhikkhu hoti uddhato …pe…
analyzed: pasukūliko ce pi gahapati bhikkhu hoti uddhataḥ pe
translated: If a bhikkhu who wears rag-robes is agitated …

original: evaṁ so tenaṅgena gārayho.
analyzed: evam saḥ tena aṅgena gārayhaḥ
translated: he is blameworthy in that respect.

original: Paṁsukūliko cepi, gahapati, bhikkhu hoti anuddhato …pe…
analyzed: pasukūliko ce pi gahapati bhikkhu hoti anuddhato pe
translated: If a bhikkhu who wears rag-robes is not agitated …

original: evaṁ so tenaṅgena pāsaṁso.
analyzed: evam saḥ tena aṅgena pāsasaḥ
translated: he is praiseworthy in that respect.

original: Gahapaticīvaradharo cepi, gahapati, bhikkhu hoti uddhato unnaḷo capalo mukharo vikiṇṇavāco muṭṭhassati asampajāno asamāhito vibbhantacitto pākatindriyo.
analyzed: gahapati cīvara dharaḥ ce pi gahapati bhikkhu hoti uddhataḥ unnaḷaḥ capalaḥ mukharaḥ vikiṇṇa vācaḥ muṭṭhaḥ sati asampajānaḥ asamāhitaḥ vibbhanta cittaḥ pākatindriyaḥ
translated: “If a monk who wears robes given by householders is restless, puffed up, personally vain, talkative, unalert, and not focused on his own benefit,

original: Evaṁ so tenaṅgena gārayho.
analyzed: evam saḥ tena aṅgena gārayhaḥ
translated: then in that case he should be criticized for that.

original: Gahapaticīvaradharo cepi, gahapati, bhikkhu hoti anuddhato anunnaḷo acapalo amukharo avikiṇṇavāco upaṭṭhitassati sampajāno samāhito ekaggacitto saṁvutindriyo.
analyzed: gahapati cīvara dharaḥ ce pi gahapati bhikkhu hoti an uddhataḥ an unnaḷaḥ a capalaḥ a mukharaḥ a vikiṇṇa vācaḥ upaṭṭhita sati sampajānaḥ samāhitaḥ ekagga cittaḥ savuti indriyo
translated: “If a monk who wears robes given by householders is not restless, puffed up, personally vain, talkative, unalert, and not focused on his own benefit,

original: Evaṁ so tenaṅgena pāsaṁso.🔽Iṅgha tvaṁ, gahapati, saṅghe dānaṁ dehi.
analyzed: evam saḥ tena aṅgena pāsasaḥ  iṅgha tva gahapati saṅghe dānam dehi
translated: then in that case he should be praised for that.🔽So, householder, give a gift to the Sangha.

original: Saṅghe te dānaṁ dadato cittaṁ pasīdissati.
analyzed: saṅghe te dānam dadataḥ cittam pasīdissati
translated: When you give a gift to the Sangha, your mind will be uplifted.

original: So tvaṁ pasannacitto kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjissasī”ti.
analyzed: saḥ tvam pasanna cittaḥ kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā sugatim saggam lokam upapajjissasi iti
translated: With a mind uplifted, on the breakup of the body, after death, you will be reborn in a good destination, in a heavenly world.”

original: “Esāhaṁ, bhante, ajjatagge saṅghe dānaṁ dassāmī”ti.🔽Pañcamaṁ.
analyzed: esā aha bhante ajjatagge saṅghe dānam dassāmi iti  pañcama
translated: “From this day forth, I will give a gift to the Sangha.”🔽The fifth section on the Sangha is finished.

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 6.60
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya
translated: The Book of the Fives

original: 6. Mahāvagga
analyzed: mahāvagga
translated: The Greater Division

original: Hatthisāriputtasutta
analyzed: hatthisāriputtasutta
translated: With Hatthaka of Āḷavī

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā bārāṇasiyaṁ viharati isipatane migadāye.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā bārāṇasiyam viharati isipatane migadāye
translated: At one time the Buddha was staying at Benares, at the Deer Park in Isipatana.

original: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā therā bhikkhū pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantā maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnā sannipatitā abhidhammakathaṁ kathenti.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena sambahulāḥ therāḥ bhikkhū pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkantāḥ maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnā sannipatitāḥ abhidhamma katham kathenti
translated: At that time, after the meal, on return from their alms round, a number of senior monks had gathered together in the assembly hall. They were sitting together discussing the Teaching, the Monastic Law, and the summaries.

original: Tatra sudaṁ āyasmā citto hatthisāriputto therānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ abhidhammakathaṁ kathentānaṁ antarantarā kathaṁ opāteti.
analyzed: tatra sudam āyasmā cittaḥ hatthi sāri putto therānam bhikkhūnam abhidhamma katham kathentānam antarantarā katham
translated: At that time Venerable Citta Hatthisariputta kept interrupting their discussion.

original: Atha kho āyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko āyasmantaṁ cittaṁ hatthisāriputtaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho āyasmā mahākoṭṭhikaḥ āyasmantam cittam hatthisāriputtam etat avoca
translated: Venerable Mahā Koṭṭhita said to him,

original: “māyasmā citto hatthisāriputto therānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ abhidhammakathaṁ kathentānaṁ antarantarā kathaṁ opātesi, yāva kathāpariyosānaṁ āyasmā citto āgametū”ti.
analyzed: mā āyasmā cittaḥ hatthisāriputto therānam bhikkhūnam abhidhamma katham kathentānam antarantarā katham opātesi yāva kathā pariyosānam āyasmā cittaḥ āgametu uti
translated: “Venerable Citta, don’t interrupt the senior monks’ discussion of the Teaching. Please wait until it’s finished.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, āyasmato cittassa hatthisāriputtassa sahāyakā bhikkhū āyasmantaṁ mahākoṭṭhikaṁ etadavocuṁ:
analyzed: evam vutte āyasmataḥ cittassa hatthisāriputtassa sahāyakāḥ bhikkhū āyasmantam mahākoṭṭhikam etat avocuḥ
translated: When he said this, Citta’s companions said to Mahā Koṭṭhita,

original: “māyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko āyasmantaṁ cittaṁ hatthisāriputtaṁ apasādesi, paṇḍito āyasmā citto hatthisāriputto.
analyzed: mā āyasmā mahākoṭṭhikaḥ āyasmantam cittam hatthi sāriputtam apasādesi paṇḍitaḥ āyasmā cittaḥ hatthi sāriputto
translated: “Don’t discourage Venerable Citta Hatthisāriputta. He’s wise,

original: Pahoti cāyasmā citto hatthisāriputto therānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ abhidhammakathaṁ kathetun”ti.
analyzed: pahoti ca āyasmā cittaḥ hatthisāri putto therānam bhikkhūnam abhidhamma katham kathetun ti
translated: and he’s capable of discussing the Teaching, the Monastic Law, and the summaries with the senior monks.”

original: “Dujjānaṁ kho etaṁ, āvuso, parassa cetopariyāyaṁ ajānantehi.
analyzed: dujjānam kho ete āvuso parassa cetaḥ upariyāyam a jānantehi
translated: “It’s hard for those who don’t know the minds of others to know the minds of others.

original: Idhāvuso, ekacco puggalo tāvadeva soratasorato hoti, nivātanivāto hoti, upasantupasanto hoti, yāva satthāraṁ upanissāya viharati aññataraṁ vā garuṭṭhāniyaṁ sabrahmacāriṁ.
analyzed: idha āvuso ekaccaḥ puggalo tāvat eva sorata sorataḥ hoti nivāta nivātaḥ hoti upasantupasantaḥ hoti yāva satthāram upanissāya viharati aññataram vā garuṭṭhāniyam sabrahmacāri
translated: There’s a person who is very still and calm and peaceful only as long as he stays with the Teacher or a venerables monk.

original: Yato ca kho so vapakassateva satthārā, vapakassati garuṭṭhāniyehi sabrahmacārīhi,🔽so saṁsaṭṭho viharati bhikkhūhi bhikkhunīhi upāsakehi upāsikāhi raññā rājamahāmattehi
analyzed: yatas ca kho saḥ vapakassatā iva satthārā vapakassati garuṭṭhāniyehi sabrahmacārīhi  so sa saṭṭhaḥ viharati bhikkhūhi bhikkhunīhi upāsakehi upāsikāhi raññā rāja mahāmattehi
translated: But when he’s corrected by the Teacher or the venerables monks,

original: titthiyehi titthiyasāvakehi.
analyzed: titthiyehi titthiya sāvakehi
translated: he associates with monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen; with kings, kings’ ministers, and sectarians and their disciples.

original: Tassa saṁsaṭṭhassa vissatthassa pākatassa bhassamanuyuttassa viharato rāgo cittaṁ anuddhaṁseti.
analyzed: tassa sa saṭṭhassa vissatthassa pākatassa bhassa manuyuttassa viharataḥ rāgaḥ cittam anuddhaseti
translated: As he lives associating with and attending on good persons, the unarisen stain of sleepiness arises in him and the arisen stain of sleepiness increases.

original: So rāgānuddhaṁsitena cittena sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: so rāga an uddhasitena cittena sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati
translated: With his mind obsessed by the stain of sleepiness, he abandons the training and reverts to the lower life.

original: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, goṇo kiṭṭhādo dāmena vā baddho vaje vā oruddho.
analyzed: seyyathā api āvuso goṇaḥ kiṭṭhādaḥ dāmena vā baddhaḥ vaje vā oruddhaḥ
translated: Suppose a cow to be milked had her calf always with her.🔽Now suppose someone said, ‘This cow to be milked, with her calf always with her, will not give milk,’

original: Yo nu kho, āvuso, evaṁ vadeyya: ‘na dānāyaṁ goṇo kiṭṭhādo punadeva kiṭṭhaṁ otarissatī’ti, sammā nu kho so, āvuso, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?
analyzed: yaḥ nu kho āvuso evam vadeyya na dāna ayam goṇaḥ kiṭṭhādo punar eva kiṭṭham otarissati iti sammā nu kho saḥ āvuso vadamānaḥ vadeyya ati
translated: would he be speaking rightly?”

original: “No hidaṁ, āvuso”.
analyzed: na u hide āvuso
translated: “No, friend.

original: “Ṭhānañhetaṁ, āvuso, vijjati, yaṁ so goṇo kiṭṭhādo dāmaṁ vā chetvā vajaṁ vā bhinditvā, atha punadeva kiṭṭhaṁ otareyyāti.🔽Evamevaṁ kho, āvuso, idhekacco puggalo tāvadeva soratasorato hoti, nivātanivāto hoti,
analyzed: ṭhānan ha itas āvuso vijjati yam saḥ goṇaḥ kiṭṭhādaḥ dāmam vā chetvā vajam vā bhinditvā atha punar eva kiṭṭham otareyya ati  evam evam kho āvuso idha ekaccaḥ puggalo tāvat eva sorata sorataḥ hoti nivāta nivātaḥ hoti
translated: Because there is a possibility that this cow to be milked, with her calf always with her, will give milk.

original: upasantupasanto hoti yāva satthāraṁ upanissāya viharati aññataraṁ vā garuṭṭhāniyaṁ sabrahmacāriṁ.
analyzed: upasantu upasantaḥ hoti yāva satthāram upanissāya viharati aññataram vā garuṭṭhāniyam sabrahmacāri
translated: So too, friend, there are some persons here who are so delicate and soft that they are unable to endure the discomfort of pricking ear-dust, the discomfort of contact with robes, almsfood, and resting places, and the discomfort of the various kinds of contacts.

original: Yato ca kho so vapakassateva satthārā, vapakassati garuṭṭhāniyehi sabrahmacārīhi,
analyzed: yatas ca kho saḥ vapakassatā iva satthārā vapakassati garuṭṭhāniyehi sabrahmacārīhi
translated: But he keeps on talking about it to the Teacher and to his wise companions in the holy life.

original: so saṁsaṭṭho viharati bhikkhūhi bhikkhunīhi upāsakehi upāsikāhi raññā rājamahāmattehi
analyzed: so sa saṭṭhaḥ viharati bhikkhūhi bhikkhunīhi upāsakehi upāsikāhi raññā rāja mahāmattehi
translated: He keeps associating with the bhikkhus, bhikkhunis, male and female lay followers, kings and royal ministers, and with other sectarians and their disciples.

original: titthiyehi titthiyasāvakehi.🔽Tassa saṁsaṭṭhassa vissatthassa pākatassa bhassamanuyuttassa viharato rāgo cittaṁ anuddhaṁseti.
analyzed: titthiyehi titthiya sāvakehi  tassa sa saṭṭhassa vissatthassa pākatassa bhassa manuyuttassa viharataḥ rāgaḥ cittam anuddhaseti
translated: He keeps on talking about it to them.🔽As he keeps on talking about it, lust invades his mind and remains.

original: So rāgānuddhaṁsitena cittena sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: so rāga an uddhasitena cittena sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati
translated: With his mind invaded by lust, he abandons the training and reverts to the lower life.

original: Idha panāvuso, ekacco puggalo vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.🔽So ‘lābhimhi paṭhamassa jhānassā’ti saṁsaṭṭho viharati bhikkhūhi …pe…
analyzed: idha pana āvuso ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ vivicca iva kāmehi pe paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati  so lābhimhi paṭhamassa jhānassa ati sasaṭṭhaḥ viharati bhikkhūhi pe
translated: “Here, friend, someone, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, enters and dwells in the first jhana…🔽He keeps on talking about it to the bhikkhus…

original: sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati
translated: With his mind invaded by lust, he abandons the training and reverts to the lower life.

original: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, cātumahāpathe thullaphusitako devo vassanto rajaṁ antaradhāpeyya, cikkhallaṁ pātukareyya.
analyzed: seyyathā api āvuso cātumahāpathe thullaphusitakaḥ devaḥ vassantaḥ rajam antaradhāpeyya cikkhallam pātukareyya
translated: “Suppose, friend, a light rain shower falls on a great rock, and the water runs off, flows off, streams off, and spreads out.

original: Yo nu kho, āvuso, evaṁ vadeyya: ‘na dāni amusmiṁ cātumahāpathe punadeva rajo pātubhavissatī’ti, sammā nu kho so, āvuso, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?
analyzed: yaḥ nu kho āvuso evam vadeyya na dāni amusmin cātumahāpathe punar eva rajaḥ pātubhavissati iti sammā nu kho saḥ āvuso vadamānaḥ vadeyya ati
translated: “If someone were to say, ‘From now on no more dust and dirt will appear on this crossroads,’ would he be speaking rightly?”

original: “No hidaṁ, āvuso”.🔽“Ṭhānañhetaṁ, āvuso, vijjati, yaṁ amusmiṁ cātumahāpathe manussā vā atikkameyyuṁ, gopasū vā atikkameyyuṁ, vātātapo vā snehagataṁ pariyādiyeyya, atha punadeva rajo pātubhaveyyāti.
analyzed: na u hide āvuso  ṭhānam ha itas āvuso vijjati yam amusmin cātumahāpathe manussāḥ vā atikkameyyu gopasū vā atikkameyyu vāta ātapaḥ vā sneha gatam pariyādiyeyya atha punar eva rajaḥ pātubhaveyya ati
translated: “No, friend.🔽Because there is a possibility that people or cattle will stir up the dust and dirt that is there.”

original: Evamevaṁ kho, āvuso, idhekacco puggalo vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: evam evam kho āvuso idha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ vivicca iva kāmehi pe paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “So too, friend, here some person, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, enters and dwells in the first jhāna …

original: So ‘lābhimhi paṭhamassa jhānassā’ti saṁsaṭṭho viharati bhikkhūhi …pe…
analyzed: so lābhimhi paṭhamassa jhānassa ati sasaṭṭhaḥ viharati bhikkhūhi pe
translated: He thinks: ‘I obtain the first jhāna.’ He dwells in close association with bhikkhus …

original: sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati
translated: and having abandoned the training, he reverts to the low life.

original: Idha panāvuso, ekacco puggalo vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: idha pana āvuso ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā pe dutiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Here, friend, some person, with the stilling of applied and sustained thought, enters upon and dwells in the second jhāna …

original: So ‘lābhimhi dutiyassa jhānassā’ti saṁsaṭṭho viharati bhikkhūhi …pe…
analyzed: so lābhimhi dutiyassa jhānassa ati sasaṭṭhaḥ viharati bhikkhūhi pe
translated: thinking, ‘I obtain the second jhāna,’ he dwells in a way that is incompatible with the second jhāna. …

original: sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati
translated: He thinks, ‘I’m attaining the second jhāna.’ He lives in a way that violates the monastic code of conduct.🔽He gives up the practice of the spiritual life and returns to a lesser life.

original: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, gāmassa vā nigamassa vā avidūre mahantaṁ taḷākaṁ.🔽Tattha thullaphusitako devo vuṭṭho sippisambukampi sakkharakaṭhalampi antaradhāpeyya.
analyzed: sā iyyathā api āvuso gāmassa vā nigamassa vā avidūre mahantam taḷāka  tattha thullaphusitakaḥ devaḥ vuṭṭhaḥ sippi sambukam pi sakkhara kaṭhalam pi antaradhāpeyya
translated: “Suppose there’s a large pond not far from a village or town.🔽After a heavy rain, the water from the hills would flow into the pond, filling it up and covering any stumps or sand banks that were there.

original: Yo nu kho, āvuso, evaṁ vadeyya: ‘na dāni amusmiṁ taḷāke punadeva sippisambukā vā sakkharakaṭhalā vā pātubhavissantī’ti, sammā nu kho so, āvuso, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?
analyzed: yaḥ nu kho āvuso evam vadeyya na dāni amusmin taḷāke punar eva sippi sambukāḥ vā sakkhara kaṭhalāḥ vā pātubhavissanti iti sammā nu kho saḥ āvuso vadamānaḥ vadeyya ati
translated: If someone were to say that the stumps and sand banks are no longer there, would they be speaking rightly?”

original: “No hidaṁ, āvuso”.
analyzed: na u hide āvuso
translated: “No, friend.

original: “Ṭhānañhetaṁ, āvuso, vijjati, yaṁ amusmiṁ taḷāke manussā vā piveyyuṁ, gopasū vā piveyyuṁ,
analyzed: ṭhānan ha itas āvuso vijjati yam amusmin taḷāke manussāḥ vā piveyyu gopasū vā piveyyu
translated: Because there’s a chance that people or cattle might use the pond,

original: vātātapo vā snehagataṁ pariyādiyeyya, atha punadeva sippisambukāpi sakkharakaṭhalāpi pātubhaveyyunti.
analyzed: vāta ātapaḥ vā sneha gatam atha punar eva sippi sambukā api sakkhara kaṭhalā api pātubhaveyyunti
translated: or that the wind and sun might dry it up, and then the stumps and sand banks would reappear.”

original: Evamevaṁ kho, āvuso, idhekacco puggalo vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: evam evam kho āvuso idha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā pe dutiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: So too, a person here attains the second jhāna …

original: So ‘lābhimhi dutiyassa jhānassā’ti saṁsaṭṭho viharati bhikkhūhi …pe…
analyzed: so lābhimhi dutiyassa jhānassa ati sasaṭṭhaḥ viharati bhikkhūhi pe
translated: he dwells in close association with the bhikkhus …

original: sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.🔽Idha panāvuso, ekacco puggalo pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati  idha pana āvuso ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ pītiyā ca virāgā pe tatiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: and having abandoned the training, he reverts to the low life.🔽“Here, a person attains the third jhāna …

original: So ‘lābhimhi tatiyassa jhānassā’ti saṁsaṭṭho viharati bhikkhūhi …pe…
analyzed: so lābhimhi tatiyassa jhānassa ati sasaṭṭhaḥ viharati bhikkhūhi pe
translated: he dwells in close association with the bhikkhus …

original: sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati
translated: and having abandoned the training, he reverts to the low life.

original: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, purisaṁ paṇītabhojanaṁ bhuttāviṁ ābhidosikaṁ bhojanaṁ nacchādeyya.
analyzed: seyyathā api āvuso purisam paṇīta bhojanam bhuttāvim ābhidosikam bhojanam
translated: “Suppose a man had eaten exquisite food and then swallowed poison.🔽Now if someone were to say: ‘The exquisite food that he has eaten will not kill him, but the poison that he has swallowed will kill him’—

original: Yo nu kho, āvuso, evaṁ vadeyya: ‘na dāni amuṁ purisaṁ punadeva bhojanaṁ chādessatī’ti, sammā nu kho so, āvuso, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?
analyzed: yaḥ nu kho āvuso evam vadeyya na dāni amum purisam punar eva bhojanam chādessati iti sammā nu kho saḥ āvuso vadamānaḥ vadeyya ati
translated: would he be speaking rightly?”

original: “No hidaṁ, āvuso”.
analyzed: na u hide āvuso
translated: “No, friend.”

original: “Ṭhānañhetaṁ, āvuso, vijjati, amuṁ purisaṁ paṇītabhojanaṁ bhuttāviṁ yāvassa sā ojā kāye ṭhassati tāva na aññaṁ bhojanaṁ chādessati.
analyzed: ṭhānam ha itas āvuso vijjati amum purisam paṇīta bhojanam bhuttāvim yāva sā ojā kāye tāva na aññam bhojanam chādessati
translated: ‘It’s possible that a man, after eating fine food, would not want any other food until the nutriment from that meal had decayed in his stomach.

original: Yato ca khvassa sā ojā antaradhāyissati, atha punadeva taṁ bhojanaṁ chādeyyāti.🔽Evamevaṁ kho, āvuso, idhekacco puggalo pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: yatas ca khvassa sā ojā antaradhāyissati atha punar eva tam bhojanam chādeyyāti  evam evam kho āvuso idha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ pītiyā ca virāgā pe tatiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: But when it had decayed, he would want that food again.🔽In the same way, a person enters & remains in the third jhāna…

original: So ‘lābhimhi tatiyassa jhānassā’ti saṁsaṭṭho viharati bhikkhūhi …pe…
analyzed: so lābhimhi tatiyassa jhānassa ati sasaṭṭhaḥ viharati bhikkhūhi pe
translated: He dwells together with the monks, the bhikkhus…

original: sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.🔽Idha, panāvuso, ekacco puggalo sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati  idha pana āvuso ekaccaḥ puggalo sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pe catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: and falls back into the secular life.🔽“Here, a person, with the abandoning of pleasure & pain—as with the earlier disappearance of elation & distress—enters & remains in the fourth jhāna: purity of equanimity & mindfulness, neither pleasure nor pain.

original: So ‘lābhimhi catutthassa jhānassā’ti saṁsaṭṭho viharati bhikkhūhi …pe…
analyzed: so lābhimhi catutthassa jhānassa ati sasaṭṭhaḥ viharati bhikkhūhi pe
translated: He dwells together with the monks, the bhikkhus…

original: sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati
translated: and falls back into the secular life.

original: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, pabbatasaṅkhepe udakarahado nivāto vigataūmiko.
analyzed: seyyathā api āvuso pabbata saṅkhepe udaka rahadaḥ nivātaḥ vigata ūmikaḥ
translated: Just as there is a lake in a mountain recess, clear, limpid, and undisturbed,

original: Yo nu kho, āvuso, evaṁ vadeyya: ‘na dāni amusmiṁ udakarahade punadeva ūmi pātubhavissatī’ti, sammā nu kho so, āvuso, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?
analyzed: yaḥ nu kho āvuso evam vadeyya na dāni amusmin udakarahade punadeva ūmi pātubhavissati iti sammā nu kho saḥ āvuso vadamānaḥ vadeyya ati
translated: If someone were to say, ‘There will be no more turbidity in this lake,’ would he be speaking rightly?”

original: “No hidaṁ, āvuso”.
analyzed: na u hide āvuso
translated: “No, friend.

original: “Ṭhānañhetaṁ, āvuso, vijjati, yā puratthimāya disāya āgaccheyya bhusā vātavuṭṭhi.🔽Sā tasmiṁ udakarahade ūmiṁ janeyya. Yā pacchimāya disāya āgaccheyya …pe… yā uttarāya
analyzed: ṭhānan ha itas āvuso vijjati yā puratthimāya disāya āgaccheyya bhusā  sā tasmin udakarahade ūmim janeyya yā pacchimāya disāya āgaccheyya pe yā uttarāya
translated: Because there is a possibility that a violent storm might arise in the eastern direction,🔽and that storm might stir up the waters of that lake, and bring turbidity to it.

original: disāya āgaccheyya … yā dakkhiṇāya disāya āgaccheyya bhusā vātavuṭṭhi. Sā tasmiṁ udakarahade ūmiṁ janeyyāti.🔽Evamevaṁ kho, āvuso, idhekacco puggalo sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: disāya āgaccheyya yā dakkhiṇāya disāya āgaccheyya bhusā vāta vuṭṭhi sā tasmin udakarahade ūmim janeyya ati  evam evam kho āvuso idha ekaccaḥ puggalo sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pe catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: Or a violent storm might arise in the western direction, in the northern direction, in the southern direction, and that storm might stir up the waters of that lake, and bring turbidity to it.🔽In the same way, friend, here some person, with the abandoning of pleasure and pain… enters and dwells in the fourth jhāna…

original: So ‘lābhimhi catutthassa jhānassā’ti saṁsaṭṭho viharati bhikkhūhi …pe…
analyzed: so lābhimhi catutthassa jhānassa ati sasaṭṭhaḥ viharati bhikkhūhi pe
translated: He dwells in close association with bhikkhus…

original: sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati
translated: and then abandons the training and reverts to the lower life.

original: Idha, panāvuso, ekacco puggalo sabbanimittānaṁ amanasikārā animittaṁ cetosamādhiṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: idha pana āvuso ekaccaḥ puggalo sabba nimittānam amanasikārā animittam cetosamādhim upasampajja viharati
translated: “There is the case where a certain person, with the abandoning of pleasure & pain—as with the earlier disappearance of elation & distress—enters & remains in the fourth jhāna: purity of equanimity & mindfulness, neither pleasure nor pain.

original: So ‘lābhimhi animittassa cetosamādhissā’ti saṁsaṭṭho viharati bhikkhūhi bhikkhunīhi upāsakehi upāsikāhi raññā rājamahāmattehi titthiyehi titthiyasāvakehi.🔽Tassa saṁsaṭṭhassa vissatthassa pākatassa bhassamanuyuttassa viharato rāgo cittaṁ anuddhaṁseti.
analyzed: saḥ lābhimhi animittassa cetosamādhissa ati sasaṭṭhaḥ viharati bhikkhūhi bhikkhunīhi upāsakehi upāsikāhi raññā rāja mahāmattehi titthiyehi titthiya sāvakehi  tassa sa saṭṭhassa vissatthassa pākatassa bhassa manuyuttassa viharataḥ rāgaḥ cittam anuddhaseti
translated: He thinks, ‘I attain & emerge mindfully.’ He extols himself & disparages others because of his attainment of the fourth jhāna.

original: So rāgānuddhaṁsitena cittena sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: so rāga an uddhasitena cittena sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati
translated: As he extols himself & disparages others, conceit arises in him.🔽With the arising of conceit, I tell you, monks, there is the arising of suffering.

original: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, rājā vā rājamahāmatto vā caturaṅginiyā senāya addhānamaggappaṭipanno aññatarasmiṁ vanasaṇḍe ekarattiṁ vāsaṁ upagaccheyya.
analyzed: seyyathā api āvuso rājā vā rāja mahāmattaḥ vā caturaṅginiyā senāya addhāna magga ppaṭipannaḥ aññatarasmim vana saṇḍe eka rattim vāsam upagaccheyya
translated: “There is the case where a certain person, with the abandoning of pleasure & pain—as with the earlier disappearance of elation & distress—enters & remains in the fourth jhāna: purity of equanimity & mindfulness, neither pleasure nor pain.🔽He thinks, ‘I attain & emerge mindfully.’ He becomes intoxicated with the idea of attainment, grows negligent, & fails to achieve the goal of recluseship.🔽“Suppose a king had a frontier fortress with a single gate.

original: Tatra hatthisaddena assasaddena rathasaddena pattisaddena bheripaṇavasaṅkhatiṇavaninnādasaddena cīrikasaddo antaradhāyeyya.
analyzed: tatra hatthi saddena assa saddena ratha saddena patti saddena bheri paṇava saṅkhati ṇava ninnāda saddena cīrika saddaḥ antaradhāyeyya
translated: Then the sound of elephants, the sound of horses, the sound of carriages, the sound of infantry, the sound of conches, the sound of drums, the sound of kettledrums, the sound of cymbals, and the sound of music would disappear.

original: Yo nu kho, āvuso, evaṁ vadeyya: ‘na dāni amusmiṁ vanasaṇḍe punadeva cīrikasaddo pātubhavissatī’ti, sammā nu kho so, āvuso, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?
analyzed: yaḥ nu kho āvuso evam vadeyya na dāni amusmin vana saṇḍe punar eva cīrika saddo pātubhavissati iti sammā nu kho saḥ āvuso vadamānaḥ vadeyya ati
translated: “If someone were to say, ‘The sound of crickets in that grove will never appear again,’ would he be speaking rightly?”

original: “No hidaṁ, āvuso”.
analyzed: na u hide āvuso
translated: “No, friend.

original: “Ṭhānañhetaṁ, āvuso, vijjati, yaṁ so rājā vā rājamahāmatto vā tamhā vanasaṇḍā pakkameyya, atha punadeva cīrikasaddo pātubhaveyyāti.
analyzed: ṭhānan ha itas āvuso vijjati yam saḥ rājā vā rāja mahāmattaḥ vā tamhā vana saṇḍā pakkameyya atha punar eva cīrika saddo pātubhaveyya ati
translated: Because it’s possible that the king or a king’s minister would leave that grove, and then the sound of crickets would appear again.

original: Evamevaṁ kho, āvuso, idhekacco puggalo sabbanimittānaṁ amanasikārā animittaṁ cetosamādhiṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: evam evam kho āvuso idha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ sabba nimittānam amanasikārā animittam cetosamādhim upasampajja viharati
translated: In the same way, friend, there is the case where a certain person, with the abandoning of pleasure & pain—as with the earlier disappearance of elation & distress—enters & remains in the fourth jhāna: purity of equanimity & mindfulness, neither pleasure nor pain.

original: So ‘lābhimhi animittassa cetosamādhissā’ti saṁsaṭṭho viharati bhikkhūhi bhikkhunīhi upāsakehi upāsikāhi raññā rājamahāmattehi titthiyehi titthiyasāvakehi.
analyzed: saḥ lābhimhi animittassa cetosamādhissa ati sasaṭṭhaḥ viharati bhikkhūhi bhikkhunīhi upāsakehi upāsikāhi raññā rāja mahāmattehi titthiyehi titthiya sāvakehi
translated: He thinks, ‘I obtain the fourth jhāna.’ He dwells in close association with bhikkhus & bhikkhunis, with male & female lay followers, with kings & their ministers, with teachers of other paths & their disciples.

original: Tassa saṁsaṭṭhassa vissatthassa pākatassa bhassamanuyuttassa viharato rāgo cittaṁ anuddhaṁseti.
analyzed: tassa sa saṭṭhassa vissatthassa pākatassa bhassa manuyuttassa viharataḥ rāgaḥ cittam anuddhaseti
translated: As he lives in association, open and frank, devoted to the teaching of the Teacher, lust invades his mind.

original: So rāgānuddhaṁsitena cittena sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattatī”ti.
analyzed: so rāga an uddhasitena cittena sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati iti
translated: With his mind invaded by lust, he abandons the training and returns to the lower life.”

original: Atha kho āyasmā citto hatthisāriputto aparena samayena sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: atha kho āyasmā cittaḥ hatthi sāriputtaḥ aparena samayena sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya āvattati
translated: Then, after some time, Citta Hatthisariputta abandoned the training and returned to the lower life.

original: Atha kho cittassa hatthisāriputtassa sahāyakā bhikkhū yenāyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṁ mahākoṭṭhikaṁ etadavocuṁ:
analyzed: atha kho cittassa hatthisāriputtassa sahāyakāḥ bhikkhū yena āyasmā mahākoṭṭhikaḥ tena upasaṅkamisu upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantam mahākoṭṭhikam etat avocu
translated: Then the monks who were Citta’s friends went to the venerable Maha Kotthita and said to him,

original: “kiṁ nu kho āyasmatā mahākoṭṭhikena citto hatthisāriputto cetasā ceto paricca vidito:
analyzed: kim nu kho āyasmatā mahākoṭṭhikena cittaḥ hatthisāriputto cetasā cetaḥ paricca vidito
translated: “Did you, Venerable Kotthita, read the mind of Citta Hatthisariputta with your mind,

original: ‘imāsañca imāsañca vihārasamāpattīnaṁ citto hatthisāriputto lābhī, atha ca pana sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissatī’ti;
analyzed: imāsam ca imāsam ca vihāra samāpattīnam cittaḥ hatthisāriputto lābhī atha ca pana sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattissati iti
translated: knowing, ‘Citta Hatthisariputta is capable of attaining the attainments of the first jhana, and so on up to: the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling, and yet he will abandon the training and return to the lower life’?🔽Or did deities inform you of this matter,

original: udāhu devatā etamatthaṁ ārocesuṁ:
analyzed: ud āhu devatāḥ etam attham
translated: saying,

original: ‘citto, bhante, hatthisāriputto imāsañca imāsañca vihārasamāpattīnaṁ lābhī, atha ca pana sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissatī’”ti?
analyzed: cittaḥ bhante hatthisāriputto imāsam ca imāsam ca vihāra samāpattīnam lābhī atha ca pana sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattissati iti
translated: ‘Venerable Sir, Citta Hatthisariputta has attained these and those deep attainments, and yet he’s going to give up the training and return to the lower life.’”

original: “Cetasā ceto paricca vidito me, āvuso:🔽‘citto hatthisāriputto imāsañca imāsañca vihārasamāpattīnaṁ lābhī, atha ca pana sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissatī’ti.
analyzed: cetasā cetaḥ paricca viditaḥ me āvuso  cittaḥ hatthisāriputto imāsam ca imāsam ca vihāra samāpattīnam lābhī atha ca pana sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattissati iti
translated: “I know Citta’s mind,🔽and so do the gods.

original: Devatāpi me etamatthaṁ ārocesuṁ:
analyzed: devatā api me etam attham ārocesu
translated: And the gods have told me too.

original: ‘citto, bhante, hatthisāriputto imāsañca imāsañca vihārasamāpattīnaṁ lābhī, atha ca pana sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissatī’”ti.
analyzed: cittaḥ bhante hatthisāriputto imāsam ca imāsam ca vihāra samāpattīnam lābhī atha ca pana sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattissati iti
translated: ‘Venerable Sir, Citta Hatthisariputta has attained these and those deep attainments, and yet he’s going to give up the training and return to the lower life.’”

original: Atha kho cittassa hatthisāriputtassa sahāyakā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu;
analyzed: atha kho cittassa hatthisāriputtassa sahāyakāḥ bhikkhū yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamisu
translated: Then Citta’s monk friends went to the Buddha,🔽bowed, sat down,

original: upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Ekamantaṁ nisinnā kho🔽te bhikkhū bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
analyzed: upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam ekamantam nisīdisu ekamantam nisinnā kho 🔽te bhikkhū bhagavantam etat avocuḥ
translated: and told him what had happened.

original: “citto, bhante, hatthisāriputto imāsañca imāsañca vihārasamāpattīnaṁ lābhī, atha ca pana sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattatī”ti.
analyzed: cittaḥ bhante hatthisāriputto imāsam ca imāsam ca vihāra samāpattīnam lābhī atha ca pana sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya āvattati iti
translated: “Venerable Sir, Citta Hatthisariputta has attained these and other absorptions, and yet he’s given up the training and returned to the lower life.”

original: “Na, bhikkhave, citto ciraṁ sarissati nekkhammassā”ti.🔽Atha kho citto hatthisāriputto nacirasseva kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbaji.
analyzed: na bhikkhave cittaḥ ciram sarissati nekkhammassa ati  atha kho cittaḥ hatthi sāriputtaḥ nacirassa iva kesa massum ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasma anagāriyam pabbaji
translated: “He won’t remember the pleasures of renunciation for long.”
