original: Atha kho āyasmā citto hatthisāriputto eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto🔽nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ
analyzed: atha kho āyasmā cittaḥ hatthi sāriputto ekaḥ vūpakaṭṭhaḥ appamattaḥ ātāpī pahitattaḥ viharantaḥ  kula puttā sammat eva agārasmai anagāriyam pabbajanti tad anuttara brahmacariya pariyosāna
translated: Soon after his ordination, Citta Hatthisariputta, dwelling alone, withdrawn, heedful, ardent, and resolute,

original: diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
analyzed: diṭṭhe iva dhamme sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi
translated: soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual life for which people from good families rightly go forth from the household life into homelessness.

original: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
analyzed: vusitam brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati
translated: He directly knew: “Birth is ended, the spiritual life fulfilled, the job done. There is nothing further for this world.”

original: Aññataro ca panāyasmā citto hatthisāriputto arahataṁ ahosīti.🔽Chaṭṭhaṁ.🔽Aṅguttara Nikāya 6.61🔽6. Mahāvagga
analyzed: aññataro ca pana āyasmā citto hatthisāriputto arahatam ahosi iti  chaṭṭha  aṅguttara nikāya  mahāvagga
translated: Venerable Citta Hatthisariputta became another one of the arahants.

original: Majjhesutta🔽Evaṁ me sutaṁ—🔽ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā bārāṇasiyaṁ viharati isipatane migadāye.🔽Tena kho pana samayena sambahulānaṁ therānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantānaṁ maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānaṁ sannipatitānaṁ ayamantarākathā udapādi:🔽“vuttamidaṁ, āvuso, bhagavatā pārāyane metteyyapañhe:🔽‘Yo ubhonte viditvāna,🔽majjhe mantā na lippati;🔽Taṁ brūmi mahāpurisoti,🔽sodha sibbini maccagā’”ti.🔽“Katamo nu kho, āvuso, eko anto, katamo dutiyo anto, kiṁ majjhe, kā sibbinī”ti?🔽Evaṁ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu there bhikkhū etadavoca:
analyzed: majjhesutta 🔽evam me suta 🔽ekam samayam bhagavā bārāṇasiyam viharati isipatane migadāye 🔽tena kho pana samayena sambahulānam therānam bhikkhūnam pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkantānam maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānam sannipatitānam ayam antarākathā udapādi 🔽vuttam idam āvuso bhagavatā pārāyane metteyya pañhe 🔽yaḥ ubhonte viditvāna 🔽majjhe mantā na lippati 🔽tam brūmi mahā purisaḥ iti 🔽sodha sibbini maccagāti 🔽katamaḥ nu kho āvuso ekaḥ antaḥ katamaḥ dutiyaḥ antaḥ kim majjhe kā sibbinī iti 🔽evam vutte aññataraḥ bhikkhu there bhikkhū etat avoca
translated: Venerable Citta Hatthisariputta became another one of the perfected ones.

original: “phasso kho, āvuso, eko anto, phassasamudayo dutiyo anto, phassanirodho majjhe, taṇhā sibbinī;
analyzed: phassaḥ kho āvuso ekaḥ antaḥ phassa samudayaḥ dutiyaḥ antaḥ phassa nirodho majjhe taṇhā sibbinī
translated: “Contact is one end, friends, the origin of contact is the second end, the cessation of contact is in the middle, and craving is the seamstress.

original: taṇhā hi naṁ sibbati tassa tasseva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā.
analyzed: taṇhā hi nam sibbati tassa tassa iva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā
translated: For craving sews one to the production of this or that state of existence.🔽To this extent there is what is subject to birth, what is subject to aging, what is subject to death, what is subject to sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair.

original: Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhu abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānāti, pariññeyyaṁ parijānāti, abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānanto pariññeyyaṁ parijānanto diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hotī”ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā kho āvuso bhikkhu abhiññeyyam abhijānāti pariññeyyam parijānāti abhiññeyyam abhijānantaḥ pariññeyyam parijānantaḥ diṭṭhe iva dhamme dukkhassa anta karaḥ hoti iti
translated: “When a bhikkhu directly knows and fully understands on the basis of this very body—which is subject to birth, subject to aging, subject to sickness, subject to death, subject to sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair—that ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self,’ then he is called a bhikkhu who has been shaken by the supreme shaking.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu there bhikkhū etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte aññataraḥ bhikkhu there bhikkhū etat avoca
translated: When this was said, a certain bhikkhu said to the venerable elder bhikkhus:

original: “atītaṁ kho, āvuso, eko anto, anāgataṁ dutiyo anto, paccuppannaṁ majjhe, taṇhā sibbinī;
analyzed: atītam kho āvuso ekaḥ antaḥ anāgatam dutiyaḥ antaḥ paccuppannam majjhe taṇhā sibbinī
translated: “The past, friends, is one end, the future is a second end, and the present is in the middle. Craving is the seamstress.

original: taṇhā hi naṁ sibbati tassa tasseva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā.
analyzed: taṇhā hi nam sibbati tassa tassa iva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā
translated: For craving sews one to the production of this or that state of existence.🔽To this extent there is what is subject to birth, what is subject to aging, what is subject to death, what is subject to sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair.

original: Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhu abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānāti, pariññeyyaṁ parijānāti, abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānanto, pariññeyyaṁ parijānanto diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hotī”ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā kho āvuso bhikkhu abhiññeyyam abhijānāti pariññeyyam parijānāti abhiññeyyam abhijānantaḥ pariññeyyam parijānantaḥ diṭṭhe iva dhamme dukkhassa anta karaḥ hoti iti
translated: “When a bhikkhu directly knows and fully understands on the basis of this very body—which is subject to birth, subject to aging, subject to sickness, subject to death, subject to sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair—that ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self,’ then he is called a bhikkhu who has been shaken by the supreme shaking.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu there bhikkhū etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte aññataraḥ bhikkhu there bhikkhū etat avoca
translated: When this was said, a certain bhikkhu addressed the elder bhikkhus thus:

original: “sukhā, āvuso, vedanā eko anto, dukkhā vedanā dutiyo anto, adukkhamasukhā vedanā majjhe, taṇhā sibbinī;
analyzed: sukhā āvuso vedanā ekaḥ antaḥ dukkhā vedanā dutiyaḥ antaḥ adukkhamasukhā vedanā majjhe taṇhā sibbinī
translated: “Pleasant feeling, friends, is one extreme, painful feeling is the second extreme, neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling is in the middle; craving is the measurer;

original: taṇhā hi naṁ sibbati tassa tasseva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā.🔽Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhu abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānāti, pariññeyyaṁ parijānāti, abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānanto, pariññeyyaṁ parijānanto diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hotī”ti.
analyzed: taṇhā hi nam sibbati tassa tassa iva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā  ettāvatā kho āvuso bhikkhu abhiññeyyam abhijānāti pariññeyyam parijānāti abhiññeyyam abhijānantaḥ pariññeyyam parijānantaḥ diṭṭhe iva dhamme dukkhassa anta karaḥ hoti iti
translated: for craving measures out: ‘Let me be such and such, let me be thus and thus.’🔽To this extent there is what is born, what ages, what dies, what passes away and what arises: to this extent there is the lokaprajñapti, the designation of the world, the designation of beings, the designation of the person.

original: Evaṁ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu there bhikkhū etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte aññataraḥ bhikkhu there bhikkhū etat avoca
translated: “To this extent, friend, a bhikkhu who is a bahussuta, a great man of vision, a great man of learning, might speak of what he has seen, heard, and sensed.🔽“To this extent, friend, a bhikkhu who is a bahussuta, a great man of vision, a great man of learning, might speak of what he has seen, heard, and sensed.

original: “nāmaṁ kho, āvuso, eko anto, rūpaṁ dutiyo anto, viññāṇaṁ majjhe, taṇhā sibbinī;🔽taṇhā hi naṁ sibbati tassa tasseva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā.
analyzed: nāmam kho āvuso ekaḥ antaḥ rūpam dutiyaḥ antaḥ viññāṇam majjhe taṇhā sibbinī 🔽taṇhā hi nam sibbati tassa tassa iva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā
translated: “Name, friends, is one extreme, form is the second extreme, consciousness is in the middle; craving is the measurer;

original: Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhu abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānāti, pariññeyyaṁ parijānāti, abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānanto pariññeyyaṁ parijānanto diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hotī”ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā kho āvuso bhikkhu abhiññeyyam abhijānāti pariññeyyam parijānāti abhiññeyyam abhijānantaḥ pariññeyyam parijānantaḥ diṭṭhe iva dhamme dukkhassa anta karaḥ hoti iti
translated: To this extent, friend, a bhikkhu is one who knows in the sense of experiencing ; to this extent he is one who has fully understood in the sense of penetrating . In this way, a bhikkhu who knows in the sense of experiencing and who has fully understood in the sense of penetrating can put an end to suffering in this very life.”

original: Evaṁ vutte aññataro bhikkhu there bhikkhū etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte aññataraḥ bhikkhu there bhikkhū etat avoca
translated: When this was said, one bhikkhu said to the elder bhikkhus:

original: “cha kho, āvuso, ajjhattikāni āyatanāni eko anto, cha bāhirāni āyatanāni dutiyo anto, viññāṇaṁ majjhe, taṇhā sibbinī;
analyzed: cha kho āvuso ajjhattikāni āyatanāni ekaḥ antaḥ cha bāhirāni āyatanāni dutiyaḥ antaḥ viññāṇam majjhe taṇhā sibbinī
translated: “Friends, the six internal bases are one end, the six external bases are the other end, and consciousness is in the middle, with craving running through the middle.

original: taṇhā hi naṁ sibbati tassa tasseva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā.
analyzed: taṇhā hi nam sibbati tassa tassa iva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā
translated: Craving binds a person to the production of this or that state of existence.

original: Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhu abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānāti, pariññeyyaṁ parijānāti, abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānanto pariññeyyaṁ parijānanto diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hotī”ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā kho āvuso bhikkhu abhiññeyyam abhijānāti pariññeyyam parijānāti abhiññeyyam abhijānantaḥ pariññeyyam parijānantaḥ diṭṭhe iva dhamme dukkhassa anta karaḥ hoti iti
translated: To this extent, friend, a bhikkhu is one who knows in the sense of experiencing ; to this extent he is one who has fully understood in the sense of penetrating . In this way, a bhikkhu who knows in the sense of experiencing and who has fully understood in the sense of penetrating can put an end to suffering in this very life.”

original: Evaṁ vutte aññataro bhikkhu there bhikkhū etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte aññataraḥ bhikkhu there bhikkhū etat avoca
translated: When this was said, one bhikkhu said to the elder bhikkhus:

original: “sakkāyo kho, āvuso, eko anto, sakkāyasamudayo dutiyo anto, sakkāyanirodho majjhe, taṇhā sibbinī;
analyzed: sa kāyaḥ kho āvuso ekaḥ antaḥ sakkāya samudayaḥ dutiyaḥ antaḥ sakkāya nirodho majjhe taṇhā sibbinī
translated: ‘The self is one end, the origin of the self is the other end, the cessation of the self is in the middle, and craving is the seamstress.

original: taṇhā hi naṁ sibbati tassa tasseva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā.
analyzed: taṇhā hi nam sibbati tassa tassa iva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā
translated: For craving sews one to the production of this or that state of existence.

original: Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhu abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānāti, pariññeyyaṁ parijānāti, abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānanto pariññeyyaṁ parijānanto diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hotī”ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā kho āvuso bhikkhu abhiññeyyam abhijānāti pariññeyyam parijānāti abhiññeyyam abhijānantaḥ pariññeyyam parijānantaḥ diṭṭhe iva dhamme dukkhassa anta karaḥ hoti iti
translated: To this extent there is what is to be directly known. Having directly known this, the monk directly knows what is to be directly known. To this extent there is what is to be fully understood. Having fully understood this, the monk fully understands what is to be fully understood. To this extent there is what is to be developed. Having developed this, the monk develops what is to be developed. To this extent there is what is to be realized. Having realized this, the monk realizes what is to be realized.’

original: Evaṁ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu there bhikkhū etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte aññataraḥ bhikkhu there bhikkhū etat avoca
translated: When this was said, a certain bhikkhu said to the elder bhikkhus:

original: “byākataṁ kho, āvuso, amhehi sabbeheva yathāsakaṁ paṭibhānaṁ.🔽Āyāmāvuso, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamissāma; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato etamatthaṁ ārocessāma.
analyzed: byākatam kho āvuso amhehi sabbehi iva yathāsakam paṭibhāna  āyāma āvuso yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamissāma upasaṅkamitvā bhagavataḥ etam attham ārocessāma
translated: “Friends, we have all spoken according to our own inspiration.🔽Let us now go to the Blessed One and report this matter to him.

original: Yathā no bhagavā byākarissati tathā naṁ dhāressāmā”ti.
analyzed: yathā naḥ bhagavā byākarissati tathā nam dhāressāma ati
translated: He will take it upon himself to resolve this matter.”

original: “Evamāvuso”ti kho therā bhikkhū tassa bhikkhuno paccassosuṁ.
analyzed: evam āvuso ti kho therāḥ bhikkhū tassa bhikkhuno
translated: “Yes, friend,” the elder bhikkhus replied.

original: Atha kho therā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu.🔽Ekamantaṁ nisinnā kho therā bhikkhū yāvatako ahosi sabbeheva saddhiṁ kathāsallāpo, taṁ sabbaṁ bhagavato ārocesuṁ.
analyzed: atha kho therāḥ bhikkhū yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamisu upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdisu  ekamantam nisinnāḥ kho therāḥ bhikkhū yāvatakaḥ ahosi sabbeha iva saddhim kathā sallāpo tam sabbam bhagavataḥ ārocesu
translated: and told him what had happened.

original: “Kassa nu kho, bhante, subhāsitan”ti?
analyzed: kassa nu kho bhante su bhāsitanti
translated: “Venerables, who spoke well?”

original: “Sabbesaṁ vo, bhikkhave, subhāsitaṁ pariyāyena, api ca yaṁ mayā sandhāya bhāsitaṁ pārāyane metteyyapañhe:
analyzed: sabbesam vaḥ bhikkhave su bhāsitam pariyāyena api ca yam mayā sandhāya bhāsitam pārāyane metteyya pañhe
translated: “Monks, all of you spoke well in a way. But I spoke with reference to the verses in the Pārāyanavagga called ‘The Questions of Metteyya’:

original: ‘Yo ubhonte viditvāna,
analyzed: yaḥ ubhonte viditvāna
translated: ‘One who understands both ends

original: majjhe mantā na lippati;
analyzed: majjhe mantā na lippati
translated: and the middle of the mind,

original: Taṁ brūmi mahāpurisoti,
analyzed: tam brūmi mahā purisaḥ iti
translated: I call a great man,

original: sodha sibbinimaccagā’ti.
analyzed: sodha sip bini macca gāti
translated: a pure one, a polished gem.’

original: Taṁ suṇātha, sādhukaṁ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
analyzed: tam suṇātha sādhukam manasi karotha bhāsissāmi iti
translated: Listen and pay careful attention, I will speak.”

original: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho therā bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
analyzed: eva bhante iti kho therāḥ bhikkhū bhagavato
translated: “Yes, Venerable Sir,” the senior monks replied.

original: Bhagavā etadavoca:
analyzed: bhagavān etat avoca
translated: The Buddha said this:

original: “phasso kho, bhikkhave, eko anto, phassasamudayo dutiyo anto, phassanirodho majjhe, taṇhā sibbinī;
analyzed: phassaḥ kho bhikkhave ekaḥ antaḥ phassa samudayaḥ dutiyaḥ antaḥ phassa nirodho majjhe taṇhā sibbinī
translated: “Contact, monks, is one end. The origin of contact is the second end. The cessation of contact is in the middle. Craving is the seamstress.

original: taṇhā hi naṁ sibbati tassa tasseva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā.
analyzed: taṇhā hi nam sibbati tassa tassa iva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā
translated: Craving afflicts him for the arising of that and that kind of renewed existence.

original: Ettāvatā kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānāti, pariññeyyaṁ parijānāti, abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānanto pariññeyyaṁ parijānanto diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hotī”ti.🔽Sattamaṁ.🔽Aṅguttara Nikāya 6.62
analyzed: ettāvatā kho bhikkhave bhikkhu abhiññeyyam abhijānāti pariññeyyam parijānāti abhiññeyyam abhijānantaḥ pariññeyyam parijānantaḥ diṭṭhe iva dhamme dukkhassa anta karaḥ hoti iti  sattama  aṅguttara nikāya
translated: To this extent, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu is one who directly knows what should be directly known; he is one who fully understands what should be fully understood; and he is one who, in regard to nibbana, the ultimate good, has himself attained it, is himself fully released.🔽Thus have I heard.🔽Thus have I heard.

original: 6. Mahāvagga
analyzed: mahāvagga
translated: The Book of the Aggregates

original: Purisindriyañāṇasutta
analyzed: purisa indriya ñāṇa sutta
translated: The Knowledge of the Male Faculty

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā kosalesu cārikaṁ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ yena daṇḍakappakaṁ nāma kosalānaṁ nigamo tadavasari.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā kosalesu cārikam caramānaḥ mahatā bhikkhu saṅghena saddhim yena daṇḍakappakam nāma kosalānam nigamaḥ tat avasari
translated: On one occasion the Blessed One was wandering in the Kosalan country with a large Sangha of bhikkhus, and eventually he arrived at a Kosalan town named Dantapura.

original: Atha kho bhagavā maggā okkamma aññatarasmiṁ rukkhamūle paññatte āsane nisīdi.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā maggā okkamma aññatarasmim rukkha mūle paññatte āsane nisīdi
translated: Then the Blessed One left the road, went to the foot of a tree, and sat down on the seat prepared for him.

original: Te ca bhikkhū daṇḍakappakaṁ pavisiṁsu āvasathaṁ pariyesituṁ.
analyzed: te ca bhikkhū daṇḍakappakam pavisisu āvasatham pariyesitu
translated: The bhikkhus entered Dantapura for alms.

original: Atha kho āyasmā ānando sambahulehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṁ yena aciravatī nadī tenupasaṅkami gattāni parisiñcituṁ.
analyzed: atha kho āyasmai ānandaḥ sambahulehi bhikkhūhi saddhim yena aciravatī nadī tena upasaṅkami gattāni parisiñcitu
translated: Then the venerable Ananda went with a number of bhikkhus to the Aciravatl River to bathe.

original: Aciravatiyā nadiyā gattāni parisiñcitvā paccuttaritvā ekacīvaro aṭṭhāsi gattāni pubbāpayamāno.🔽Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:🔽“kiṁ nu kho, āvuso ānanda, sabbaṁ cetaso samannāharitvā nu kho devadatto bhagavatā byākato:
analyzed: aciravatiyāḥ nadiyāḥ gattāni parisiñcitvā paccuttaritvā eka cīvaraḥ aṭṭhāsi gattāni pubbāpayamāno  atha kho aññataraḥ bhikkhu yena āyasman ānandaḥ tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantam ānandam etat avoca  kim nu kho āvuso ānanda sabbam cetasaḥ samannāharitvā nu kho devadattaḥ bhagavatā byākataḥ
translated: He bathed in the Aciravatī River, came out, and stood in one robe drying himself.

original: ‘āpāyiko devadatto nerayiko kappaṭṭho atekiccho’ti, udāhu kenacideva pariyāyenāti?
analyzed: āpāyikaḥ devadattaḥ nerayikaḥ kappaṭṭhaḥ atekiccho ti udāhu kenacid eva pariyāyena ati
translated: Then a certain monk went to Ven. Ānanda and, on arrival, said to him, “Was it with full awareness, friend Ānanda, that the Blessed One declared Devadatta to be ‘irreversibly destined to an eon-long stay in hell,’ or was it with some underlying intention?

original: Evaṁ kho panetaṁ, āvuso, bhagavatā byākatan”ti.
analyzed: evam khalu pana itas āvusaḥ bhagavatā byākatanti
translated: “It was with full awareness, friend, that the Blessed One declared Devadatta to be ‘irreversibly destined to an eon-long stay in hell.’

original: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha khalu āyasmai ānandaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ khalu āyasmai ānandaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: “Then Ven. Ānanda went to the Blessed One and, on arrival, having bowed down to him, sat to one side. As he was sitting there, he said to the Blessed One,

original: “idhāhaṁ, bhante, sambahulehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṁ yena aciravatī nadī tenupasaṅkamiṁ gattāni parisiñcituṁ.
analyzed: idha āha bhante sambahulehi bhikkhūhi saddhim yena aciravatī nadī tena upasaṅkamim gattāni parisiñcitu
translated: “Just now, lord, after the meal, on returning from my alms round, I went to the Aciravatī River to bathe.

original: Aciravatiyā nadiyā gattāni parisiñcitvā paccuttaritvā ekacīvaro aṭṭhāsiṁ gattāni pubbāpayamāno.
analyzed: aciravatiyāḥ nadiyāḥ gattāni parisiñcitvā paccuttaritvā eka cīvaraḥ aṭṭhāsim gattāni pubbāpayamāno
translated: I bathed in the Aciravatī River, came out, and stood in one robe drying myself.

original: Atha kho, bhante, aññataro bhikkhu yenāhaṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṁ etadavoca:🔽‘kiṁ nu kho, āvuso ānanda, sabbaṁ cetaso samannāharitvā nu kho devadatto bhagavatā byākato—
analyzed: atha kho bhante aññataraḥ bhikkhu yena aham tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā mama etat avoca  kim nu kho āvuso ānanda sabbam cetasaḥ samannāharitvā nu kho devadattaḥ bhagavatā byākataḥ
translated: Then a monk came to me and asked,

original: āpāyiko devadatto nerayiko kappaṭṭho atekicchoti, udāhu kenacideva pariyāyenā’ti?
analyzed: āpāyikaḥ devadattaḥ nerayikaḥ kappaṭṭhaḥ atekiccho ti udāhu kenacid eva pariyāyena ati
translated: ‘Is it the case, Ānanda, that the Buddha has declared Devadatta to be irredeemably destined to an eon in hell, having fallen under the control of others, having been rejected by the Buddha, and that he has done so without taking anything into account?’

original: Evaṁ vutte, ahaṁ, bhante, taṁ bhikkhuṁ etadavocaṁ:
analyzed: evam vutte aha bhante tam bhikkhum etat avoca
translated: When he had finished, I said to him,

original: ‘evaṁ kho panetaṁ, āvuso, bhagavatā byākatan’”ti.
analyzed: evam khalu pana itas āvusaḥ bhagavatā byākatanti
translated: ‘It’s just as the Buddha has declared.’”

original: “So vā kho, ānanda, bhikkhu navo bhavissati acirapabbajito, thero vā pana bālo abyatto.
analyzed: so vā kho ānanda bhikkhu navaḥ bhavissati acira pabbajitaḥ theraḥ vā pana bālaḥ abyatto
translated: “Ānanda, that monk must be new, not long gone forth. Or else he’s an ignorant and incompetent senior monk.

original: Kathañhi nāma yaṁ mayā ekaṁsena byākataṁ tattha dvejjhaṁ āpajjissati.
analyzed: katham hi nāma yam mayā ekasena byākatam tattha dvejjham āpajjissati
translated: How can he doubt what I have declared with a definite meaning?

original: Nāhaṁ, ānanda, aññaṁ ekapuggalampi samanupassāmi, yo evaṁ mayā sabbaṁ cetaso samannāharitvā byākato, yathayidaṁ devadatto.
analyzed: na aha ānanda aññam eka puggalam pi samanupassāmi yaḥ evam mayā sabbam cetasaḥ samannāharitvā byākataḥ devadatto
translated: I do not see even one other person who, when I have spoken to them in this way, has been so quick to understand as Devadatta.

original: Yāvakīvañcāhaṁ, ānanda, devadattassa vālaggakoṭinittudanamattampi sukkadhammaṁ addasaṁ;
analyzed: ānanda devadattassa sukka dhammam addasa
translated: As long as I saw even a hair’s tip of a good quality in Devadatta,

original: neva tāvāhaṁ devadattaṁ byākāsiṁ:
analyzed: na iva tāva aham devadattam
translated: I did not declare him to be:

original: ‘āpāyiko devadatto nerayiko kappaṭṭho atekiccho’ti.
analyzed: āpāyikaḥ devadattaḥ nerayikaḥ kappaṭṭhaḥ atekiccho ti
translated: ‘Devadatta is irredeemably destined to an eon in hell.’

original: Yato ca kho ahaṁ, ānanda, devadattassa vālaggakoṭinittudanamattampi sukkadhammaṁ na addasaṁ;
analyzed: yatas ca kho aha ānanda devadattassa vā ālagga koṭi nittudana mattam pi sukka dhammam na addasa
translated: But when I no longer saw even a hair’s tip of a good quality in Devadatta,

original: athāhaṁ devadattaṁ byākāsiṁ:
analyzed: atha aham devadattam
translated: I declared him to be:

original: ‘āpāyiko devadatto nerayiko kappaṭṭho atekiccho’ti.🔽Seyyathāpi, ānanda, gūthakūpo sādhikaporiso pūro gūthassa samatittiko.
analyzed: āpāyikaḥ devadattaḥ nerayikaḥ kappaṭṭhaḥ atekiccho ti  seyyathā api ānanda gūtha kūpaḥ sādhika porisaḥ pūraḥ gūthassa sama tittikaḥ
translated: ‘Devadatta is irredeemably destined to an eon in hell.’

original: Tatra puriso sasīsako nimuggo assa.
analyzed: tatra purisaḥ sa sīsakaḥ nimuggo assa
translated: Suppose there were a cesspit deeper than a man’s height, full of feces, its surface covered by a thin crust.

original: Tassa kocideva puriso uppajjeyya atthakāmo hitakāmo yogakkhemakāmo tamhā gūthakūpā uddharitukāmo.
analyzed: tassa kocid eva purisaḥ uppajjeyya attha kāmaḥ hita kāmaḥ yogakkhema kāmaḥ tamhā gūthakūpā uddharitu kāmo
translated: And a man were to appear who wanted to protect, benefit, and make him happy.🔽He would want to pull him out of the cesspit.

original: So taṁ gūthakūpaṁ samantānuparigacchanto neva passeyya tassa purisassa vālaggakoṭinittudanamattampi gūthena amakkhitaṁ, yattha taṁ gahetvā uddhareyya.
analyzed: saḥ tam gūthakūpam samantā anuparigacchantaḥ na iva passeyya tassa purisassa vā ālagga koṭi nittudana mattam pi gūthena amakkhita yattha tam gahetvā uddhareyya
translated: As he went around the cesspit, he would not see even a hair tip’s worth of the man that was not covered with excrement.

original: Evamevaṁ kho ahaṁ, ānanda, yato devadattassa vālaggakoṭinittudanamattampi sukkadhammaṁ na addasaṁ;
analyzed: evam evam kho aha ānanda yatas devadattassa vā ālagga koṭi nittudana mattam pi sukka dhammam na addasa
translated: In the same way, Ānanda, I did not see even a hair tip’s worth of a good quality in Devadatta.

original: athāhaṁ devadattaṁ byākāsiṁ:
analyzed: atha aham devadattam
translated: I then declared him:

original: ‘āpāyiko devadatto nerayiko kappaṭṭho atekiccho’ti.
analyzed: āpāyikaḥ devadattaḥ nerayikaḥ kappaṭṭhaḥ atekiccho ti
translated: ‘Devadatta is destined for the downfall, for the lower worlds, for staying there for an eon, staying there for a long time, with no possibility of a speedy release.’

translated: “Here, Ānanda, I see a certain person with his mind affected by lust, hate, and delusion, and I understand how his unwholesome qualities will lead to his harm and suffering for a long time.🔽But then, at another time, I see that his unwholesome qualities have disappeared and wholesome qualities have appeared in their place.

original: Nete kāmā yāni citrāni loke;🔽Saṅkapparāgo purisassa kāmo,🔽Tiṭṭhanti citrāni tatheva loke;

translated: They are called sensual pleasures in the world,🔽But these are not sensual pleasures.🔽They are called sensual pleasures in the world,🔽But these remain just as they are.

original: Athettha dhīrā vinayanti chandanti.
analyzed: atha itthā dhīrāḥ vinayanti chandanti
translated: The wise one here controls desire.

original: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, kāmānaṁ nidānasambhavo?
analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhave kāmānam nidāna sambhavaḥ
translated: “And what, monks, is the source and origin of sensual pleasures?

original: Phasso, bhikkhave, kāmānaṁ nidānasambhavo.
analyzed: phassaḥ bhikkhave kāmānam nidāna sambhavaḥ
translated: Contact is the source and origin of sensual pleasures.

original: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, kāmānaṁ vemattatā?
analyzed: katamā ca bhikkhave kāmānam vematta tā
translated: “And what, monks, is the variety of sensual pleasures?

original: Añño, bhikkhave, kāmo rūpesu, añño kāmo saddesu, añño kāmo gandhesu, añño kāmo rasesu, añño kāmo phoṭṭhabbesu.
analyzed: aññaḥ bhikkhave kāmaḥ rūpesu aññaḥ kāmaḥ saddesu aññaḥ kāmaḥ gandhesu aññaḥ kāmaḥ rasesu aññaḥ kāmaḥ phoṭṭhabbesu
translated: Sensual pleasure in regard to forms is one thing, sensual pleasure in regard to sounds is another, sensual pleasure in regard to smells is another, sensual pleasure in regard to tastes is another, sensual pleasure in regard to touches is another.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, kāmānaṁ vemattatā.
analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave kāmānam vematta tā
translated: This is called the variety of sensual pleasures.

original: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, kāmānaṁ vipāko?
analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhave kāmānam vipākaḥ
translated: “And what, monks, is the result of sensual pleasures?

original: Yaṁ kho, bhikkhave, kāmayamāno tajjaṁ tajjaṁ attabhāvaṁ abhinibbatteti puññabhāgiyaṁ vā apuññabhāgiyaṁ vā, ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, kāmānaṁ vipāko.
analyzed: yam kho bhikkhave kāmayamānaḥ tajjam tajjam atta bhāvam abhinibbatteti puññabhāgiyam vā apuññabhāgiyam vā ayam vuccati bhikkhave kāmānam vipākaḥ
translated: Whatever being, by being desirous, generates such and such a form of renewed existence, whether it be in the heavenly world or the human world or the animal world or the ghost world or the realm of misfortune, this is called the result of sensual pleasures.

original: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, kāmanirodho?
analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhave kāma nirodhaḥ
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, is the cessation of sensual pleasures?

original: Phassanirodho, bhikkhave, kāmanirodho.🔽Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo kāmanirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: phassa nirodhaḥ bhikkhave kāma nirodhaḥ  ayam eva ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo kāma nirodha gāminī paṭipadā
translated: The cessation of contact is the cessation of sensual pleasures.

original: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi.🔽Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṁ kāme pajānāti, evaṁ kāmānaṁ nidānasambhavaṁ🔽pajānāti, evaṁ kāmānaṁ vemattataṁ pajānāti, evaṁ kāmānaṁ vipākaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ kāmanirodhaṁ🔽pajānāti, evaṁ kāmanirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ pajānāti, so imaṁ nibbedhikaṁ brahmacariyaṁ
analyzed: sammā diṭṭhi sammā saṅkappo sammā vācā sammā kammanto sammā ājīvaḥ sammā vāyāmaḥ sammā sati sammā samādhi  yatas kho bhikkhave ariya sāvakaḥ evam kāme pajānāti evam kāmānam nidāna sambhava  pajānāti evam kāmānam vemattatam pajānāti evam kāmānam vipākam pajānāti evam kāma nirodha  pajānāti evam kāma nirodha gāminim paṭipadam pajānāti saḥ imam nibbedhikam brahmacariya
translated: The way leading to the cessation of sensual pleasures is simply this Noble Eightfold Path; that is, right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration.

original: pajānāti kāmanirodhaṁ.
analyzed: pajānāti kāma nirodha
translated: “When a noble disciple thus understands sensual pleasures, the source and origin of sensual pleasures, the diversity of sensual pleasures, the result of sensual pleasures, the cessation of sensual pleasures, and the way leading to the cessation of sensual pleasures, he entirely abandons the underlying tendency to lust, he abolishes the underlying tendency to aversion, he extirpates the underlying tendency to the view and conceit ‘I am,’ and by abandoning ignorance and arousing true knowledge he here and now makes an end of suffering.🔽“Thus, bhikkhus, this has been taught by me, this has been revealed by me.

original: Kāmā, bhikkhave, veditabbā …pe… kāmanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti,
analyzed: kāmāḥ bhikkhave veditabbā pe kāma nirodha gāminī paṭipadā veditabbā ati
translated: ‘Sensual pleasures should be understood… The way leading to the cessation of sensual pleasures should be understood.’

original: iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
analyzed: iti yam tam vuttam idam etam paṭicca vutta
translated: That is what I said, and this is why I said it.

original: Vedanā, bhikkhave, veditabbā …pe… vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti,
analyzed: vedanā bhikkhave veditabbā pe vedanā nirodha gāminī paṭipadā veditabbā ati
translated: ‘Feelings should be understood… The way leading to the cessation of feelings should be understood.’

original: iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ. Kiñcetaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ?
analyzed: iti kho pana itam vutta kiñca itam paṭicca vutta
translated: That is what I said, and this is why I said it.

original: Tisso imā, bhikkhave, vedanā—
analyzed: tissaḥ imāḥ bhikkhave vedanā
translated: There are these three kinds of feelings:

original: sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā.
analyzed: sukhā vedanā dukkhā vedanā adukkhamasukhā vedanā
translated: pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant.

original: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, vedanānaṁ nidānasambhavo?
analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhave vedanānam nidāna sambhavaḥ
translated: And what is the source and origin of feelings?

original: Phasso, bhikkhave, vedanānaṁ nidānasambhavo.
analyzed: phassaḥ bhikkhave vedanānam nidāna sambhavaḥ
translated: Contact is their source and origin.

analyzed: katamā ca bhikkhave vedanānam vematta tā  atthi bhikkhave sāmisā sukhā vedanā atthi nirāmisā sukhā vedanā atthi sāmisā  dukkhā vedanā atthi nirāmisā dukkhā vedanā atthi sāmisā adukkhamasukhā vedanā
translated: And what is the diversity of feelings?🔽There is a pleasant worldly feeling, and a pleasant spiritual feeling, a painful worldly feeling, a painful spiritual feeling, a pleasant worldly neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling,

original: atthi nirāmisā adukkhamasukhā vedanā.
analyzed: atthi nirāmisā adukkhamasukhā vedanā
translated: and a pleasant spiritual neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, vedanānaṁ vemattatā.
analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave vedanānam vematta tā
translated: This is called the diversity of feelings.

original: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, vedanānaṁ vipāko?
analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhave vedanānam vipākaḥ
translated: “And what is the result of feelings?

original: Yaṁ kho, bhikkhave, vediyamāno tajjaṁ tajjaṁ attabhāvaṁ abhinibbatteti puññabhāgiyaṁ vā apuññabhāgiyaṁ vā,
analyzed: yam kho bhikkhave vediyamānaḥ tajjam tajjam atta bhāvam abhinibbatteti puññabhāgiyam vā apuññabhāgiyam vā
translated: When one feels, one generates a corresponding kind of personality.

original: ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, vedanānaṁ vipāko.
analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave vedanānam vipākaḥ
translated: This is called the result of feelings.

original: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, vedanānirodho?
analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhave vedanā nirodhaḥ
translated: “And what is the cessation of feelings?

original: Phassanirodho, bhikkhave, vedanānirodho.🔽Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṁ—🔽sammādiṭṭhi …pe… sammāsamādhi.

translated: With the cessation of contact there is cessation of feelings.

analyzed: yatas kho bhikkhave ariya sāvakaḥ evam vedanam pajānāti evam vedanānam nidāna sambhava  pajānāti evam vedanānam vemattatam pajānāti evam vedanānam vipākam pajānāti eva
translated: The way leading to the cessation of feelings is simply this Noble Eightfold Path, that is: right view, right resolve, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right concentration.

original: vedanānirodhaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ vedanānirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ pajānāti. So imaṁ nibbedhikaṁ
analyzed: vedanā nirodham pajānāti evam vedanā nirodha gāminim paṭipadam pajānāti saḥ imam nibbedhika

analyzed: rūpa saññā sadda saññā gandha saññā rasa saññā phoṭṭhabba saññā dhamma saññā  katamaḥ ca bhikkhave saññānam nidāna sambhavaḥ

original: Vohāravepakkaṁ, bhikkhave, saññaṁ vadāmi.
analyzed: vohāravepakka bhikkhave saññam vadāmi
translated: I call perception the result of verbal kamma,

analyzed: yathā yathā nam sañjānāti tathā tathā voharati evam saññī

analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave saññānam vipāko
translated: This is called the result of perception.

analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhave saññā nirodho
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, is the cessation of perception?

analyzed: phassa nirodhaḥ bhikkhave saññā nirodhaḥ  ayam eva ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo saññā nirodha gāminī paṭipadā

analyzed: sammā diṭṭhi pe sammā samādhi  yatas kho bhikkhave ariya sāvakaḥ evam saññam pajānāti evam saññānam nidāna sambhava  pajānāti evam saññānam vemattatam pajānāti evam saññānam vipākam pajānāti eva
translated: This Noble Eightfold Path is the way leading to the cessation of perception; that is, right view … right concentration.🔽“When a noble disciple thus understands perception, its source, its diversity, its result, its cessation, and the way leading to its cessation,

analyzed: saññā nirodham pajānāti evam saññā nirodha gāminim paṭipadam pajānāti saḥ imam nibbedhika

analyzed: saññā bhikkhave veditabbā pe saññā nirodha gāminī paṭipadā veditabbā ati
translated: ‘Perception should be understood … The way leading to the cessation of perception should be understood.’

original: Iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
analyzed: iti yam tam vuttam idam etam paṭicca vutta
translated: So it was with reference to this that it was said: ‘The outcome and development of perception should be understood … The way leading to the cessation of perception should be understood.’

original: Āsavā, bhikkhave, veditabbā …pe… āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā veditabbāti,
analyzed: āsavā bhikkhave veditabbā pe āsava nirodha gāminī paṭipadā veditabbā ati
translated: ‘“The taints should be understood … The way leading to the cessation of the taints should be understood.’

original: iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ. Kiñcetaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ?
analyzed: iti kho pana itam vutta kiñca itam paṭicca vutta
translated: So it was said. And with reference to what was it said?

original: Tayome, bhikkhave, āsavā—
analyzed: tayo me bhikkhave āsavā
translated: There are these three taints:

original: kāmāsavo, bhavāsavo, avijjāsavo.
analyzed: kāma āsavaḥ bhava āsavaḥ avijja āsavaḥ
translated: the taint of sensuality, the taint of existence, and the taint of ignorance.

original: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, āsavānaṁ nidānasambhavo?
analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhave āsavānam nidāna sambhavaḥ
translated: And what is the source and origin of the taints?

original: Avijjā, bhikkhave, āsavānaṁ nidānasambhavo.
analyzed: avijjā bhikkhave āsavānam nidāna sambhavaḥ
translated: Ignorance is their source and origin.

original: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, āsavānaṁ vemattatā?
analyzed: katamā ca bhikkhave āsavānam vematta tā
translated: And what is the diversity of the taints?

original: Atthi, bhikkhave, āsavā nirayagamanīyā, atthi āsavā tiracchānayonigamanīyā, atthi āsavā pettivisayagamanīyā, atthi āsavā manussalokagamanīyā, atthi āsavā devalokagamanīyā.
analyzed: atthi bhikkhave āsavāḥ niraya gamanīyāḥ atthi āsavāḥ tiracchāna yoni gamanīyāḥ atthi āsavāḥ pettivisaya gamanīyāḥ atthi āsavāḥ manussa loka gamanīyāḥ atthi āsavāḥ deva loka gamanīyāḥ
translated: There are taints leading to hell, taints leading to the animal realm, taints leading to the realm of afflicted spirits, taints leading to the human world, and taints leading to the world of the gods.

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, āsavānaṁ vemattatā.
analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave āsavānam vematta tā
translated: This is called the diversity of the taints.

original: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, āsavānaṁ vipāko?
analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhave āsavānam vipākaḥ
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, is the result of the taints?

original: Yaṁ kho, bhikkhave, avijjāgato tajjaṁ tajjaṁ attabhāvaṁ abhinibbatteti puññabhāgiyaṁ vā apuññabhāgiyaṁ vā, ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, āsavānaṁ vipāko.
analyzed: yam kho bhikkhave avijjā gataḥ tajjam tajjam atta bhāvam abhinibbatteti puññabhāgiyam vā apuññabhāgiyam vā ayam vuccati bhikkhave āsavānam vipākaḥ
translated: When one subject to taints generates a particular form, generates a particular feeling, generates a particular perception, generates a particular formation, generates a particular consciousness subject to taints, that is called the result of the taints.

original: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, āsavanirodho?
analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhave āsava nirodhaḥ
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, is the cessation of the taints?

original: Avijjānirodho, bhikkhave, āsavanirodho.
analyzed: avijjā nirodhaḥ bhikkhave āsava nirodhaḥ
translated: The cessation of ignorance is the cessation of the taints.

original: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṁ—🔽sammādiṭṭhi …pe… sammāsamādhi.
analyzed: ayam eva ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo āsava nirodha gāminī paṭipadā  sammā diṭṭhi pe sammā samādhi
translated: The way leading to the cessation of the taints is this Noble Eightfold Path; that is, right view … right concentration.

original: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṁ āsave pajānāti, evaṁ āsavānaṁ nidānasambhavaṁ
analyzed: yatas kho bhikkhave ariya sāvakaḥ evam āsave pajānāti evam āsavānam nidāna sambhava
translated: “When a noble disciple thus understands the taints, their origin, their cessation, and the way leading to their cessation,

original: yathākammūpage satte pajānāti, idampi, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṁ hoti,🔽yaṁ balaṁ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṁ ṭhānaṁ paṭijānāti, parisāsu sīhanādaṁ nadati,
analyzed: yathā kammūpage satte pajānāti idam pi bhikkhave tathāgatassa tathāgata balam hoti  yam balam āgamma tathāgataḥ āsabham ṭhānam paṭijānāti parisāsu sīha nādam nadati
translated: “The Tathāgata, bhikkhus, understands as it really is the dispositions of other beings, other persons.

original: brahmacakkaṁ pavatteti.
analyzed: brahma cakkam pavatta iti

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, tathāgato āsavānaṁ khayā …pe… sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.🔽Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato āsavānaṁ khayā …pe… sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati,
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave tathāgataḥ āsavānam khayā pe sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati  yam pi bhikkhave tathāgataḥ āsavānam khayā pe sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati
translated: “Again, the Tathāgata understands as it really is the way leading to the cessation of the taints.

original: idampi, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa tathāgatabalaṁ hoti, yaṁ balaṁ āgamma tathāgato āsabhaṁ
analyzed: idam pi bhikkhave tathāgatassa tathāgata balam hoti yam balam āgamma tathāgataḥ
translated: This, bhikkhus, is a Tathāgata’s power that the Tathāgata has, by virtue of which he claims the herd-leader’s place,

translated: roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and sets rolling the Wheel of Brahmā.

analyzed: imāni kho bhikkhave cha tathāgatassa tathāgata balāni yehi balehi samannāgataḥ tathāgataḥ āsabham ṭhānam paṭijānāti parisāsu sīha nādam nadati brahmacakkam pavatteti  tatra ce bhikkhave pare tathāgatam ṭhānam ca ṭhānataḥ a aṭṭhānam ca aṭṭhānataḥ yathābhūtam ñāṇena upasaṅkamitvā pañham pucchanti
translated: “These, bhikkhus, are the six powers of a Tathagata, possessed of which the Tathagata claims the herd-leader’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and sets rolling the Wheel of Brahm a.🔽“Now, bhikkhus, if others should approach the Tathagata and question him about this matter,

original: Yathā yathā, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa ṭhānañca ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṁ🔽ñāṇaṁ viditaṁ tathā tathā tesaṁ tathāgato ṭhānañca ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṁ
analyzed: yathā yathā bhikkhave tathāgatassa ṭhānañca ṭhānataḥ aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānataḥ yathābhūta  ñāṇam viditam tathā tathā tesam tathāgataḥ ṭhānañca ṭhānataḥ aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānataḥ yathābhūta
translated: then the Tathagata would explain to them as they ask,

analyzed: tatra ce bhikkhave pare tathāgatam atīta anāgata paccuppannānam kamma samādānānam ṭhānasaḥ hetusaḥ vipākam yathābhūtam ñāṇena upasaṅkamitvā pañham pucchanti
translated: then the Tathagata would explain to them as they ask,

original: Yathā yathā, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṁ kammasamādānānaṁ ṭhānaso🔽hetuso vipākaṁ yathābhūtaṁ ñāṇaṁ viditaṁ tathā tathā tesaṁ tathāgato atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṁ
analyzed: yathā yathā bhikkhave tathāgatassa atīta anāgata paccuppannānam kamma samādānānam ṭhānaso  hetusaḥ vipākam yathābhūtam ñāṇam viditam tathā tathā tesam tathāgataḥ atīta anāgata paccuppannāna
translated: “As the Tathagata has understood the result of past, future, and present volitional actions in terms of possibilities and causes, so has he explained it.🔽“As the Tathagata has understood the result of past, future, and present volitional actions in terms of possibilities and causes, so has he described it.

original: kammasamādānānaṁ ṭhānaso hetuso vipākaṁ yathābhūtaṁ ñāṇena pañhaṁ puṭṭho byākaroti.
analyzed: kamma samādānānam ṭhānasaḥ hetusaḥ vipākam yathābhūtam ñāṇena pañham puṭṭhaḥ byākaroti
translated: “As the Tathāgata has true knowledge of the result of the undertaking of action in the past, future, and present according to its cause and condition, to that extent he answers questions that arise.

original: Tatra ce, bhikkhave, pare tathāgataṁ jhānavimokkhasamādhisamāpattīnaṁ saṅkilesaṁ vodānaṁ vuṭṭhānaṁ yathābhūtaṁ ñāṇena upasaṅkamitvā pañhaṁ pucchanti.🔽Yathā yathā, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa jhānavimokkhasamādhisamāpattīnaṁ saṅkilesaṁ🔽vodānaṁ vuṭṭhānaṁ yathābhūtaṁ ñāṇaṁ viditaṁ tathā tathā tesaṁ tathāgato jhānavimokkhasamādhisamāpattīnaṁ
analyzed: tatra ce bhikkhave pare tathāgatam jhāna vimokkha samādhi samāpattīnam saṅkilesam vodānam vuṭṭhānam yathābhūtam ñāṇena upasaṅkamitvā pañham pucchanti  yathā yathā bhikkhave tathāgatassa jhāna vimokkha samādhi samāpattīnam saṅkilesa  vodānam vuṭṭhānam yathābhūtam ñāṇam viditam tathā tathā tesam tathāgato jhāna vimokkha samādhi samāpattīnaṃ
translated: “If others approach the Tathāgata and ask him questions about the defilement, cleansing, and emergence in regard to the jhānas, liberations, concentrations, and attainments,

translated: as the Tathāgata has true knowledge of the defilement, cleansing, and emergence in regard to the jhānas, liberations, concentrations, and attainments, to that extent he answers questions that arise.

original: Tatra ce, bhikkhave, pare tathāgataṁ pubbenivāsānussatiṁ yathābhūtaṁ ñāṇena upasaṅkamitvā pañhaṁ pucchanti.🔽Yathā yathā, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa pubbenivāsānussatiṁ yathābhūtaṁ ñāṇaṁ viditaṁ tathā tathā tesaṁ tathāgato pubbenivāsānussatiṁ yathābhūtaṁ ñāṇena pañhaṁ puṭṭho byākaroti.
analyzed: tatra ce bhikkhave pare tathāgatam pubbenivāsa anussatim yathābhūtam ñāṇena upasaṅkamitvā pañham pucchanti  yathā yathā bhikkhave tathāgatassa pubbenivāsa anussatim yathābhūtam ñāṇam viditam tathā tathā tesam tathāgataḥ pubbenivāsa anussatim yathābhūtam ñāṇena pañham puṭṭhaḥ byākaroti

original: Tatra ce, bhikkhave, pare tathāgataṁ sattānaṁ cutūpapātaṁ yathābhūtaṁ ñāṇena upasaṅkamitvā pañhaṁ pucchanti.

translated: then the Tathagata answers their questions according to his knowledge of the passing away and rebirth of beings.

translated: “As the Tathagata has understood the destruction of the taints, so he answers questions that arise.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, yampidaṁ ṭhānañca ṭhānato aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṁ ñāṇaṁ tampi samāhitassa vadāmi no asamāhitassa.🔽Yampidaṁ atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṁ kammasamādānānaṁ ṭhānaso hetuso vipākaṁ yathābhūtaṁ ñāṇaṁ tampi samāhitassa vadāmi no asamāhitassa.

translated: “The knowledge of what is possible and what is impossible is for one who is concentrated, I say, not for one who is unconcentrated.🔽“The knowledge of the result of action in terms of possibilities and causes in the past, future, and present is for one who is concentrated, I say, not for one who is unconcentrated.

original: Yampidaṁ jhānavimokkhasamādhisamāpattīnaṁ saṅkilesaṁ vodānaṁ vuṭṭhānaṁ yathābhūtaṁ ñāṇaṁ tampi samāhitassa vadāmi no asamāhitassa.

translated: “The knowledge of the defilement, the cleansing, and the emergence in regard to the jhanas, liberations, concentrations, and attainments is for one who is concentrated, I say, not for one who is unconcentrated.

analyzed: sīlāni a paripūretvā kāma rāgam vā rūpa rāgam vā arūpa rāgam vā pajahissati iti na etat ṭhānam vijjati  saḥ vata bhikkhave bhikkhu kalyāṇa mittaḥ kalyāṇa sahāyaḥ kalyāṇa sampavaṅkaḥ kalyāṇa mitte
translated: It is impossible for one who has not fulfilled virtue to abandon sensual desire.

translated: It is possible, monks, for a monk who has a good friend, a good companion, a good comrade, who cultivates a good friend, a good companion, a good comrade, and follows his example, to fulfill the training rule on proper conduct.

original: dhammaṁ paripūressatī’ti ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.🔽‘Ābhisamācārikaṁ dhammaṁ paripūretvā sekhaṁ dhammaṁ paripūressatī’ti ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.

translated: it is possible that they will fulfill the Dhamma.🔽it is possible that, having fulfilled the Dhamma of the disciple in higher training, they will fulfill the Dhamma of one beyond training.

original: ‘Sekhaṁ dhammaṁ paripūretvā sīlāni paripūressatī’ti ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.🔽‘Sīlāni paripūretvā kāmarāgaṁ vā rūparāgaṁ vā arūparāgaṁ vā pajahissatī’ti ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī”ti.

translated: it is possible that, having fulfilled the Dhamma of one beyond training, they will fulfill the virtues of one beyond training.

translated: it is possible that, having fulfilled the virtues of one beyond training, they will abandon sensual desire, desire for form, and desire for the formless, and the conceit ‘I am.’”🔽The third section on “is possible” is finished.🔽The Book of the Tens

translated: “It is impossible, monks, it cannot happen that a monk who delights in company, takes delight in company, and devotes himself to delight in company, who delights in large groups, takes delight in large groups, and devotes himself to delight in large groups, will delight in being alone.

translated: It is impossible for one who has not fulfilled right view to fulfill right concentration.🔽It is impossible for one who has not fulfilled right concentration to abandon the fetters.

original: ‘Saṁyojanāni appahāya nibbānaṁ sacchikarissatī’ti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.

translated: It is impossible for one who has not abandoned the fetters to realize Nibbana.

translated: “It is possible, bhikkhus, for a bhikkhu who does not delight in company, who does not enjoy company, who does not find his satisfaction in company,

analyzed: anuyuttaḥ na gaṇa ārāmaḥ na gaṇa rataḥ na gaṇa ārāmatam anuyuttaḥ ekaḥ paviveke abhiramissati iti ṭhānam etam vijjati  ekaḥ paviveke abhiramantaḥ cittassa nimittam gahessati iti ṭhānam etam vijjati
translated: who does not delight in groups, who does not enjoy groups, who does not find his satisfaction in groups,🔽who delights in solitude, who enjoys solitude, who finds his satisfaction in solitude, to discern the sign of the mind.

original: ‘Cittassa nimittaṁ gaṇhanto sammādiṭṭhiṁ paripūressatī’ti ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.

translated: It is possible for one who discerns the sign of the mind to fulfill right view.

original: ‘Sammādiṭṭhiṁ paripūretvā sammāsamādhiṁ paripūressatī’ti ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhim paripūretvā sammāsamādhim paripūressati iti ṭhānam etam vijjati
translated: It is possible that, having fulfilled right view, they will fulfill right concentration.

analyzed: sammāsamādhim paripūretvā sayojanāni pajahissati iti ṭhānam etam vijjati
translated: It is possible that, having fulfilled right concentration, they will abandon the fetters.

original: ‘Saṁyojanāni pahāya nibbānaṁ sacchikarissatī’ti ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī”ti.
analyzed: sayojanāni pahāya nibbānam sacchikarissati iti ṭhānam etam vijjati iti

original: vimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ vimuttaṁ cittanti pajānissatī’ti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.🔽‘Anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarissati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ, dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarissatī’ti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: vimuttam vā cittam vimuttam cittanti pajānissati iti na etat ṭhānam vijjati  aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarissati seyyathīdam ekam pi jāti dve pi jātiyo pe iti sa ākāram sa uddesam aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarissati iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: knowing it as it really is thus: “This person is of such a nature and that person is of such a nature”’—this is impossible.🔽‘He will recollect his manifold past abodes with their aspects and details’—this is impossible.

original: ‘Dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passissati …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānissatī’ti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.

translated: ‘With the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, he will see beings passing away and arising: … he will understand how beings pass on according to their actions’—this is impossible.

original: ‘Āsavānaṁ khayā …pe… sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissatī’ti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.🔽‘So vata, bhikkhave, bhikkhu santena samādhinā paṇītena paṭippassaddhiladdhena ekodibhāvādhigatena
analyzed: āsavānam khayā pe sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati iti na etat ṭhānam vijjati  saḥ vata bhikkhave bhikkhu santena samādhinā paṇītena paṭippassaddhi laddhena ekodibhāva adhigatena
translated: It is impossible for him to realize the undefiled freedom of mind, freedom by wisdom, right here and now, and to dwell in it having realized it for himself with direct knowledge.

original: anekavihitaṁ iddhividhaṁ paccanubhavissati …pe… yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṁ vattessatī’ti ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: aneka vihitam iddhi vidham paccanubhavissati pe yāva brahmalokā api kāyena vasam vattessati iti ṭhānam etam vijjati
translated: It is possible that a monk with such concentration, flexible, malleable, wieldy, and radiant, might wield the various kinds of psychic power: having been one, he becomes many; having been many, he becomes one; he appears and vanishes; he goes unhindered through a wall, through a rampart, through a mountain as though through space; he dives in and out of the earth as though through water; he goes on unbroken water as though on earth; seated cross-legged he travels through space like a bird; with his hand he touches and strokes even the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful; he wields bodily mastery even as far as the Brahmā world.

original: ‘Dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇissati—dibbe ca mānuse ca ye dūre santike cā’ti ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkanta mānusikāya ubho sadde suṇissati dibbe ca mānuse ca ye dūre santike ca ati ṭhānam etam vijjati
translated: It is possible that with the divine ear element, which is purified and surpasses the human, he might hear both kinds of sounds, the divine and human, those that are far as well as near.🔽It is possible that he might understand the minds of other beings and persons, having encompassed them with his own mind.

original: ‘Parasattānaṁ parapuggalānaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānissati—🔽sarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ sarāgaṁ cittanti pajānissati …pe…
analyzed: para sattānam para puggalānam cetasā cetaḥ paricca pajānissati  sa rāgam vā cittam sa rāgam cittanti pajānissati pe
translated: He might understand a mind with passion as a mind with passion,🔽and a mind without passion as a mind without passion;🔽a mind with aversion as a mind with aversion, and a mind without aversion as a mind without aversion;🔽a mind with delusion as a mind with delusion, and a mind without delusion as a mind without delusion;🔽a restricted mind as restricted, and a scattered mind as scattered;🔽a developed mind as developed, and an undeveloped mind as undeveloped;🔽a surpassable mind as surpassable, and an unsurpassable mind as unsurpassable;🔽concentrated mind as concentrated, and an unconcentrated mind as unconcentrated;

original: vimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ vimuttaṁ cittanti pajānissatī’ti ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: vimuttam vā cittam vimuttam cittanti pajānissati iti ṭhānam etat vijjati
translated: liberated mind as liberated, and an unliberated mind as unliberated.

original: ‘Anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarissati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ, dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarissatī’ti ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.🔽‘Dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passissati cavamāne upapajjamāne
analyzed: aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarissati seyyathīdam ekam pi jāti dve pi jātiyo pe iti sa ākāram sa uddesam aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarissati iti ṭhānam etam vijjati  dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena satte passissati cavamāne upapajjamāne
translated: It’s possible that he will recollect his many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

original: hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānissatī’ti ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathā kammūpage satte pajānissati iti ṭhānam etam vijjati
translated: It’s possible that with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, he will see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He will understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.

original: ‘Āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ …pe… sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissatī’ti ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī”ti.
analyzed: āsavānam khayā anāsavam cetaḥ vimuttim pe sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati iti ṭhānam etam vijjati iti
translated: It’s possible that he will realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements.”

original: Chaṭṭhaṁ.
